We were a large group which I'm sure is never easy but there were about 20 minutes between the first and last people being served. This is unacceptable. Everyone's dish looked good so I will give it another chance if I'm nearby.
author: Gonzalo S.

description:
After a year, we're going our separate ways!

The good: decent Thai fusion, lots of choices, nice presentation, pretty waitresses. 

The bad: pricey for what you get, spotty delivery service, take-out got increasingly bad.

We have given this place PLENTY of business over the past year, and we have
forgiven the times that one of the 7 entrees ordered had been forgotten.
We have also forgiven the fact that sometimes they deliver and sometimes they don't..
which is really crappy because they still show up on grubhub on the days they don't.
I suppose that's the price to pay for a pretty convenient location.. 

Unfortunately yesterday was the last straw T_T
I called my 3-entree order at 11:15 and was told it would have been ready in 20 minutes.
I arrived around 11:35, and accidentally put 22 minutes in the meter.
I was told they were still finishing up my order.. fair enough, I have waited a few minutes before.
Place was deserted, and there were at least half a dozen employees.
After 20 minutes, I'm wondering where my order is because my meter is about to expire,
and I'm told by the waiter that I should probably add more money to the meter O_O
Really?! I thought he was kidding, but alas he was not..
At 12:06 I get my food and I ask whether they can give me a discount or a comp spring roll for the wait
and I'm told "oh, we don't do that"

After waiting for 50+ minutes for a tiny order for THE SECOND TIME IN A MONTH,
stay assured that neither I nor any of my coworkers will be coming again.
There are too many Thai options in the area to get away with bad service.
Forgive you for this? Oh, we don't do that. 

Farewell, Koh Samui!
author: Jade T.

description: Despite its terrible delivery service, its portions and price for portions was outlandish.  The only way to describe such portions is that if I had a 7 year old daughter who was  having a tea party for her dollies, the portions would not have satisfied even them.  They are not deserving of one star. For the portions we received at $72.00 for two, we could have had dinner and drinks at a number of upper scale downtown establishments.
author: Stephen O.

description:
this is a great spot for either lunch or dinner. i stopped in for lunch and was pleased with the many menu options, speed of service, and quality of the food.

they offer a few different pricing options for lunch outside of the regular menu. there are 2- and 3-course meals, in addition to bento boxes. i was hungry but not starving, so i decided to stick to one dish.

as soon as the waitress took our order, she came back with small bowls of soup. it was a clear broth with tofu, bok choy, carrots, and mushrooms. this was a great way to start the meal since it was a lighter broth with just enough flavor to get me ready for more. i then had the tom yum papaya salad, which is one of my favorite thai entrees. the flavor was excellent - slightly spicy and balanced excellently with the sweet fruit. i wish the shrimp had a bit more flavor, but they were fresh. i also got some sticky rice on the side.

prices were extremely reasonable, and the food is good. i would definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone who happens to be in the area.
author: Jamie H.

description:
A good Thai place but nothing great about it!

The food and decor were ok. Alongside the waitress, we were also greeted by an old weird lady. We had Mojito, Imperial Rolls, Tom Kha Gai Soup and Panang Beef Curry. As I said earlier, everything was good but nothing great.

I must mention here that they have a super fast and prompt service, so prompt that the server was too keen to take my plate away while I was still working.
author: Suchismita D.

description:
Got dinner to go from Koh Samui and picked it up when it was ready. Ordered the clay pot with sea bass, glass noodles and vegetables in a soy based sauce (needless to say, there was no clay pot). 

The food was mediocre, but should have been better for the price. The flavor of the noodles was there, but the whole meal just didn't taste very fresh. The noodles were lukewarm and the vegetables soggy, making me feel that the food wasn't cooked to order. The sea bass was the worst part...it was on the bottom of the noodles, not too moist and not much flavor and overall disappointing. 

I had come to here in the past and remember the food being alright, so maybe the to go orders are a fluke.
author: Ronnie S.

description:
Service was terrible. I ended up leaving the place without eating so cannot comment for the food.
I came here for lunch and ordered Wonton Noodle Soup. The place was very busy and I had to wait for a long time. Afrer about 15 minutes I asked my waiter if my dish was coming and he said it was coming right up.
Then after 25 minutes, he came back and told me that they were out of wonton. 
I screamed YOU'VE GOT BE KIDDING...
They totally ruined my precious 1 hr lunch break.
author: Hide S.

description:
I've had pad thai at many thai restaurants and this place ranks amongst the worst I've tasted.  The entire dish was way too oily, with soggy noodles.  

2 stars for the decor which is nice.
author: Peter Y.

description:
Server dropped sauce on my shoes and RUINED them!!!! Didn't apologize (he was clearly embarrassed) and just walked away. 

The shoes are COMPLETELY ruined!!!!

The oil in the sauce will not come out and I'm stuck with a very expensive cleaning bill. Very VERY unprofessional service. 

The food isnt even that great so needless to say I'm pissed. I work in SoMa so I plan on letting all my coworkers know about this as there are clearly much better Thai places around.
author: Tal Y.

description: Been here a few times. The food is good, but not great. The chicken satay is decent. The pad thai is quite bland. The drunken noodles are a hit or miss: sometimes great, but sometimes so greasy they'll make you sick. There are not a ton of options for food around SOMA where I work, so it's not bad if you just want some warm food.
author: Rita K.

description: Sitting at the restaurant, waiting for the bill and writing this review...the food is not bad, but the quantity is ridiculous. We ordered the Andaman Sea Bass, Jurassic Park Shrimp and tom yum soup. The tom yum was the worst that we've ever had. It was very sweet with big whole pieces of cherry tomatoes floating in it. When the sea bass arrived, the tiny little piece of fish was hidden under a bed of huge pile of veggies. The fish was so less, $20 for the plate it was shocking. We were 2 in our group. When we divided the fish it was exactly two spoonfuls. One spoon for each of us!! The shrimp was also quite small, but not as less as the fish. For $55 (without tip) we left feeling cheated. There are many Thai restaurants in and around Soma where you can get a good portion of protein for $55! While walking out, I politely told them about the disappointment about the food and the quantity. I was told that sea bass is very expensive that's why the portion is so small. Sea Bass is also one of my fav fishes and I order it in other restaurants quite often. Never have I been served two spoonfuls of fish hidden under piles of onions, red peppers and some leafy vegetable. So watch out for the Monkey! I think the Monkey eats most of the food before it is served to you!
author: Pakhi P.

description:
While I generally will avoid sub-4 star restaurants in the Bay (call me a snob, but I've found that even most 4 star restaurants have been mediocre here), it was almost 9pm on a Thursday night, we were without a car, and my friend was hungry, somewhat broke, and also in heels. Koh Samui managed to fit the bill, so we trekked the one block to get there, glanced over a well-rounded menu, and ordered the Miracle Duck and Basil Gai for entrees, two sides of rice, and a green tea creme brulee for dessert.

Overall, everything was just okay, with nothing that stood out. The duck curry had good flavor overall (a bit sweet, with a bit of kick), but the texture of the duck was a bit unusual, and more akin to chicken. The basil gai was even less interesting: a simple stir-fried ground chicken dish that was a bit on the sweet side as well. And the creme brulee was a bit disappointing because the green tea flavor was not noticeable at all. 

Service was very friendly, while the decor was interesting (very thematic, if any anything, which can sometimes err on the side of being too touristy). Total bill came out to $57 after tax and tip, which was probably a bit more than we were aiming for (they charge $2-3 dollars for a bowl of rice). All in all, not a bad Thai restaurant, but given the other options available to you in the city, there are much, much better places for your money (Ler Ros and Basil Thai, for example).

As an aside - one will notice that the restaurant is actually up on the second floor. For those in wheelchairs, they have a wheelchair lift near the entrance that you can self-operate to get up there.
author: Johnny W.

description:
This is my favorite place for Thai food in the city.

It's a large place, so there's always seating, and the food's very good.  They are great at customizing (I like it spicier than most).  

This is a conveniently located place that makes decent Thai, easy to get in and out, quick with your order, and they can handle special requests.
author: Rob H.

description:
I was in the Bay Area last week for some work related training and all I could think of was where was I going to eat.  I found Koh Sammui & the Monkey on one of my yelp friends reviews.  The review was well done and my experience matched my expectations.  I thank all of the yelpers for their time and effort in making sure we a good clear picture of a location.
I love the fact that I can eat a local establishment that most out of town people would never realize even existed.   I started with the fresh spring roll, Basil Gai ground chicken med heat, coconut steamed rice and the traditional Bangkok Pad Thai with chicken.  All topped off with a cold Singha that hit the spot after a long day of learning stuff. 
The service was excellent; the atmosphere was elegant yet friendly.  This is the perfect place to take a date.  I have added it to my list of places to return with my wife.  
Good eats
author: JORGE R.

description:
I had a groupon that needs to be used by August. We didn't read the fineprint that stated it was not honored on Fridays. We said, screw it. It's late Friday evening already and we didn't want to deal with the hassle. I'm at the point where I almost don't even care to use the groupon anymore. 

The one star rating is warranted in the way this establishment treats their patrons. As stated in my previous review, they don't consistently charge as advertised. They also don't seem to comprehend the fact they are in customer service. 

The ruckus I'm about to describe was a nearby couple that I felt horrendously bad for, but the interaction pretty much destroyed my dining experience. They had called in earlier and inquired if the groupon could be used. The person they spoke to on the phone confirmed that it could and made a reservation for them. They came, completed their meal and so began a pretty lengthly, verbal battle between Koh Samui versus the groupon couple. Although they were verbally told when making their reservation it was allowable, the server and shift manager would not budge. There was zero remorse and minimal accountability. In fact, the on shift manager began to threaten the patrons if they would not pay the bill. She offered a partial discount, but wouldn't honor the groupon. She began to threaten the patrons that she would call the police. 

These people were trying to enjoy a meal and you pretty much not only ruined theirs, you ruined mine as well. 

If companies don't want to deal with the repercussions of deals like groupon, living social, etc., DON'T USE IT. 

For the owners, teach your staff basic etiquette and fundamentals of customer service.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Ambiance:  This place is very modern.  For a Thai restaurant, it's very buttoned up as well.  I found the front bar to be amply stocked and the decor to be impressively chic.  Like Jon C. said, the area outside of the restaurant isn't necessarily the best -- but I enjoyed that the windows were large enough to see the foot traffic outside (who doesn't like people watching?) and vice versa.

Service:  Very friendly!  They also know the menu backwards and forwards.  

Food:  ZOMG!  TRY the calamari!  I uploaded a picture... it was soooo good!  We paired it with some of their signature cocktails and we almost filled up too much before dinner.  It was still really, really good.

TIP:  With enough advanced planning, you can easily get a group of 10 in here.  WE DID.

TIP:  TRY one of their signature cocktails.  Really good!  And you get a little plastic monkey in the place of a tropical umbrella. :)
author: Bryan H.

description: This place should be banished (along with the current Thai prime minister) for doing injustice to Thai food and local patrons. It's high prices combined with terrible quality food should be a crime. Case in point, the duck curry over rice. As one of the more expensive items on the menu, I was shocked when a cold plate of duck fat, bone and skin arrived (late no less.) I immediately sent it back. Also judging by other people's plates, I wrote this place off. I'll add on an extra star because the staff is pleasant, and I like the name, and I like the sister spot in the Mission much better. But the total lack of respect to one of the world's better cuisines along with a half-assed attempt to make it hip won't be taken lightly by me. And in particular, the take out lunch case... Ugh. What a total disgrace.
author: Brian J.

description:
I was expecting a lot better, but like many others before me, I was also disappointed with this place. 

Food: 2/10 - I had a Green Papaya Salad (which wasn't as flavorful as it should be) and a Chicken Pad Thai (which was bland with crap on top of it). The GPS wasn't sweet or tangy but rather it was a little stale and somewhat bland. The pad thai was greasy and also very bland. Not even the hot sauce helped. I think the only thing they did relatively okay on is my thai iced tea.

Service: 7/10 - The waitress was really nice and very friendly as well as some of the other staff members. 

Prices: 1/10 - Expensive for crappy food. 

Overall: 3/10 - Food was meh and very pricey. However, the staff were great when I went there and that boosts their rating just a bit. I would avoid though since there are plenty of better thai places around SoMA.
author: Billy W.

description:
What a disappointment. Although the red monkey cocktail, a blend of lime vodka, French ginger liqueur, fresh lime, sweet & sour, and pomegranate was good; the rest of the meal went downhill. The beef in the sirloin salad was tough, the tom ka soup was average and the scallops were just okay.  I think P and I had something else but neither us can remember what we had a few days later. I can enjoy better Thai food in my local neighborhood restaurants.

Ah the service, we were asked if what we wanted to order before we even were given menus and then not even give enough time to decide before we were asked again. Yet, when it came time to pay the bill it took forever to get our check.
author: Terry T.

description:
For thai food, this was incredibly disappointing.

First, I went around 5:30. There was a decent number of people at the bar for happy hour, and maybe 3 tables seated. Service was slow, and they were clearly understaffed. The service was super friendly though, and they consistently attempted to make sure everything was ok.

The food.. I had the Meing Kham, which was incredibly overpriced (7.5 for 6 leaves? WHAT) and instead of giving you the little bowls of everything, they pre made the leaves with a mix of depression, and totally not fresh.

The Pad Thai was what really set me off though. Bland, the noodles seemed to be coated in oil rather than pan fried in it. No crunchy deliciousness to be found. They also topped the pad thai with some weird ass salad greens that were bitter and didn't help anything.

Go here for happy hour (the bar was quite busy and they had good deals), and eat somewhere else.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Their cashew chicken was superb! The right amount of crunch and flavor. I don't recommend the lemonade since it's a bit too tart, but other then that the service and the food was fantastic!

Will certainly be coming back.
author: Marisa K.

description:
Don't go unless someone has a gun to your head, and even then, make sure the assailant is paying.

It's hard to know where to start to warrant a 1 star, so I guess I'll go with chronology.

I ordered takeout and got the emerald curry and some spring rolls.  I was a little concerned when I went to pick up my order and was greeted by a dingy, depressing decor. I paid my $36, picked up my food and left. That's a bit pricey for curry and spring rolls, but I took a gamble that it was worth it. 

When I got home, I found that they had not included rice in the order. Assuming that it was just a mistake, I called them up to get an order prepared. They informed me that rice isn't included with a curry order. What?! That's like ordering a PB&J and being told that you have to order the bread separately.  

So it's not a $20 curry. It's a $22.50 curry.  Thats right, a $22.50 curry from a restaurant nobody has ever heard of. 

So I decided to take a bite of my spring rolls while I fumed over being bamboozled. Imagine my surprise (note heavy sarcasm) when I bit into iceberg lettuce poorly wrapped in rice paper.  That was $9.

I will give them credit that the curry was actually decent, so if they shaved about $8 off the price, it might be passable.
author: Luke K.

description:
VERY EXPENSIVE for very so-so portions.  $19 for a small curry dish with 2 shrimp and 2 scallops - Really?  $17 for a medium size portion of Pad Thai with barely a trace of seafood?

And ready for this?  Rice is not included in a $19 curry dish.  So the curry ended up costing $22 for a small portion, with just a little seafood that was served LUKE WARM.

STAY AWAY
author: SF Y.

description:
3.5 stars - came here for dinner with hubby and found a space right in front.  It was half full and we were lead to sit at a four top table even though there were quite a few 2 tops available.  Not complaining since we tend to order a lot of food.

While we were going over the menu, our waitress came by and told us about their prix fixe at $40/person that includes a glass of wine, about 9 dishes total and dessert - quite a deal but it didn't have the items we were considering so we opted to order our own.  What we had:

Fat Tire ($5) for hubby and Thai iced tea ($3) for me.  

Emperor steamed dumpling - stuffed w/ mixed pork, calamari and shrimp served with ponzu sauce - $10 - it looks like a pillow, tasted ok.

Crispy imperial rolls stuffed w/ ground pork, wood ear fungus, veggies and taro topped w/ fresh carrot - $8 - cut in half lengthwise and stacked them up for presentation purpose, not a fan at all.  The sauce was too sweet and too much of it.  

Sea bass Mor Din - steamed seabass sauteed w/ vermicelli noodle, shitake mushroom, broccoli and carrots - $16 - it was ok.

Eggplant tofu sauteed w/ bell pepper, fresh basil in chili and garlic sauce - $9 - it was ok, a bit on the greasy side

Young pepper pork - $13 - this was the best dish.  It has a nice spicy flavor to it - the pork was pretty tender.

Steamed jasmine rice - $2.50.

We mixed the eggplant tofu to the pork and brought it home.
author: Gloria H.

description: I just work up the street and it's a pretty good Thai place to go to if you're looking to get a quick lunch. They have a to-go section where you can quickly pick up food and of course the option to dine in. My favorite is their yellow curry with jasmine rice. So good!
author: Janelle L.

description:
Great Thai restaurant  - Decor is quite impressive , food is tasty , staff is friendly.
We had a early dinner on a weekday - service was quick.  And they do take their spice levels seriously - a Thai hot is hot !
author: The M.

description:
Even as a San Franciscan, I had never heard of this place, but it was a fabulous night. The samosa's were delicious and made out of sweet potato. The chicken satay w/peanut sauce was great. And my BBQ chicken w/delicious and filling sticky rice was perfect. Prices were fair, considering how nice the place was. Our waitress should win "Waitress of the Year", she was that nice. And the 2 monkey beers on tap(w/ plastic monkey toy thingy) got me pretty good. 

Thank you to Valeria for inviting me and it was a pleasure to share dinner with all these great CM's from around the world.
author: Andrew T.

description:
AMAZING! That's what it is - food and service wise. I was there with a group of 15 people and have to say. Every dish looked really yummie and not one dish was similar than the other. Sometimes dishes can look and taste very similar in asian cuisine.  
I went for the vegetarian Samosas with red jam, carrot, yam, corn, wood-ear fungus and jicama served with cucumber salad for a starter. Really tasty and quite a big portion - for $8 a fair deal. For mains i had the Koh Tao - flat rice noodle topped with peanut sauce served with spinach, cucumber and sesame seeds and Tofu. The pieces of Tofu were huge and it was really perfectly fried- not too long which makes  it taste like rubber. No this one was perfect! I really loved it. 

Linda our waitress scared me at some point as she was super friendly - kind of unnaturally friendly. :-D Actutally by far the most friendliest waitress during my time in San Francisco. She was always smiling and was totally organized. She knew exactly what i had when we split up the bill ( remember we were 15 people) Water was always refilled without asking but smiling. The atmosphere at Koh Samui & The Monkey is really nice as well. Dimmed light, nice Asian furniture and of course a bunch of Buddha statues everywhere. What i didn't like that much were the flatscreens near the bar broadcasting some sports games. This was a bit detracting the whole atmosphere, but i guess this is a European thing. If i am out for dinner i wanna eat and don't watch TV. In general really liked the place and i can highly recommend it to people that love Thai food!
author: Verena S.

description: Bangkok bbq chicken is disgusting, feels like dog food, waiter didn't even asked if I like it, i guess he s used to see customers not eating their meals
author: Tony T.

description: My friend raved about this place and it was her birthday. The calamari had this green sauce to die for.  That was the best part.  Really. I prefer OSHA if ur gonna spend the $ anyways.
author: Virgo M.

description:
This restaurant is right down the street from my apartment.  I really enjoyed the Pineapple Fried Rice, Pumpkin Curry, and their Pad Thai.  This restaurant is exactly what you'd expect out of a Thai restaurant.  The only thing is that I felt the prices were a bit high for each dish.  Completely understandable, since it's the city, but I did feel that each dish was a notch too expensive.

The service was extremely good.  At Koh Samui & The Monkey, you can always expect your drinks to be full.  Even if you have 1/4 of your drink, they will still ask you if you want another one without hesitation.  Overall, a great selection on the menu and one of the few Thai restaurants in SoMA besides Osha.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Great 'happy monkey hour'! 5p to 7p everyday.

It was a tough week and I honed in on the $3 beer special (except Delirium which is a bit more) and the $6 Pad Kee Mao with tofu (noodles, red bell peppers, basil, tomatoes and Thai chili peppers.) It was a generous size for happy hour, and the noodles cooked just right with a delicious blend of flavors. If you want extra fire, request the chili sauces (just beware of the sliced green peppers, just one slice kept the rest of my meal toasty!).

In addition to this, they offer special prices on select appetizers and entrees, wine and well drinks.

Great bartenders and service. I look forward to another monkey happy hour!
author: Cathy K.

description:
It isn't often that I leave a place feeling this angry. 

I think KS&TM should rename itself to Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde. A couple months ago, I had a nice time on a Dr. J night - we had a large party of people, but the service was relatively efficient. The food was pretty good. I had a plate of seabass that was extremely tasty and my drink was decent too. I thought - wow, how have I missed coming to this place? especially since it was a five minute walk from my house. I envisioned becoming a neighborhood regular and ordering some takeout on movie nights. I would have rated the place about 2.5-3 stars. 

A few days later, I decided to take my sister there for some decent Thai food and a repeat of the seabass dish. Clearly Mr Hyde was in the house. Despite having a reservation, we waited to be seated in the half empty restaurant for 20 minutes. Not sure where the hostess was on a Sat night, but it wasn't at the desk. Once we got the table, it took quite a while to get someone to take an order. Then it took 30 minutes to get an order of spring rolls (which were ok, but nothing special). After scarfing down our appetizer, we waited 45 minutes with no sign of our entrees. I managed to flag someone to check on our food, but she didn't bother to return. During this time, other tables around us ordered, finished eating and left. 75 minutes...

Finally, I was just about to blow a gasket when someone came by with a tray of food. Unfortunately, it was not what we had ordered. 

At that point, I couldn't take it anymore, threw a twenty on the table, and we left. The waitress couldn't even be bothered to ask why (she was chitchatting with her little friends in the back). If I had waited for a bill I think I would still be there.

I am not an angry person. I don't throw tantrums very often. This was some of the WORST service I have ever had! They are on my NO GO list!

ARGH!!
author: Connie B.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place for years and finally did. I like the ambiance and convenient (for the soma crowd) location. I ordered the items below and 1 and 2 (the mains) were good but the appetizers were subpar. 

1. Mango wok tossed, sub in shrimp
2. Penang curry, sub in chicken
3. Rice
4. Tom kha soup was soso
5. Satay chicken was lower grade chicken, not as good
author: Mike G.

description:
I love this place. I've been there a few times this year, and I always love it.

It's please is nice, the food is good, and the staff is great! I've gotten to know some of them, and I enjoy just talking to them when they get a min. Raffy the manager (may have spelled his name wrong) is really great.

There's really nothing I don't like about this place :)
author: Maria S.

description:
I've passed by this place maybe on two occasions.  It looked nice from the outside and it was very packed so I thought "let me add this place on my bucket list".   

Last night the Mister and I stopped by here because we were on our way to the Giants game and didn't want to pay bank to eat overly processed and bland ballpark food.  Not impressed.  The food was just as bland and equally overly priced.  He ordered chicken pad thai: bland, unseasoned chicken, terrible presentation, cold tofu pieces that smelled sour (old).  I ordered tom yum goong extra spicy: very bland, no flavor dimension, very sweet and not close to extra spicy like I ordered.  We also had the bags of gold: tasty inside and nice presentation.  That's about it folks, nothing to rant and rave about and definitely not a place I'll be visiting any time soon, if ever at all...

Note: There is a pretty nice bar set up.  Several flat screen TVs and at one point the place even set up a projector which played the game...this is the only real positive.
author: Nancy P.

description:
I was trying to leave town and got stuck in horrible Bay traffic. So we pulled over and  sure enough, there was Koh Samui -- right in front of us.

We were hungry so we said why not, let's try it out. Our phones weren't even getting reception, so we had to do what the kids did in the olden days.... 

TRY A RESTAURANT WITHOUT YELP!!! EEEEK -- 2011 b.y (before yelp).

Well, first thing that rocked was that it was happy hour (4-7, if I remember right). It was like 6:50 and they nicely ushered us to a bar table where we had our drink and food orders in by 6:55!

The beers are $2-3. Awesome. Singha or regular drafts, even Blue moons for cheap. 

Then apps were all bomb! Ranging from $5-9, we ordered like the entire happy hour menu!

~The chicken satay was 5 bux and great--the peanut sauce was the highlite.

~The BBQ pork was marinated brilliantly, but the meat was a bit fatty. And at $9 I would stick to the others.

~The Yellow curry was amazing and worth the $9.

~The pad thai was decent at $5, but the pad see ew is better for only 2 bux more.

I would come to this place again next time I'm in the Bay for some very very Happy hour!!!
author: Bobby C.

description:
To help me with this review, I have asked Dieter, the anally erect host of Sprockets, to interject with anomalous comments that disturb him almost to the point of insanity ...There. He is insane now.

"Would you like to touch my monkey? Touch him! Touch my monkey!"

Koh Samui & the Monkey sounds like a Siamese organ grinder and his pimpy chimp with the little bellboy hat and an even littler tin cup. But no, it's not....it's really an industrial-chic Thai restaurant with lots of Pier One touches to remind you that hey, you're in a Thai restaurant.

..."I am so filled with anticipation that my genitals have sucked up into my body cavity."

Saturday in the early afternoon is a great time to go there. It's empty since you can barely tell it's open from the street. Jamie W. and I realized neither of us had been there in quite a while. He used to work a block away and get take-out, and I used to meet colleagues there after work. When it's quiet, the open space makes the place seem more inviting. That and the staff is relaxed and constantly smiling in that true Thai manner.

..."I appreciate a warm hand on my opening....your story has become tiresome."

We are trying to eat healthier these days, so we went for three dishes that did not appear to make our triglycerides do a sizable uptick. First up was the $8 Crying Tiger Salad, a provocatively named dish that mixed grilled strips of beef with lime juice, various herbs, chili flakes and red onion. Deliciously savory. I was genuinely excited to see Pea Shoots in Garlic as a vegetable side since I haven't had them since a visit to Ton Kiang out on Geary a couple of years ago. Extremely tasty with a nice bite to them.

..."Now I am as happy as a little girl!" (Dieter is now pinching his black spandex shirt to simulate the erection of his nipples.)

Our main entree was the $10 Bangkok B.B.Q. Chicken which came with a tangy green papaya salad. The chicken came in small pieces perfectly grilled. We were sated. The only blight on the afternoon were the expensive Diet Cokes, $3 a glass and no refills.

..."I feel spent...like a man who is forced to wear his genitals around his neck like a pendant."

Jamie and I decided we need to come back here more often, as this and Basil are easily the two best Thai restaurants in SoMa. By the way, what's with those funky "Lost and Found" postcards of faux-missing dogs in the restroom? I think they would have been funnier in a Vietnamese place since their fictitious canine dishes are the stuff of legend.

 ..."I am emotionally obliterated ...now is the time on Sprockets when we dance ...DANCE!"

FOOD - 5 stars...really like every dish I've had at this place...fresh and never sauce-laden
AMBIANCE - 5 stars...love the open space, and hey, I like Pier One
SERVICE - 5 stars...forever smiling and attentive
TOTAL - 5 stars... Dieter has the final word: "This restaurant pulls down my pants and taunts me. But not in a mean-spirited way. It looks at me when I'm naked and calls its friends."...need I say more.
author: Ed U.

description: Fantastic food. Some of the best peanut sauce and rice noodles. Services was fast and high quality. Would eat again.
author: Brian M.

description:
After leaving an amazing Yelp event, the boyfriend and I were hungry and my feet hurt, so we walked over to the nearby Koh Samui & The Money. It's average rating is 3.5 stars, which describes it perfectly but which I cannot award here. I think the dishes are just slightly overpriced because of the area, but the honey duck curry and pad thai were definitely tasty. 

I think my boyfriend wished there was more actual curry and duck and less veggies, but my pad thai made a great late-night meal when I got home. The place is cute and has a huge bar, so - heads up - I can imagine it gets a bit crazy on game days. I might try other restaurants in the area first, but I wouldn't be bummed if fate brought me there again.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Been eating lunch here about once a week on average for the past 9 years. Management and service varies as it does with most places. I notice many of the more negative food reviews are when people get food to go.

For me their food must be eaten right out of the kitchen. The preparation on the noodles is hard to beat. Everything is very fresh with attention to detail and presentation. Every other Thai place I got to in the East Bay seems second rate by comparison.

Also, I eat at the bar especially where there is World Cup or NCAA Tournament, so it is a good place to eat solo. The dining area is very loud and not the best place for a group that wants intimate conversation.
author: Geoff L.

description:
Yum, so good. The pumpkin curry is amazing. The taste and texture of the pumpkin were something unexpected and quite lovely. Highly recommend this item.

Service was great, just the right amount of visits to the table without being overbearing. Definitely a dining experience worth having.
author: Samantha U.

description:
Now I have some issues with this place. Of the four times I've eaten here for lunch in the past 2 mos, THREE times has my order been wrong!

While they have a "to-go" bar in the back room, the menu options are VERY limited, so in order to get what you want, you must order from the normal lunch menu.

After the 3rd time, I called them to explain how they've screwed up yet again. The woman told me to come back and explain to the manager who should provide a meal at no cost.

Well when I went in to do just that, they looked at me like I had 8 heads.

Never again will I have to worry about my order being correct b/c I won't be going here again unless I get my meal pro bono.
author: Rick P.

description:
So I was curious about the recent drop in rating, because I had been here a couple times about 3 years ago and loved it.

After my recent return, I can say that the food is as good as ever. That being said, there are definitely a couple things that have changed for the worse. They have crammed in way too many tables in the space that they have... almost all were occupied, but it really doesn't create a positive dining experience when you are surrounded by other tables within an arm's reach. (A claustrophobic's nightmare!) And you can only imagine how loud it would be! We requested to sit at a table on the side, which was still quite loud, but bearable. In addition, when I dined here previously, they used to carve the outside of the "pumpkin" in which they serve the pumpkin curry... it was a nice touch. But it seems they no longer do this...

We ordered the Bags of Gold and Corn Fritters for appetizers. Both were excellent. The pumpkin curry was delicious as always... one of the best red curries I've ever had, and the pieces of squash are so yummy! Our server recommended it with shrimp, which was a nice change from the usual chicken. The grilled chicken was our least favorite... the flavor was okay, but the chicken itself was dry, and my bf detested the papaya salad it came with even though he generally loves green papaya! Aside from that, our server was very friendly and energetic... no complaints about the service.

Overall, I really enjoy the food here. The atmosphere would be nice if it weren't so cramped... Change that, and Koh Samui would be back to a solid 4 stars.
author: Kavita S.

description: I love this place. But Ive never eaten in before. We usually get take out and it's delicious!!! Their volcano fried rice is amazing! LOVE the catfish curry! So flavorful. Ive been to Thailand before and this is as authentic as it gets. And their honey roasted duck curry...yummmmy. This food is perfect for take out and never gets soggy on the way home.
author: sofia r.

description:
4 stars for the food, but 1 star only for the price.

I used to live in the Inner Richmond, where Pumpkin Curry at King of Thai cost 8.95. It cost 20 bucks here! 

After splitting an appetizer with my partner and ordering a curry, the bill between us both was $57...sorry, but way, way too expensive for a Thai restaurant. 

The value is not worth the price tag.
author: Peter-Christian P.

description:
With fresh spring rolls, spicy curries, and smiling service, Koh Samui and the Monkey serves up pricey, but delicious Thai food in SOMA.

Light and crunchy, fresh spring rolls ($9) with shrimp, mint leaf, lettuce, tofu, carrot, noodle and bean sprouts are the perfect beginning to a meal.  Popular in Thailand, but rarely found on menus in The City, mieng kum ($8) features an array items--peanuts, roasted coconut, fresh lime, ginger, onion, and fresh chopped Thai chili peppers--that diners wrap in spinach leaves and eat:  the perfect finger food.  

Tasty but not exceptional, chicken satay ($5) is served with the de rigueur peanut sauce and cucumber salad.  Piquantly spicy, tom yum kung soup ($6) with prawns and mushroom is redolent of lemongrass and kaffir lime.  Sea bass ($16) simmered in green curry with green beans, bell pepper, fresh basil, and eggplant offered a zippy spice level, while pumpkin curry ($16) with chicken and bell pepper in a red curry sauce was more mild.

Service is friendly, and dishes arrived at a pace that was neither too slow, nor too fast, although refilling water or iced tea glasses did not seem a priority.

While Thai food seems created to be perfectly paired with beer, Koh Samui and the Monkey has a full bar and reasonable wine list for more adventurous drinkers.

This is not a cheap date:  prices are more than a bit steep for Thai food.  On the other hand, you get what you pay for.  While Ozone Thai down the street may be less expensive, Koh Samui and the Monkey delivers so much more.  For the thrifty, the deal is a happy hour that can't be beat:  beers are only $2.50 and some food items are less than $5.

For expensive, but tasty Thai, Koh Samui and the Monkey can't be beat.
author: CJ G.

description:
Glad to keep on finding good food in SOMA.  Make no mistake, this is expensive Thai.  That said, the food is good and there is a wide variety of options to suit any tastes.  

Had the beef mango which was by far the best dish.  The beef was perfectly stir fried to have a nice carmalized crust and the mango added a nice refreshing tart bite.  Good balance in terms of both texture and flavor.

The duck curry was pretty good because they gave us lots of moist duck meat.  Most Thai places will give you lots of skin and bones with their curry dishes.  Not this place.  Good amounts of duck breast.  So you get something for the money.  

Cap it off with some spicy string beans and you have a great balanced meal.  

Very happy with the food and the service was promt and enthusiastic so made for a very pleasant experience.  

Looking forward to coming back.
author: Scott C.

description:
Koh Samui & The Monkey is fancier (and pricier) than your average Thai restaurant in the city - and I'm not sure if it's worth it.

I mean, the service is awesome and the food is decent, but for the price you pay, I would much rather eat at regular Thai Restaurants for half the price (even with 30% on Savored.com). Yes, the dishes here are more unique, but eh..

Chicken Mieng Kum
This Thai snack is full of flavor - chicken, lime, ginger, coconut, peanut, jalapeno, onion all wrapped up with a spinach leave, and topped with some peanut sauce. I would've never imagined to combine all these ingredients together, but they do complement each other very well. I would recommend this to try! 

Tom Yum Kung Soup
A little bit too sour for me, but it was okay. Bf really enjoyed this soup, as the prawns inside tasted really fresh! 

Larb Gai
Other than spiciness from the chilies, the chicken was otherwise bland. I felt that it was a little bit too spicy for my taste.. and just underwhelming. Would definitely skip this dish.

Kee Mao Pork Sausage
Limited selection of noodle dishes. This dish was okay, but was a little bit disappointed when it came out because it wasn't the flat rice noodles.. instead it was like squid ink spaghetti.. This dish, too, was a bit too spicy and lacked some flavor of a Kee Mao noodle dish. The pork sausages were okay, but not a fan.

Emerald Curry
Surprisingly packed a lot of prawns and scallops in that little coconut that was served in. Yes, a little bit too spicy, but it was much more manageable with the sticky rice. 

For two starters, one soup, one noodle, and one entree, it was about $70-80 total. If you were to eat at a regular Thai restaurant, it would've probably costed you $40-50. Luckily, we made reservations through Savored.com, so the meal came out to be $50ish. With gratuity, we walked out the door at about $70. In conclusion, pretty pricey for what it is. Not sure if I'll be returning.. definitely not for a long time.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I went here for a Farewell Party - First time customer... 
I loved loved loved the decor; and even though the space was a little tight, I still liked the setup. Very enjoyable place to eat with great service. The food and drinks taste great, but the portions could have been bigger... regardless, I would go back. I do like this place :) 

Location: 1 star 
Taste: 1 star 
Cleanliness: 1 star 
Service: 1 star 
Portions: No star... sorry, maybe it's what we ordered, but it was way too small for the price we were paying... 

...still - 4 stars! :)
author: Sonnia P.

description: its fine Thai food for the neighborhood.  nothing special.
author: Asher Y.

description:
I love this place. I've been there about 5 times in the last couple months. Everything I've had has been delicious. My recommendation for dinner - calamari app, beef mango with coconut rice and a sazerac. It has a nice date vibe - quiet, low lights, cool decor. You can go there casual but then I feel a little under dressed. 

I would have given this place 5 stars after my first visit, but the service isn't consistant. The meals are definitely better some nights than others, the service as well. And on those off nights I feel a little miffed about the price. Take that with a grain of salt though since I will definitely go back.
author: Raquel L.

description:
This a little pricey thai, and I left kinda hungry still but didn't wnat to spend another 40 bucks here.  The food is a little salty but it's pretty tasty nonetheless. Their bags of gold is pretty good and the bacon wrapped scallops!!! really good.

I had the sea bass but it was a little fishy like .. it was old..
author: Toby I.

description:
They're still great for gluten free and other dietary restrictions.
I'm tempted to deduct a star, because they're getting a little lower on quality.  Honestly, with the right competition close enough, I'd give them 3 stars.
I can't eat at the places nearby that do some things better and I often don't have time and the more money to travel to the places further away.

Monkey's are tricksters and appropriate for Koh.  They've downgraded from baby carrots to crinkle cut disks and that's after putting less stuff in the curry, if you know what I mean.  Costs more than the competition.  Though occasionally I end up with like ridiculous amounts of meat in the curry.  It's cheaper to eat in, than order to go (from the restaurant, like through the app).  Their to go counter is a nice lunch option for those who can eat gluten, but you can get cheaper elsewhere in that arena, too.  Apparently, not me, but they mistakenly told another party that something breaded was gluten free - doh Koh.  Ask to see the gluten free menu (it's a dinner menu), but you can trust it.

Belly up to the bar, the bar service is faster and a cut above the regular table host service, usually.  The bar is nice to look at.   I've been offered free thai iced tea (rarer) and water while I wait, sometimes. 
A lot of times they forget my request for chopsticks (though this happens less with the eat24 where it is in writing, I guess).  
They all greet with smiles and are as friendly to casuals as professionals.
author: Denae W.

description:
My complaint for this spot is the very small portions with prices there were a little higher than normal.  

I thought the food tasted pretty good, but with a party of 3 we ordered 5 dishes (2 apps and 3 entrees)  and didn't really leave that full.
author: Steven F.

description:
Very fancy, slightly overpriced Thai dinner. Good thing is everything is legitimately spicy and the curries are really flavored well.

Bags of Gold rice paper sacks of minced chicken and shrimp, tied with banana leaf, fried to a medium crisp $9
- not super impressive. The filling is overcooked to the point of being rubbery and you dont get to experience the texture of either meat

Chiang Mai Style Pork Sausage minced pork, egg, tumeric and ginger $10
- spicy! the pork is hearty and not overly minced. nice dish, but not incredibly memorable.

Fire Cracker seafood Sizzling hot plate of prawns, squid, scallop, crab claw and spicy peanut sauce $18
- a nice mixture of seafoods, cooked to a good tenderness. 
- spicy but not much else to the flavor (didnt taste the peanut), good but not very memorable

Basil Gai* white meat ground chicken wok fried with fresh basil, green beans and chili garlic sauce $12
- another solid dish, good spiciness to it, not very memorable

Madame Sea Bass* simmered in green curry with green beans, bell pepper, fresh basil and eggplant $16
- very nice dish, loved the green beans which are the thinner type that you normally only see in asian grocery stores that i grew up with and love
- eggplant soft, good flavor to the curry (though it was a little thin for my liking)

Aromatic Pumpkin Curry* chicken, bell pepper in red curry sauce served in pumpkin $16
- a really nice dish, great curry, and very impressive looking because it came out in a pumpkin!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Service: Came in for a late dinner on a Saturday night with 2 other friends. Was seated at a table, was given menus but no water. Nobody came to take our orders for at least 15 minutes. Water cups had lipstick stains. Was told multiple times that kitchen was closing and it was last call for food (we understood it the first time). They gave us a check, and kept coming by to check if we were ready to pay. 

Food: mediocre at best. Had much better food for 1/2 the cost.

Shame because it's so close to my house.
author: Daniel K.

description:
I tried...you can't fault me on that. I gave this place a try and then a try again...For lunch it gets pretty busy so be prepared to wait, depending on you arrive. The menu is mediocre at best and the food tends to be on the greasy/oily side.  I've had the pad thai and the Sea Bass dish. Both were not enough to knock my socks off but were good.  

The mixed drinks on the other hand always taste like medicine. When I read the ingredients on the menu I get so excited because they sound so delicious but then when i actually get them, oh my gawd! My throat burns with every sip.  Sorry guys but just by looking at your drinks when they arrive, I always get the feeling it won't be good. I've had their Lychee Politan, The Thai Kiss, Red Monkey & Shock the Monkey. None of which pleased me.

The service there is pretty good. They are friendly and attentive. I show no faults when it comes to the service.

The restaurant itself during the day is pretty kewl. They decor is worth staring at and admiring. I know me and my friend love the bird cages.

Overall if I go again, I will keep it simple.
author: Zara-Maria S.

description:
Ate here twice. Once was dine in and the other time was delivery. DON'T order delivery! I ordered around 6:15pm, and they said it would be delivered around 7:30. One hour and 15 minutes? It was a Friday night, so that was understandable. Close to 7:45, the food wasn't here, so I called them. The girl said the driver would be here in about 5 minutes. at 8pm, I called again. She said another 10 minutes. He finally came at 8:15 (45 minutes late). He called us and asked us to come down instead of him coming to our door. Horrible service!

The food is ok. The pumpkin curry is good. The pad thai is ok - nothing special. Dining in is fine, but do NOT order delivery!!
author: Jane M.

description:
Service was excellent, so was the presentation. 

I loved the frog, my favorite dish. 

The alligator was good too. 

Nothing was spicy at all, I guess you we should have asked for spicy since that's what we wanted. 

Tom Yum soup was not very good, that is my benchmark for a thai place so that was too bad. Again, maybe asking for it spicy would have helped. 

The bar is rad. Check it out.
author: Ryan L.

description: Horribly over priced for Thai food. I ordered a sea bass dish and it came with 4oz of fish (according to the waiter when I pointed it out). I can tolerate small portions but the service was horrible. When I pointed it, the waiter insulted me by saying 'it couldn't be that less if I ate all of it.' Really?! That's how they take feedback? I asked for the manager and he said the manager was "out." I left my phone number and never got a call back. Clearly they don't care about customer experience.
author: y D.

description:
2 of us went for dinner; ambiance was great. The start of the service was good. We got water within 2 minutes, and server came to take order within 5 minutes. After we ordered, we had our appetizer (Chicken Mieng Kum) within 8-10 minutes; 5 pieces of spinach leaves with little to no chicken, was ridiculously pricey. After that we waited 50 minutes to get our entree; we saw other tables where people came and sat after us get their entree and finish their food, before we got ours. Whn we finally got our food, Entree's portion size was ridiculously small for Basil eggplant and , specially when charging for regular steamed rice $2.50. None the less when the meal finished, the server didn't even bother to ask if we wanted dessert. 
My money will be better spent somewhere else.
author: N Z.

description: Food was good but the waiter's continuous up-sell attempts and serving my entree a good five minutes before that of my guests were served theirs took a bite out of his tip.  Four stars if not for that.
author: John K.

description:
I don't know why, but I'm always pleasantly surprised whenever I visit a nice restaurant in SOMA. Maybe it's cause I work on 5th...

Anyways, Koh Mui was a great place to celebrate my last day of work! The atmosphere is really pleasant and classy; I was surprised at how reasonable the prices were, given the atmosphere!

I ordered the Jakajuta Pad See Ew beef, which was a delicious, savory dish that was surprisingly filling. Great food, low prices- I kind of wish I could've discovered this place earlier so I could drop by for lunch more often!
author: Lucy C.

description:
Don't bother.
We tried it, several times in fact, because it is so close to our house, but it is just not that good.  
Bland and pricy.
Their fresh spring roll is decent as is their pumpkin curry and spicy green beans.
Everything else is "meh" at best.
Also service is really sub par.
The only upside is that they do have a full bar (one star for this!) because bland food does taste better when you are drunk :-)
author: Liz A.

description:
Service was sllllloooooow. You'll need 1.5 hours for lunch. 
Food was good. But a bit oily. Decent sized potion. The reason why it's only 2 stars is because of the slow service and that they ONLY ACCEPT 3 CREDIT CARDS PER TABLE.  Ridiculous.
author: Beau D.

description:
Excellent food, great ambience, and wonderful take out/dine in service. 

I live across the street from this place, so I go fairly often. Some of my favorite are the Sea Bass Madame and the Imperial Rolls. Everything I have had is excellent though. Top notch place.
author: Robert T.

description:
Had the soft shell crab dish for dinner. Very good in terms of retaining crispiness but plating could have been better (vegetables were hard to eat and crowded the plate). Sauce was too spicy for my liking, and I didn't touch the cucumber vinaigrette. Ordered steamed coconut rice which had a lovely flavour but should have been included with the entree. 

I'm a little on the fence with this one. The restaurant started to "break down" a little after us arriving. We were a party of 5, so I sat on the end of the table, which was unfortunately underneath a dripping pipe from the A/C. Nearby servers rotated the table, and in the end, moved our party to a different table altogether.  I was waiting for the women's washroom (single stall) when a male server came out and told me the soap dispenser was damaged. And I'm not sure he actually washed his hands properly in the process of trying to fix it, because he came out to say he couldn't. 

As for ambiance, it's a bit busy with the decorations, but it gets quite loud, to a level where it was hard to hear one of our dinner companions two seats away from me unless I really leaned forward and strained to listen in. 

I'm not sure that I would recommend it, but I wouldn't object if someone suggested going there for lunch (when rice is apparently included with meals). Other Yelpers seem to like the pumpkin curry, and now that I know you can substitute the protein for something other than shrimp, I wouldn't mind the opportunity to try that.
author: Deborah C.

description:
I haven't been here in over 7 years, but just came back recently with a Groupon.

Everything we ordered was delish!:
- Grapefruit salad: refreshing, lots of fruits, perfect dressing
- Pad Thai: tasty
- Green Tea Creme Brulee: nice flavor, creamy, nice crust
- Pumpkin Curry:  I'm not a curry person, the other people at my table had this and loved it

I would recommend this place to others if you're looking for something different than the usual Osha Thai in SF.
author: Rye G.

description:
For once, I told my boyfriend we can go out to grab Thai food for once. I wanted something semi-fancy. After much research, I came across Koh Samui & The Monkey as it appears they have great ambiance as well as a more classy atmosphere in comparison to other Thai restaurants.  
 
Once we entered, we were seated immediately. We were seated window side which was nice as it felt like we had a more intimate feel during our dinner. I ordered the spring rolls after looking over the reviews on Yelp. It came with 4 piece of spring rolls for $10. They tasted just as good as any other spring roll with the shrimp and pork. Its seems quite expensive for spring rolls as it is 3-4 times the price depending on what city you order spring rolls.  

For my main entree, I ordered the pumpkin curry as people raved about how it was the best pumpkin curry ever. You know what? They were right! It has the perfect amount of sweetness with perfectly cooked pumpkin. The curry is just amazing and not too heavy. I love that they put basil that gives the dish a nice little kick. 
 
Not bad, not bad.
author: Becky Q.

description:
Honestly...average thai food. Pretty good if you go to the restaurant, but if you get delivery, the food is super inconsistent...I've ordered chicken pad thai and received less than a 1/2 oz of chicken and about a pound of tofu...multiple times...

If this place were 30-40% cheaper, it'd make sense. Just get OSHA
author: Will R.

description:
3.5 stars is pretty accurate . could easily be a four if the dishes were upped and tweaked a bit . ..

+ :  ambiance (of bar area and inside the restaurant) . tasty food . pretty good wine beer sake selection . ..

scallop satay good
stuffed mushrooms ok
tom kha gai soup good, tasty
belly basil tasty good but some bits a little chewy overcooked
miracle duck pretty good
brown rice had hard rice bits
volcano fried rice good
Turley zinfandel wine bottle solid:

-- :  service (several times throughout the visit we were given the wrong dish, luckily one of our party kept track - nice recovery though) . dishes were good but nothing extraordinarily so . ..
author: Y I L I W.

description: This place is one of the best Thai places in the city. The only reason I'm not giving them 5 stars is bc of the price. When I moved to this area in 2005, most entrees were larger and less than $10/each.  I understand the neighborhood has changed, but $100 for 3 or 4 for dinner is kinda crazy.
author: Amy S.

description:
This place is really great on all counts.  The food and service are EXCELLENT, and the restaurant itself is pretty nice.  A plethora of delicious eats, and very attentive waitstaff await you.

I was surprised it wasn't busier, but I went on a Monday evening, so perhaps on another night it would be.  I ordered chicken satay, samosas (I didn't know there were Thai samosas!) and prosecco.  My friend had coconut curry with rice.  

The coconut curry came in a coconut with beautiful garnishing, and the samosas contained yams instead of potatoes, as well as fungi (the good kind) and some other interesting ingredients.  They were small, sweet, and crispy; so perfect I would go back just for those.

(ps - I recommend they reconsider the lost dog and cat signs in the restroom. I thought it was cute, but there are others that may see it differently)
author: Adrienne K.

description:
I sadly write this review after two lackluster experiences. The first one, I thought it was me in that the food was just not as good as before.  I went again last week and it sadly disappointed.  Thinking I was insane, I asked my friend, who agreed that she also felt they lost their luster.

The pumpkin chicken curry is still good. But the flavors and the spices in the other dishes are just average. Average is ok, but not when you charge high prices like at Koh Samui. My hubby eats spicy food and he asked for his dish to be spicy spicy spicy. And although the chef made it spicy, it was not spicy at all. Finally after asking for chilis in soy sauce, he realized, the chilis weren't spicy at all! We also ordered the string beans and they were just covered in sauce and was also in a extremely tiny portion.  The mango sticky rice is $9 and the mangoes were just bland! 

Again, if you charge steep prices, you have to make sure you deliver, and Koh Samui failed this past time.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Mmmmmm........................ 
I have either their Bento- Box lunch special which comes with mango salad, spring roll, BBQ pork, and your choice of entree ( I choose curry), or I get take out from their separate take out station which they have available on the side of the restaurants. 
My only qualms? They are a little pricey if you eat in the restaurant, and the wait for takeout can be up to an hour when their walk up takeout window is not open. Also, I wish some of the dishes were spicier.
author: Alyssa J.

description:
Incredibly disappointed with the service! My entree arrived with only 2 of the 4 main ingredients and the server refused to do anything to fix it.

Specifically, I ordered an item on the menu that said it included prawns, green peppers, and mushrooms on a bed of asparagus. It arrived as prawns with 2 asparagus (not really a "bed") and it was missing the green peppers and mushrooms.

I told our server Masha (pointed at the item in the menu) and she just smiled and said there was nothing she could do about it. What? I didn't want to cause a scene (it was just mushrooms & peppers after) but really? Once I ordered a beet salad that arrived beet-less but the server quickly gave me a side of beets and I was happy - easy fix! 

There were other issues too but the other main problem was Masha also double charged us for our wine! Fortunately, unlike my entree, she was able to fix her mistake after we flagged her down and pointed out.

Super bummed!
author: Bonnie P.

description:
Hrm... what to say... things change. I am disappointed with Monkey togo now. It is sad how you up the prices and lower the portions to make a buck. I went here yesterday and ordered the two item combo with my co-worker. It is sad that the reason why the line was taking so long was because the person packing our containers was measuring the items prior to putting it into the container. He would take a scoop of yellow curry only to shake off the excess meat or veggies. If you picture the 3 compartment containers (two small ones on top and the big one which contains rice). They only fill it up those small cups 2/3 or less.... 

The garlic beef was really tough to eat (not tender at all) and the chicken yellow curry... well let's just say where was the chicken? All-in-all the quality of this place is slowly going downhill.
author: Erica T.

description:
Been coming here for lunch and happy hour for a couple years. The happy hour Green Curry has become more tasteless over time so I think I'm done with this as a dinner alternative. 

I'll be back for the low cost happy hour beer, decent appetizers, and quick cheap lunch.
author: Chris D.

description: I come frequently for lunch, and sometimes for dinner as I work in the neighborhood. The service is painfully slow, even for a Thai place. Your best bet is to use the "monkey to-go" line. Otherwise be prepared to have a lengthy dinner/lunch.
author: Travis P.

description:
I wish I could give 0 stars. 

Pros: online ordering 

Cons: the food is terrible! 

I have yet to find really good Thai food in SF but this was just terrible. Ordered for takeout, spent $70 asked for medium spice on everything and this is what I got. 

Pad Thai with chicken: completely bland, noodles were cooked ok, not even a dusting of peanuts. 

Larb gai: greasy, tasteless, not a chili is sight, I dosed it with fresh lime juice and fish sauce to try to make it edible. 

Satay: pre-formed commercial meat, weird taste, peanut sauce was thinned out peanut butter. 

Green curry: greasy and watery at the same time, no flavor except sugar and certainly no spice or chili. 

Everything was super sweet and just terrible. I've spent heaps and heaps of time in Thailand.....lived in Asia for 20 years and I can forgive for not being 100% authentic but this was just slop. I make these food items often in my own kitchen and I would be happy to teach their cooking staff how to! 

Run, run fast.
author: Deena L.

description: Service was good, but the food was below average. It's good for a quick meal if you're really hungry and don't have any other choice.
author: H S.

description:
I was very pleased with my take-out order for Pumpkin curry, served with brown rice.
It arrived very quickly in less than a half hour, and was bathed in a silky red curry sauce with basil, bell pepper, and a bit of spice.

The portion of my meal was more than filling, and I remembered having more than enough for left overs the next day.

I'm not big into curries, but the harvest squash variety does better to befit the soupy mouth-feel experienced when once slurps on a curry.  Maybe because Pumpkin resonates my childhood experience as I grew up with seasonal squashes in our backyard, and laced into my mother's cooking throughout the fall.

mMm Mmm Delicious.
author: Ty T.

description:
This review is for the MONKEY portion not the main restauant.

Pad Se Ewee noodle dish tasted rubbery as did the string beans in the basil chicken dish and rice tasted stale. Server looked like I was from another planet when I had asked for more Pad Se Ewee (which btw, I paid 1.50 extra for) and the Cashier did not return the right change amount so not only did I get bad food I had to do the calculation work too!!

Simply put: Shitty food and service.
author: Doreen C.

description:
The atmosphere here just screams Soma -- the clean modern lines, large windows, and great lighting, but infused with a Thai theme. 

We ordered the pumpkin curry (a MUST), the whole snapper and the green beans. Wow... when it said 'Whole snapper' on the menu, I did NOT expect it to actually come out with a whole deep-fried snapper...yes, complete with head and all, manipulated such that it curled around the actual nuggets of snapper. We just treated the whole fish as decoration, but I ate the eye just for shock value. Wasn't bad! The snapper itself had a great flavor and had great texture. The green beans were plated very nicely, but I wasn't too impressed with them after the pumpkin curry and snapper.

For dessert, we got the creme brûlée. It had an amazing jasmine flavor but the top wasn't torched enough because my spoon went clear through when I went to crack it. We also got the Monkey's Mummy, which was a flaming banana with coconut flakes. It was rich, sweet, and worked well with the cold coconut ice cream. 

The service was pretty slow but the food was great. The presentation definitely upped my star rating. I'm glad to add an upscale Thai place to my repertoire.
author: Penny Y.

description: My friends and I love going here.  Place is a little small but the food is delicious.  The Pumpkin Curry is to die for.  Parking has never been a problem.  I'm sorry to hear their other restaurant on Valencia closed.  Glad that this location is still open.
author: T. H.

description:
We sat for dinner. Unfortunately, you cannot order happy hour drinks at the dinner tables, which kinda sucks. Not sure why you should be penalized since we're spending more for dinner...

We ordered:
Green Salmon (noodle) - TERRIBLE - salmon super dry, noodles tasted and looked like packaged ramen noodles.
Crispy Pork Hocks - DELICIOUS - omg fried pork skin, NOMNOMNOM
Beef Mango - pretty good - safe choice
Spicy Wild Boar - also pretty good - safe choice
Coconut Rice - meh, not as coconutty as I would have liked.

The amount of food per plate is ok. Definitely on the pricier side.
Generally, the atmosphere was nice. It got crowded quickly on a Monday evening.
I may come again, but the price is definitely a hurdle.
author: YaYa S.

description: Great thai food. Period. Service rocks, too.
author: Sherrick M.

description:
It was dark. The restaurant was glammed out, the chair was too heavy for me to pull out and they were so big I almost tripped over the legs. It is quite pricey and I wasn't too hungry so someone ordered fried calamari (which wasnt bad). Me and a housemate decided to share a Kah Tao with chicken. It was flat noodles mixed with peanut sauce and raw veggies. Our dish was the last to come (which took nearly 25+ minutes). And I wasn't too big of a fan over it. People that sat next to us got their Pad Thai's first and their portions were so big. Two people shared it and they were both full. It was good. I wish I got that instead. 
Stars down because of long service and also too pricey for its portion sizes. And when the bill came, it was unbelievably expensive for just 7 people. They even charged us gratuity for a person that we bought a dish to-go for. errrr, no thanks.
author: Linda K.

description:
I met up 7 of my friends here for happy hour before the Giants game. Small venue -- we had one small table near the bar that squeezed four people and the rest of us sat at the bar. A little crowded but I guess where ISN'T crowded near the park during happy hour?

I had their tofu with peanut sauce and pad see ew. For around $5, this food was delicious! The tofu appetizer came with about 8 pieces and the Pad See Ew was just the right amount for a good meal to hold me down for the game.

I give them 4 stars for the quality of the food and the cheap prices. The bartender was pretty social and very welcoming, but the service was a little slow that I ended up taking the food togo so I would make it in time for the first pitch.
author: Marissa C.

description:
Do you LOVE coconut milk soup? How about spicy mango beef? Do you enjoy having something to read and contemplate while in the restroom? If so, then KS&M is the place for you.

In dire need of something quick and easy, we found ourselves here for dinner last weekend. The items on the menu seemed a little pricey for what they were--$6 for a bowl of soup? I'm used to ordering an item of soup from other Thai restaurants which is sufficient for the whole table, not just one person.

Also, the mango beef was spicy even though it wasn't advertised as so. The beef tasted really...beefy...kinda in a bad way. Meh. I did like that they offered brown rice as an alternative though. 

2 soups, rice, mango beef, 1 thai tea =$40.
author: Misha F.

description: Good thai food. They have a pretty unique appetizer called Bags of Gold which is a fried wonton thing filled with meat that truly resembles a tiny bag of gold.
author: Thomas C.

description:
We were at this place today. We had to wait 25 mins just for the waiter to show up. The restaurant was not packed .. but busy. Either ways .. 25 mins at lunch time, during a working day? 
Worse .. one plate at our table . had left over food on it (hardened, meaning old food). When we told the waiter about this .. he just shrugged and asked" Do you want to order". No apology .. he didn't really care. We walked out.

Horrible service. Poor attitude. Last time I'm going here.
author: Vivek C.

description: I was sent to Samui & The Monkey tonight for a blind date.  When walking into the establishment, I was greeted very kindly by a nice young lady.  I advised her I was only visiting to meet a person at the bar for a drink.  I sat down at the bar, and was then greeted by the most sweet young man.  It turned out, I was stood up but spent the most lovely next 30 minutes talking off and on with the young man tending bar.  I actually left feeling happier than when I arrived...even having been stood up.  I'd wholeheartedly suggest going to the Samui & The Monkey.
author: Tess C.

description:
The food was pretty good here. I ordered the pumpkin curry and it was really good! 

Unfortunately, I was craving meat at the time and after trying my friend's lamb I started craving for it for the rest of the dinner.

Tip to all: If you are craving meat, order meat. Don't always go with what other yelpers recommend.
author: Song Z.

description:
I came here with a big group of friends to celebrate one of my close friend's 19th birthday. The place is dark, but it has a romantic feel to it. It's definitely a classy restaurant. Upon arrival, the waitress greeted us with a friendly smile, but I felt like it was kind of fake. Seeing a crowd of "kids" probably annoyed the hell out of her.

The restaurant didn't have tables that could accommodate the number of people we had, so we inevitably had to separate into two different tables. After we placed our orders, the waiting game began. I would say it was a good 30-40 minute wait for the food. When the food finally came out, it was lukewarm. Actually, some of my friends complained that their food was good. What a turn-off.

The gratuity seemed extra steep and as usual, we were short of money. After looking through the bill a couple times, we realized that they charged two plates of calamari when we specifically asked for just one. It sucks cause one of the calamari dish was $12 and it only consisted six pieces of calamari drowned in sweet chili sauce.

Long story short: the food was OK, the wait was bogus, the price was decent, and the service was mediocre.
author: Annie S.

description:
Summary: outstanding food, great service and really nice atmosphere.

The evening started at the bar drinking mojitos with my friend as we waited for our table to be ready. As we were discussing our views on medicinal marijuana, I look over her shoulder and I see fish swimming in a birdcage and started to question if I had smoked something earlier. haha She saw it too, so either we were both high or it was just a really cool looking fish tank: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/9Q8_UWUAf32TbnldHWonRw?select=3ym_Z6bEABr2TUrOV3yIHQ  -- you see it too, right?

Shortly after we were seated and ordered more mojitos, calamari and main courses.

The fried calamari was great. It wasn't your usual small calamari "oh's" that you get everywhere else. These were like fried calamari steaks with a sweet and sour sauce that you eat with a knife and fork. So good!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/9Q8_UWUAf32TbnldHWonRw?select=84ws1Yi83RVL2kjKv5fLsA

After reading the yelp reviews, I had to try the pumpkin curry and the people on here don't lie, it was amazing! Easily one of the best curries I've had and went really well with coconut rice.

Lastly, the service was great and the prices are reasonable.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Good food and nice ambiance for a sit-down dinner, but not so great prices. 

I don't understand places where rice doesn't come with curry dishes because who orders curry and doesn't eat it with rice?? (each bowl of jasmine rice is $2.50). I also feel like you are paying more for the fusion and ambiance than the food, much like dining at Straits or Sino in Santana Row, because I've had comparable Thai food for much cheaper at smaller restaurants. 


That aside, I do have to admit the food was tasty. The pumpkin curry with chicken and bell peppers is a must-try. The flavor of the duck curry was also good, but it's like a treasure hunt to find a piece of duck meat or duck fat in the dish. The basil chicken and pad thai were both good, and the pad thai actually came with a lot of shrimp. 

All in all, we left full and satisfied, though poorer than before.
author: Yang Q.

description: Went here for happy hour before a Giants game.  They have the most amazing thai ice tea cocktail.  Hot Damn!!  The appetizers we got were good too.
author: Michelle R.

description:
This is a 3.5 star review.. 
I tried the tom yum vegetarian soup - Soup was a okay, but had a lot of veggies in it, which I loved.
I ordered some chicken dish with brown rice, which was ok.

Negatives:
The service was really really slow
I found this place overpriced.
author: Parminder Nayyar C.

description: After going to this place for a second time, I must say this place cooks good Thai food! I tried their Asian Beef and I almost didn't wanna share that with anybody! Also loved their wine selection. Definitely will go back there soon!
author: V S.

description:
I finally got to dine in at Koh Samui & The Monkey this past week for dinner.  I loved the ambiance and this thai restaurant as an alternative to Osha Thai.  The presentation of some of the dishes were great.  Here were my picks of the night:

Food:
Imperial Rolls: nicely presented and great tasting
Fried Chicken with Fried Rice: Hearty portion and a good dish to share
Pad Thai with Tofu: This dish was lacking
Pumpkin Curry with Brown Rice: Probably my favorite dish of the night
Fresh Coconut Juice: really good!

Will definitely be back here when I'm craving Thai food in the SOMA.
author: Carli F.

description: Had this food catered and it was great if you only eat rice and noodles because the beef in the beef curry is overcooked and chewy, low quality, blechhh!  I passed on it after tasting it, even at free it's not worth it
author: Jack T.

description:
A pretty restaurant with white tablecloths and lots of art - and quite a menu selection.

Not crowded for a Tuesday dinner, though the bar was pretty full due to happy hour.  We called ahead for a table ( they block out the core dinner hours on opentable for some reason, even when they are barely full ) and were seated quite quickly.

They offer a full list of some creatively named cocktails, though they might not be to everyone's liking, and a good variety of beer on draft including a self-branded pilsner, which was decent.  The drinks come with cool translucent plastic monkeys hanging off them - a nice touch.

They have a prix fixe option ( $40/person with a $10 wine pairing ) that involves a lot of small sub-dishes containing some of their more popular offerings.  We were not initially offered this menu and had to ask ... and when we did the waitress suggested that we simply share one $40 set between us.  She suggested that it was plenty of food for two people, and I definitely agree.

We also got their pumpkin curry ( served in a regular bowl - some times they apparently will serve it in a hollowed out pumpkin ) and a seafood salad called Yam Talay.

Flavors were generally very approachable, though somewhat heavier than we are used to from Thai food.  Nothing was particularly spicy, including dishes that are traditionally *very* spicy.  The papaya salad was the least spicy I've ever had.  What was lost in spice was made up for in strong salt and savory flavors - plenty of fish sauce to go around.

The pumpkin curry was excellent, though my companion complained that the pumpkin chunks therein were a little large for her taste.

Service was generally good and very friendly.

In the end, there are some good things going on here, and it's a bit more upscale than most Thai places I've been to.  The dishes are competent and the flavors strong, but there is a little more emphasis placed on the extremely savory without accompanying emphasis on spice.  In my opinion, Thai food needs both to really shine.
author: Albert H.

description:
I work right around the corner and I can't help but eat here almost every day for lunch! I love Monkey Thai, the food is delicious and the people that work in the restaurant are great. 

The restaurant gets SUPER crowded at lunch time. Ive only gone a few times where Ive sat in the restaurant, and despite the crowd I have never had to wait long to be seated. I mostly go for the Monkey Thai to go. It's only open from 12-2pm but its a really convenient way to get a delicious meal for lunch in the area. It's pretty much chinese to go style where all the food is already prepared. You can choose your rice then 1 or 2 items. I always get the spicy basil chicken and sweet basil chicken. It's technically cash only, but you can pay with your credit card inside the restaurant. Little extra work, but it's no big deal. 

Also, great happy hour for after work! Sometimes it gets a little crowded since the place isn't that big, but you can't beat the house drinks at only $5 and dinners around $7-10 during happy hour!
author: Sarah I.

description: Great atmosphere and good food. Just a little disappointed when the pumpkin curry didn't come in the pumpkin bowl but tasted delicious.
author: Wendy W.

description:
My friend and I decided to dine here one night, we sat down, ordered several plates to share, and I excuse myself to wash my hands. When I returned to the table, I insisted that my friend to go to the bathroom. When he returned to the table, he said, let's get the f**k out of here! I agreed.
