I will never eat at this restaurant or any restaurant that features polaroids of missing  CATS & DOGS on their bathroom walls, especially after hearing the recent news of restaurants in Shanghai passing off rats in place of lamb. How the hell can a respectable Asian restaurant do this? It's not funny, it will never be funny, and you lost my business because of it.

P.S. You ought to FIRE the person who thought of this idea; it's not clever, it's stupid. It's perpetuating an Asian stereotype.
author: Rex G.

description:
This is our mostly frequented thai place and I've got to say, after several times here it is sad to say that the only really great dish here is the chicken pumpkin curry. Everything else lacks authentic thai flavors, are too greasy, or just missing something...

Most of the dishes I've tried other than the chicken pumpkin curry taste too fusion for my liking. (Although I do enjoy the spring rolls that come with the lunch special) The stir fried noodles like pad see ew and pad khee mao are lacking and really greasy/oily. The last time I ordered pad khee mao with extra veggies and beef, I found myself with shiny lips (from grease) and an unsatisfied hunger for spice and thai flavors.

Overall, a pretty nice place for lunch. It gets fairly crowded, but getting seated is not a problem. Prices are also decent. Again, get the curry! One of the few things that won't leave you craving for real thai cuisine.
author: Stine H.

description:
A-OK.
Got a Groupon so I went here with 3 friends to use it.
-There were a pretty good number of customers for a Wednesday night.
-Service was good, nothing to complain or rave about.
-Food was very good. Rather more expensive than other Thai restaurants I've ate at.
-Nice decor and ambiance.
-I ordered the Chicken Pumpkin Curry because a lot of people recommended it. It came out nice and hot in a whole green pumpkin as expected. I couldn't finish it so decided to get it to go. I SHOULD HAVE asked to get the whole pumpkin too! I thought they would give it to me, but then I saw 2 small boxes, I thought maybe they cut it up and put it in the box. But the next day I opened and found out it was left over rice in 1 box and leftover curry in the other box/container. I was disappointed. 

2 appetizers, 4 entrees, 1 thai iced tea, water... came out a little under $90 before tip.
author: Karen P.

description:
Made Valentine's Day reservations at Koh Samui & The Monkey last night and had a fabulous time with my sweetie!  Koh Samui also gets extra props for managing to fit us in for a VD dinner reservation after I brain-farted and had to call the morning of.

Brannon and 3rd Street is definitely a destination for us (we don't find ourselves strolling around this part of the City too often), but it was well worth the extra effort to get here ($10 cab from Financial District).  Unassuming and industrial outside belies the warm, chic, yet comfortable interior.

Check-in on a busy Valentine's Day evening was quick and painless.  We got a cozy window seat.  The interior is beautifully lit, nice music, oil lamps on tables, and seating not so close as to be eavesdropping on your neighbor's conversations.

The menu is extensive and is what I'd call Thai fusion.  What it's fused with is hard to tell, but I like the creativity!  We ordered the Fresh Shrimp Spring Rolls and Sirloin Salad as starters.  Six portions of Spring Roll arrived on a porcelain boat with a spicy peanut fish sauce dip.  Cold, crisp, and delicious!  The salad was a good 2-person portion.  Slices of perfectly grilled and seasoned steak atop chunks of iceberg lettuce, red onion, cilantro, with a fish sauce and vinegar dressing.  I could eat a bowl of this.

We ordered a $28 bottle of La Follette Pinot Noir which paired beautifully.  Light enough to not mask flavors, yet the crisp Pinot fruit came right through.

We decided to sample a few entrees so ordered the Belly Basil (crisp-skin pork belly slices stir fried with basil and vegetables), Eggplant Tofu (sauteed with bell pepper, fresh basil in chili and garlic sauce), and the Grilled Lamb To Die For (marinated lamb chops served with grilled asparagus and carrots in a white wine & garlic sauce with a side of sticky rice).  We also ordered a side of steamed brown rice and side of coconut rice.

Hands down, the lamb chops ruled!  Perfect grilling, slightly gamey taste that worked well against the sweet sticky rice.  The Belly Basil was addictive, spicy, basil-licious, and the portion of pork belly was generous.  Crisp pork skin added a great play of texture against the fatty deliciousness of the belly.  The Eggplant Tofu was good, but perhaps the weakest of the entrees we sampled.  The eggplant was well-cooked (still firm and well-flavored), but it was already only warm by the time it arrived to the table rather than piping hot.

While the steamed brown rice was your average steamed rice, the coconut rice was OFF THE HOOK!  I'd go back just for a side of rice!

Needless to say, we had no room for desserts (and they had already run out of fresh Mango and Sticky Rice).

All in (apps, dinner, bottle of wine) we racked up a $120 tab (not including tip).  And we tipped well, as the service all around was impeccable.

This may have been a Valentine's Day destination dinner, but I think Koh Samui & The Monkey is now on our favorite list.  We'll be back often!
author: Rick M.

description:
I was excited to try this place out as it is close to home and who wouldn't want to go somewhere that has the word "monkey" in the title.

Sadly, I was disappointed.  Food was so-so (I'm not a huge Osha fan, and I think their food is leaps and bounds better) and is pretty over priced (we had a Groupon and still felt like we over paid).  Not to be all--I've been to Thailand before and had authentic Thai food and this doesn't measure up to other fare you can get in SF--on you, but I have, and it doesn't.

The happy hour list seemed worth checking out but I doubt we will try it.  There are just too many other good places in town that we'd like to go back to first.
author: Lynn G.

description: This place is amazing! Great spot in SOMA for some drinks and appetizers, stopped in with some co-workers and grabbed some imperial rolls to start off that just tickled our tastebuds. Followed up by some pad see ew that is the best I've had in the city. Throw it all together with their two beers- the "monkey" variety on tap and their bar manager (yes, her name really is Beer), and the monkey is a can't miss.
author: Denny S.

description:
I like this place - pretty good Thai food and usually has seating available, especially via OpenTable. I found dinner-time reservations on New Year's Eve a few hours before, and while some may think that's a sign of a lame place, this place was actually quite busy. It just has more seating than many SF restaurants. So... that's a plus. It's also close to Caltrain, and to many SOMA locations if you have post-dinner plans.
I've had the veggie fresh spring rolls, tofu pad thai, basil eggplant and a few other items. Love their peanut sauce!
1 star removed for service - as other reviews have pointed out, it is decidedly slower and less attentive even when they are not too busy. I don't want a waiter hovering over me, but it would be nice if they would glance at you when they pass by or come by ask if you need anything - I had to wave and signal for a few minutes before any passing waiter responded!
author: What's in a nam e.

description:
I've been coming to the Monkey since I moved here from Michigan 5 years ago and it's always been my go to spot for happy hour drinks, to watch the Giants games, awesome Thai food, and great wine selection.  

The  bartender always pours great drinks and the happy hour menu is always reasonably priced but tonight was extra special as they have great new menu items and specialty cocktails.

Thai food here is very authentic, I highly recommend!
author: sam s.

description:
I have eaten authentic Thai food, and this is the best I have ever had. The food is worth every penny! The cocktails are creative and delicious...thanks to Raffy...and the elegant dishes are created by Raffy's brother.
I had the honor of meeting the owner and her stunning little daughter before dinner. I immediately picked up that she is internationally travelled and educated and has passed all this on to her daughter and businesses.

Here are some dishes we had:
Salad: Larb Gai minced chicken tossed with lime juice, chili flakes, parched rice and mint. Served in a bell pepper with lettuce on the side
Main: Basil Gai white meat ground chicken wok fried with fresh basil, green beans and chili garlic sauce
Main: Grilled Lamb To Die For marinated lamb, mixed vegetables in white wine & garlic sauce, and sticky rice
Noodle: Sea Bass Mor Din steamed sea bass sauteed with glass noodle, shitake mushroom, broccoli and carrots
Noodle: Kee Mao Scallop pan seared scallops sauteed with basil, red bell peppers, tomatoes and fresh Thai chilies and served over squid ink noodles
Main: Beef Mango flank beef stir fried with fresh mango, bell pepper, carrot, ginger, black pepper and chili garlic sauce

We will definitely go there regularly...And as for the wine selection...wow! International and perfect as pairings to the food. Bravo!
author: Tia N.

description:
Service - said nothing when I killed a crawling bug on the wall right in front of her. In addition, a bunch of little minor things that I wasn't happy about, adding up to overall annoying service. Beautifully dressed.

Food - not as good as in the Tenderloin and much more expensive. Chicken larb - overcooked and dry. Would prefer never to eat here again but if I had to, I'd get the Yam talay and the flaming banana.
author: Marina N.

description: Pretty decent food and ambiance. A tad greasy, but most Thai food is. Would come back as this is one of the closest Thai place to where I live.
author: Mel L.

description:
4 stars for $2.50 Blue Moon pints (and other draft beers except for Chimay - $5) at the bar during their Happy Hour from 5PM-7PM 7 days a week.  One of the few places by the ballpark that doesn't take away their Happy Hour deals on game nights.  They got some nice spring rolls, corn cakes, and chicken satay for $5 on their happy hour menu too.

Place is pretty good for lunch too.  Love their yellow curry meals over here.
author: Chris T.

description:
Quick Review!

I went there for a dinner and order their Pad Thai with shrimp & chicken. It was a pricey dish but definitely worth the splurge. It was actually one of the best I had in the city! 

They also have those little monkeys figurines they'll attach to your drink. An original touch.
author: Cedric L.

description: The Drinks was great! The food was ok. The panang beef were big chunks of beef that were dry, had it not been for all the curry to moisten it with the dish would have been a fail.
author: Jose A.

description:
"Monkey" as my office calls it, has two things going for it: their to-go lunch bar and their happy hour.

The lunch bar is open from noon-2 and for $8-9 you can get a heaping box of rice, tofu pad thai, and spicy or sweet basil chicken. They have other selections too in smaller quantities, but these are the staples and they are *good* (although the "spicy" basil chicken can stand to be a lot hotter - I think they accounted for people unused to Thai food).

The happy hour is really good; you get a seat at a stylish modern bar, really cheap cocktails, beer and wine, and a chance to hit on the uppity British bartender if he spares a look your way. On a good day he can tell you some pretty entertaining stories.

For dinner or their full lunch menu, though, the food is wildly overpriced and woefully small-portioned. You'd be better off going up a block to Chili Lemon Ginger where the food is cheaper, more delicious and comes in bigger portions.
author: Meg G.

description:
The TASTE of the food at this place gets 4 stars,
The Look and Presentation of this place gets 4 stars.

the PRICES/ VALUE of this place gets two stars. 

This is why I decided to give the average of 3 stars to this popular Thai joint down in the SOMA area that is often frequented by the SF scene and heard crowd.

The bar and decor is very chic and a perfect fit for the pretty SOMA peeps, but that is not why the Prince of Taiwan goes out to eat. I have fourteen extra wives back in my royal court of Taiwan, so I don't need to go to places where the hunnies are dressed like they are going to a P diddy club. 

It's all about the food, service, and overall value. I don't mind paying up the butthole for Michelin star food. And  I love paying next to nothing for home cooking at mom n pops. What I don't love doing is paying top dollar for good food that i can get at other Thai places for much much less. 

Curry dishes for 16 bucks? What the hell? That's a dish at the Brunch menu of NOPA, and this place ain't NOPA.

16 bucks and up for seafood dishes?

12 plus for fried rice? my grandma would roll over in her grave!

12 bucks for a mango mojito? holy crap batman, you can feed a family of ten in Uganda or buy some false teeth for Uncle Jeebus in Arkansas for that much. 


we had a party of 4 and it was well over 100 bucks. I fed a family of 8 for less than that last week at another Thai place. Sure, that place didn't have cute Asian girls on double dates with tool-ish looking white guys, but the food was the same in taste and portions. 
The service is average, the food is nicely presented and does taste good, but the prices really are too high for what you get.
author: Jerry C.

description:
I think they nailed the Thai iced tea.  Sweet but not overly sweet.  Hard to do.

The food is amazing - don't have to talk about that.  Service is good.  Small place so crowded during the normal hours - go early or really late.  

Squid appetizer is a must try.  

The only ding would be the parking situation but then going late/early helps.  Or NOT during baseball season homegame days.
author: Paul A.

description:
I was not impressed. I came here upon a recommendation from the concierge at the Marriot. We were out celebrating my birthday, and hadn't really put any thought into where to go for dinner. Since this was in our price range, we gave it a go. 

The service was incredibly SLOW. Seriously? We got there about 9pm, and there was hardly anyone there. When the waiter asked if we needed a few minutes, I said yes, but he didn't come back for another 30 minutes. To top it off, he was virtually impossible to get a hold of!  It was frustrating, especially since I had plans for later, and we were running out of time. We never even got a water refill. When we finished eating, I asked for the check and I watched him do a million other things before actually bringing it. GRR. I swear we ended up leaving close to 11 pm. 

Overall.. they did give me a complimentary cake and mango icecream for my birthday. The mango ice cream tasted light and fresh, definitely a nice dessert, but I wasn't a fan of how heavy the chocolate cake was. 
The mango mojito was amazing. The food was O.K. It was nicely presented...  however, I wasn't a fan of the crispy tofu (I don't know how you can miss with that).

I don't think I'd come back -- solely because I'd like to get my food in a timely manner.
author: Kary M.

description:
Thai food--whether it's fancy or not--is all the same to me. I don't really believe in overpaying for thai food but it's a nice place to go with friends. 

Ordered a bunch of food for four:

MIENG KUM -- literally bits and pieces that you put on leaves. Not so good
MIRACLE DUCK - Not bad
Crushed Sesame Scallops - Good but nothing special
Volcano Fried Rice - Really flavorful and had a lot of stuff in it to make it delicious
Fire Cracker- delicious, spicy for my taste

Okay, so all my descriptions were the same because that's generally how the food tasted to me. It's good but it's not great, it's filling but it's not memorable. 

Friendly and attentive service though.
author: Diana Y.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night and got seated right away,but no one came to our table. We sat there for 15 minutes and no one acknowledged us. They were not full either. We got up and before we left , mentioned to the girl at the counter how we were ignored and she just smiled at us! Have been there twice before and the service was fine and the food was decent. 
I wrote a message to the business to let them know what happened and I never heard back from them, I wasn't looking for anything free...just thought they should know the poor management that evening. Now I understand what happened:just poor management overall. Not even the courtesy to write me back. Will definitely NEVER go back here again!
author: Brian M.

description: Okay Thai food. Their curries are generally quite good. Everything else on the menu is pretty bad though - stay awaaaaay from the BBQ chicken in particular. The pad Thai is bland. The staff is super sweet though!!
author: Rachel D.

description: We ordered pad Thai, chicken satay and spring rolls to be delivered.  Very disappointing, the pad Thai did not taste good and the spring rolls were mushy and not fresh.  The chicken satay was the only thing edible that we ordered.
author: Erin D.

description:
Seriously? Two hours is not the fifteen minutes you mentionned.

Poor delivery service. Have to call two time to get my order shipped.
author: Maxime D.

description: Ordered takeout (Crispy Chicken over Fried Rice) and I wish I were writing a more positive review but unfortunately that's not the case. Upon opening my very heavy takeout container, I had a very thinly pounded chicken breast served over what appeared to be nearly 3lbs of fried rice! The chicken to rice ratio just did not make sense. Even after finishing the chicken, I had about 4 cups of fried rice left and more than half of the dipping sauce left!  For $12.50, I could've used more chicken. I will never order this overpriced meal again.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Really sub-average Thai food. Noodles were totally bland, curries were ok but the beef in the green curry was super dry and flavorless, appetizers (satay and golden pockets) were just so boring. Also, really boring menu - nothing special or interesting. Only highlight was the pumpkin curry, but the flavors were wasted on the prawns. Probably better if it had been vegetarian.

Skip this, order elsewhere.
author: Smellis S.

description:
My close friends would tell you that I'm  so laid-back I'm practically horizontal-- but even I had a "dude, seriously?" moment here...
One bite into the over-hyped/overrated Chicken Mieng Kum appetizer (spinach leaves topped with a sprinkle of peanuts) before our food + laps were doused with the lovely orange-tinted Thai ice tea knocked over by our waiter...
now I'm not one to cry over spilled milk, but you would think you'd get hooked up with a refill, or at least not get charged for your last drink as it continues to seep through your pants?! Ah monkey, you've failed me.
author: Mahsa K.

description: Good, cheap, and fast. Usually, it's pick any two; but, at least for their lunch specials, you get all three. From their lunch buffet, I had cashew chicken, beef curry, and jasmine rice for $7.95. It was all very good and the beef was especially tender and succulent.
author: Paul L.

description: You could find better Thai food in the area than this. They took forever for the food to come out and the service is so disorganized half the food was cold by time everyone else's food was out.
author: Tony F.

description: Enjoyed a great business lunch here. Fresh food with excellent service. Busy at lunch, so call ahead if possible. Curries were exceptional and the spices were right where I requested...spicy but not alarming. Highly recommend for authentic Thai cuisine.
author: Todd S.

description:
Since it was our last day at work, my boss and my 2 other co-workers all went out for lunch and this was the chosen spot.

We've been here numerous times for lunch and really, you have to call for a reservation - it helps for this place gets jammed pack. 

We got seated right away (service there is really fast so that they can turn the table around fast) and I ordered praram chicken with thai iced tea. I forgot what my boss and co-workers ordered but we usually all devour our food. 

My food always comes tasty but this time, the rice was a little hard. I think it was lacking water but other than that little snag, it was all good. 

My boss treated us and that even made it better! I have to take the boy here soon!
author: Cath M.

description:
3.5.

The decor is really tacky and prices are a bit overdone.  

But the food is vegefied good.  That pumpkin curry was delish and the sticky rice with peanut sauce...wwwoooohhh, still calling my name!!!  

Maybe it'd be fun place to hang with friends for happy hour, so I'll surely be back!
author: Angella S.

description:
This place is phenomenal and I am pleased to have KS&TM as my neighborhood Thai go to. The restaurant itself offers lovely Thai decor, a well appointed bar and great staff. The menu covers the usual Thai fare with a few unique offerings as well. Though I've been here a few times and have had the opportunity to sample my usual faves, I can honestly say their spicy tofu & vegetables kick ass! Seriously, pour that sauce into a glass, give me a straw and call it a day! Slurp! Deeelicious!! 

I've been here for both lunch and dinner, the prices are reasonable and the service is always pleasant. They also offer great happy hour specials, accommodating menus and several rice options. This is one of my favorite Thai restaurants which is truly a statement as Thai is one of my favorite fares that I indulge in quite a bit.
author: alexa c.

description:
Never a let down, have been here n number of times mostly with office colleagues for happy hour :) 

Their happy hour prices are pretty decent, and their food tastes so good - specially the 'yellow curry with chicken', that has been one of my favorites! I am always down to grab a drink and some dinner during happy hour.
author: Animesh D.

description:
When you're the 408th review, it's kind of sad knowing no one else is ever going to read it.. Dammit! Why can't I review restaurants in Ketchikan, Alaska? Ketchikanans (I can only assume that's what they're called and hope that it would be pronounced Ketchi-cannons) don't have this problem. 

We visited Koh Samui on our honeymoon so I admit the main reason I picked this place for dinner was the name. I hoped there would be pictures of the island all over the restaurant. Well, that wasn't so much the case. However, we also LOVE elephants, and we were happy to be served on a plate lined with raised elephants. They also sell uber-cute elephant teacups for $8.

Good thing #1
There was parking right in front

Bad thing #1 
It was super noisy. They didn't attempt to soundproof the ceiling. At all. It was so bad that we wanted to linger since we were going to a show, but decided to get to the show early instead.

Okay thing #1
Our server brought a bottle of sake and claimed that for tonight only that bottle - usually priced at $99 - would be half off. He persuaded us to try a cup, and even though we had no intention of ordering the sake we tried it without feeling like he was giving us the hard sell. The sake was really, really good. And we still didn't order it.

Good thing #2
-The food was universally very good (at least to me). We started with the Chicken Satay Mieng Kum ($8), which consists of a leaf (spinach?) topped with chopped peanut, roasted coconut, fresh lime, ginger, onion and chili. Each one was a really strongly flavored bite (especially with the lime - I advise you to remove the rind). I really liked it but the husband didn't. Six bites for $8 didn't seem like the best value.

-Entree #1 was the Pumpkin Chicken Curry ($16 - eek!), which is served in a whole pumpkin. This was definitely the best Thai pumpkin dish I've had. It was a little sweet, but definitely still savory with red curry flavors.

-Entree #2 was the Spicy Tofu with zucchini, onion, carrot and fresh basil in chili garlic sauce. The menu lists this item as $9, but it was itemized on our bill (with the name of the dish printed from the computer) as $8. It was just the right amount of spicy, and tasted great. The Pumpkin Curry outshined it, but at any other restaurant this dish would have been the big winner. 

-Rice was $2.50 to $3 per person (I don't think I've ever had rice be more than $2 per person). The Coconut Rice was yummy and tasted so good on its own we hated to put food on top of it.

Bad thing #2
The cost. I've had upscale Thai food before but this was tied with the most expensive I've been to. (The other restaurant is Sirayah in San Carlos but at least they have an excuse. They use organic ingredients and free-range chicken). Lunch sounds like the good deal here. You can get the Pumpkin Curry Chicken with rice for $8. (And since it includes rice so you don't lose $3 either).

Good thing #3
The bathrooms are decorated with lost dog and cat notices from around the world. It's odd yet compelling.
author: Kathleen M.

description: Stayed in town for a few nights and had delivery service from here a couple of times. Both times v prompt and the food was definitely above average. The tom yum soup with chicken and coconut was delicious as were the rice paper rolls. I found the pad thai a bit bland but you could order it spicier. There are much more interesting options in any case! The pumpkin curry and brown rice come recommended but remember to ask for more spice if you like it that way.
author: Alice H.

description: Pumpkin curry year-round, nuff said!
author: Stephanie F.

description: The interior design is great with nice ambiance and decor.  Service was great.  But my dish was inedible.  I came here with a friend and we got the pork ribs for appetizer which was delicious.  For main dishes I got the pork belly and my friend got the fish.  His dish was great, but my pork belly was so hard it was inedible.  I expect pork belly to have a layer of crisp and then moist pork belly with soft fat, but this was literally slices of what looked, tasted and felt like jerky.  Not what I was expecting at all, especially at that price point.  My friend and I could only eat a few pieces and left the rest because it was literally inedible.  I felt like I was gnawing on the sole of a leather shoe.  I might come back, just would order something else, which is a shame because I love pork belly and it was terrible to see such a waste.
author: X X.

description:
Must repeat!! 

Excellent pad Thai, spring rolls, yellow beef curry, and chicken satay.  The service was good, waiters friendly, and obviously a popular lunch hangout.
author: Thomas K.

description:
Been here for lunch and dinner, and recently checked out their lunch take-out counter.

Service for dine-in is average and sometimes it's slow, especially during the busy lunch hours. It gets loud in there, and I think this place is much suited for group dining, rather than having lunch solo or with another person. However, dinner seemed more calm and less busy. 

I've found ordering from the take-out counter more efficient and wallet-friendly. $6.95 for 1-item with steamed rice ($7.95 for 2-item) is a deal for lunch especially in this area. If you come around or before Noon, they'll still have a lot of items to choose from. Overall, food is decent and it satisfies my Thai cravings whenever they kick in.

Great place for Happy Hour, especially before Giants games: $2.50 drafts, $3.00 well cocktails.

-1 star for the goldfish floating belly up in the fishbowl. D:
author: Zell C.

description:
K oh Samui might have good food -- too bad I didn't get to try it
O nly could wait so long without our order being taken
H ung around for 20 minutes before we gave up and bounced

S ervice on the floor needs a lot of work
A lthough we came on a slow night, we were ignored after we sat
M uch time passed and still no water or server to take our order 
U nexcusable
I f you're a higher-priced joint, you need to be more attentive
author: Anthony N.

description:
You've been there before: you work in San Francisco, city of culinary delights, but have grown tired of even the yummy eating establishments around work. And when work is in SOMA, well, let's just say this whole process happens a bit faster.

Now, imagine that you didn't even really like the place to begin with, its food is incredibly mediocre, and you have received consistently incompetent--not bad, but incompetent--service there...but every goddamn person in your office wants to go there for some special occasion. Farewell lunch for someone in the office? We're having it at Koh Samui and the Monkey! Someone's birthday? Let's celebrate at Koh Samui and the Monkey! Long overdue lunch with a coworker who's usually too busy for a lunch out? Well, I'll be damned--Koh Samui and the Monkey for the friggin' win!

Why, may you ask, does Koh Samui and the Monkey anger the blood so? Picture a large, somewhat uncomfortable gathering with your coworkers (surprise, surprise). Waitress is taking orders, and when she gets to me, I ask her which she personally prefers: some rice and meat dish (I forget which) or their new menu item with cellophane noodles. This was a brief conversation, but a *conversation* nonetheless, over which she communicates that "they're both good" and "if I want rice, I should get the rice place, but if I want noodles, I should get the noodles plate." No shit. 

I ended up ordering the cellophane noodles dish, while clearly pointing to it on the menu. But though she saw what I was pointing at, I had the sinking feeling that she confused it with some curry dish that started with the same couple words--which, might I add, did. not. contain. cellophane. noodles.

Lo and behold, the food starts arriving and someone from the kitchen sloppily delivers a curry plate. I dislike curry. But, that's beside the point, because that is not what I ordered. They send it back, but instead of making my order a priority to remedy their bad, I know it went to the bottom of the pile--because my order arrives when our party of 11 is just finishing up. 

To add insult to injury, what arrives is, again, not what I ordered. What happened to the cellophane noodles in a light sauce with yummy salmon and shiitake mushrooms (all inherently delicious ingredients), as was promised by one of the most expensive items on the menu? Instead, the noodles were just swimming in a heavy but somehow texture-less sauce, there's very little salmon, and instead of shiitake mushrooms, there's all that Chinese mixed veggie shit, like once-frozen baby corn cobs, peas, water chestnuts, and broccoli--which are fine in other contexts, but obviously not apart of this dish's original conception, and, again, not what I was promised.

I gesture to wrap it to-go, so everyone doesn't have to wait, but they insist I eat. Noodles are awkward to eat as is, but when you're scarfing extra saucy ones down while 10 of your coworkers are watching you and also waiting for you to finish--it's kind of mortifying. 

The food itself was mediocre. Alas, something I was promised.

The worst part, really, is that the waitress did not even apologize, and because we were a large party, she was awarded a fairly high tip for remarkably sub-par service.

I have a theory that their service is so awful because the restaurant has stringent requirements for its waitstaff that are totally irrelevant to waitressing competence: i.e., must be able to fit into an XS, off-the-shoulder dress. This, my friends, would explain a lot.
author: Anna L.

description:
This is was a tough one to review.  I liked the food, but I feel that the prices are a little high for Thai food.  I suppose it's on par with Osha Thai, but I think that place is a pricey as well, and i feel like it has the same kind of flavors and atmosphere--definitely more of a hip vibe than your usual thai spots. 

We started with the calamari appetizer and the dumplings--both were not what i was expecting.  Neither were bad, but i don't know that i would order either again.  I thought the calamari was a little bit tough. 

For the main courses, we had the pumpkin curry, the scallops and the green beans plus rice.  

The pumpkin curry was excellent.  No complaints there--plus it is presented in the actual pumpkin so that was a nice touch.  

The scallops were breaded which was ok, but the breading was too heavy for the scallop and kept falling off.  That was fine since I didn't feel they needed it.  The scallop was flavorful enough on its own with the sauce.  

lastly, the spicy green beens were ok, not my favorite, and I have had better versions at other places.

I am sure I would end up going back there, but if I do, I am hoping someone else is going to foot the bill.
author: Lu E.

description:
i think its my favorite Thai place in the city and the best restaurant in our neighborhood! 
Have gotten food here several times - delivery, take-out, dine-in and always  the experience is amazing.

I love Thai food but being vegetarian, i cant eat or stand fish sauce, shrimp paste (and all its relatives) and i like it when a restaurant agrees to tweak its dishes to suit my dietary needs (note Osha Emarcadero and Osha 2nd Street are NOT as obliging)...

Love the red curry, the green beans, the tofu/eggplant, the corn fritters, vegetable fried rice, the thai iced tea and the coconut rice! Husband loves the firecracker chicken..

i really love this place, especially when I am craving some good curry (that's not Indian)..
author: Sapna E.

description: The food was OK, but we didn't order a full meal-- just cocktails and some apps.  It was a weekend afternoon and it seemed like they were out of a lot of things.  Several of the apps we tried to get were unavailable and service was pretty spotty.   The things were did get were ok, but the whole experience left something to be desired.
author: Katharine A.

description:
This is my favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco.  

I just recently went again after not going for a few years...I was nervous it wouldn't be as good as I remembered.  It was just as good, maybe even better!  

We did a family dinner and shared a bunch of entrees - each was more delicious than the next.  Everyone must try the Pumpkin Curry - it is an absolute must.  

Dishes I highly recommend: 
Tom Kha Gai Soup
Pumkin Curry
Basil Gai
Beef Mango
Spicy Crispy Chicken Fried Rice
Calamari Appetizer

Reasons CANNOT give the full 5 Stars: 
- A small bowl of plain white rice is $15....really?!?  (if one person orders, they charge for the whole table, $3/person)
- We asked how many pieces came per appetizer order...he said he could do a platter so everyone would get one of everything.  In turn we got 3 massive appetizer platters with way too much food at $24 PER platter. 
- Good signature cocktails but the glasses are tiny and the bartenders are slow. 

Overall, this is a must try.  I will continue to go because it really is delicious.
author: Morena C.

description:
We ordered 2 Pad Thai (one with chicken / one with beef) for delivery and the only good thing I can say is the food came fast.
Even tho we ordered one medium spicy and one not spicy it tasted exactly the same - like nothing.
author: Gilla E.

description:
I've been here for both their sit down and take-out for lunch. The food is more Americanized Thai. It's really pricey and the service is slow. 

 It really only cures my craving for Thai food when my mom can't cook.
author: Peonie S.

description:
This place was that busy on a Saturday night which is usually not a good sign. We needed a reservation for 9 and they had space so it was a go.

We got there at various times which didn't bother the restaurant which was nice as some places can get testy on that.

We ordered our food and the poor service began. The time between bringing out the first plate and the last plate was at least 15 mins. This meant that the first served meals were nearly done whilst the latter served meals were just getting started. 
As if to add insult to injury they didn't even serve you properly - they just put the dish at one end of the table and you had to pass it down to the correct person?! Odd. Never been to a place like that before.

The food itself was fairly good IMO. I had the Asian beef which was cooled to order perfectly. It tasted great with the pineapple salad and sticky rice.
My wife ordered the pumpkin curry which was supposed to come in a pumpkin but didn't?! It was also a good curry.
I'm not sure whether everyone enjoyed their dish...the grilled catfish looked good and our friend finished that off impressively.

For some reason, the wait staff kept dropping things - plates, forks, glasses.
author: Nick L.

description:
I couldn't have enjoyed my meal more here last night.

The dim lighting was perfect for drawing attention away from our recently self-tan sprayed faces, and low-key hoodies, and sweats. The decor was sophistiacted and classy, and the service was attentive throughout the night.

We ordered the mango salad, the spicy noodle dish, coconut rice and the sea bass clay pot.

The mango salad was divine. Fresh shreds of mango, intermixed with dried  coconut, spices, peppers, and prawns.

The sea bass and spicy noodles kept the quality coming. The sea bass was moist, non-fishy tasting, and was snuggled beautifully amongst string beans, mushrooms, and thin noodles. The portion of fish was impressive considering the price. The spicy noodles were also delicious. There was a plethora of vegetables, and the spiciness and slight grease of the noodles complimented the sweet coconut rice and buttery sea bass perfectly.

I'm definitely keeping this place in mind for future spontaneous dates with my bf in the future.  I'm confident that Koh can wrangle up delectable fresh food and spicy romance with the best of them. And even if you're looking for a fun roomy spot to meet up with a group of friends - Koh has plenty of room to accomodate.
author: Jessica T.

description:
The one thing about this place that consistently kept me coming back was the fact that their pad see ew noodles (thick wide rice noodles) were fresh and had a texture and flavor unlike any other pad see ew in the city.  Turns out, they now are serving the same thick rice noodles as every one else.. and that bums me out.

Other than that, The Monkey serves some comparable Thai food to the many other Thai place in this area.  The bar and bartenders are very friendly and it makes a good stop for happy hour.

The to-go options are also really tasty.

All in all, good place.
But bring back the tasty rice noodles!
author: Lily B.

description:
Because we got there just before 7pm, the special happy hour menu was still in effect and the dishes were half off: $5 each. So the idea was to get a bunch of small dishes to try lots of different things.

When the "small" tasty dishes arrived we couldn't even eat half of it they were large!

I'll give it an A for value!
author: Bill W.

description:
Sigh. I really hate to do this. I really do. 

But I have been consistently let down now (keep in mind I gave them 5 chances before I write this update review). This place does not know what spicy means apparently. It seems every time I say "make it spicy" they do the opposite. In fact it's almost as if they make it "un-spicy."

I don't know why people say they make spicy food because I haven't once been impressed or even phased with the spice at Koh Samui.

Oh by the way my $15 curry didn't have but 3 chunks of meat in it a few of gross cherry tomatoes and a handful (AT BEST) of mushrooms. Literally 5 small scoops of the curry and the substance was GONE. The rest is just broth. $15 for this shit? ARE YOU KIDDING ME? I'm pissed - because this dinner wasn't even fulfilling! The curry I had was super soupy and bland. It was sour and despite what the description stated (that it was a 'very spicy dish') it wasn't spicy at all not even the slightest. 

My boyfriend loves this place but after tonight we will NEVER be going back. I feel like I got ripped off!

We only order from them due to the convenience since they're only a block or so away. Thank God we're moving close to an Osha soon.
author: Sara M.

description:
Nothing special except for nice ambiance, enough waiters for good/frequent service, and fancy food presentation. 

This is a review for smoked catfish + fried chicken in fried rice: 
The food quality itself and taste are sub-par.  

Smoked catfish: meaty piece of catfish but swimming in very sweet and spicy thai sauce.  We're talking what tastes the like the sweet and source sauce you can get at 99 ranch.  The fish wasn't fully cooked all the way in too (probably because of cooking style - smoking might not get it cooked inside all the way w/o overcooking the edges).  Either way you know catfish is still raw when the meat doesn't break apart easily and is chewy.  

Fried Chicken in Fried Rice: this is normal panko chicken.  Thai fried rice, when done well, is very fragrant - I think it comes from the heat of the pan and stove as well as oil and onions.  This fried rice was just meh.  Tasted fine but not great.  

A plus is that they have TVs and a Bar so you can come in here and watch a game over mediocre Thai food in a relatively nice and clean restaurant in SOMA.
author: Alias A.

description:
We wanted to go somewhere close to home, so we went to our neighborhood Thai restaurant. What a mistake...

In an empty restaurant they made us sit in the back next to the hallway, "in case a big party arrived", was the answer we got, when we asked politely if we could change seats. 
After we ordered, it took about an hour to get our food, only to have it taken away, because it was the wrong table. Another 25 minutes later ONE of our 3 dishes came. (let me just remind you that the restaurant was not even at half capacity). After we were almost finished with our first dish (no, it was not an appetizer), the rest of the mediocre dishes came. 

Then to top it off, as I was chewing, there was a crunchy-ish piece of something, sorry to be a little gross, I took it out of my mouth, to find a piece of ceramic that chipped off from SOMEWHERE... to give them credit, they did take that dish off the check...but come on!!! 

Never again...
author: rebecca c.

description:
If you think you know about Thai food, it is the place you want to avoid.  All the dishes taste nothing but sugar.  Nothing is spicy so we had to ask Prick Nam Plah, but it was the least spicy Prick Nam Plah I ever had in my Thai food experiences.  Moreover, it was one of the worst jasmine rice I had had in the city.  It's mushy and it was yellow just like the rice was kept in the rice cooker with warm function for at least 6 hours.
As for interior, it one of the nicest Thai restaurants in the city, but food is so disappointing that I won't go back there, never.
author: Sachiko M.

description:
Tom yum Kung-not clear with a coconut base and western button mushrooms rather than straw mushroom. 
Larb- was ok, pretty spicy, decent, not enough roasted rice and didn't have any sticky rice (larb without sticky rice??? whaaaaat?) 

I think this place is good if you're into commercial American-Thai cuisine.
author: Sujan P.

description:
I came in for dinner with my family over Thanksgiving break and let's just say I was not disappointed by their culinary wizardry.  

First off, it seems like reservations are definitely the way to go - happy hour seems incredibly popular here, so if you're trying to drop by during the week I wish you the best of luck! Speaking of happy hour, their cocktail menu is delish - I tried the Mango Mojito...mmm, so good!

Between the three of us, we split the Beef Satay - the cucumber salad is so refreshing - and the Fresh Spring Rolls; then we moved our way to the main course. To be honest, I was so enthralled with my lamb that I have no clue what my parents got...but I do know that the lamb was damn good :)
author: Amanda G.

description: My hubby and I have been going out to dinner here almost 2 years. I'm all about 'green salmon' and can't count how many times I ordered! The grilled salmon is not so salty but so tender, and the green noodles are made of moloheiya. Chicken satay, beef satay, red curry, pumpkin curry and volcano fried rice etc etc. all of the meals are awesome. The service is always very nice and polite. We will go ack after we meet our dirt goals!
author: Asato T.

description:
Whaaa? Only 3.5 stars?  Koh Samui is a solid restaurant, it's my favorite Thai place in SF.  

The food = ridiculously good.  Atmosphere is a nice woodsy Thai/Indonesian theme, it's dimly lit, cozy, and romantic; my boyfriend and I had our first date here.  I've been here several times and have never been let down, everything is wonderfully flavored and cooked really well.  I read a review where someone complained about the lack of spice, this has never been the case for me; if I ask for it spicy, it comes out spicy.  I've never had an issue with the service, they've always been prompt with the food and check, and they check in mid-meal.

On to the food and drink:

Aromatic Pumpkin Curry:  O M Gosh, this is one of my favorite dishes ever.  This curry is so flavorful, and the pumpkin pieces are cooked to perfection: not too hard, not too soggy.  The curry comes in a hollowed out green squash, nice touch.  I've had OSHA's version of this and it doesn't even compare, Koh Samui owns this dish.

The Lychee Politan... this cocktail is a must.  Koh Samui has a great happy hour, cocktail and appetizer specials, plus $2.50 for beer.  There is always a good amount of people at the bar and their cocktails are really tasty.  The Monkey is Paris is my second favorite, and Shock the Monkey is great too.

TIP:  If you follow them on Twitter @kohsamuimonkey you will see their tweets for "Flip Night."   On flip nights, you can play heads or tails with the bartender to bet over whether you pay for your drink or not.  For real.  The bf and I have come in twice on Flip Nights and paid for 2-4 drinks out of about 10.  So fun.
author: S. F.

description:
Really great drink list, but it is different from what is listed on their website (strange). The pumpkin curry is literally the best thing ever. I just hate when places make you buy rice separately for a meal that requires rice for consumption. What the hell?? That's like requiring the purchase of tires separate from the car. Once the proper combination is created though, its like heaven. I recommend sharing this dish because, well its served in a pumpkin, so its HUGE.

Also the fried corn things and the spring roll appetizers were damn good themselves. I want to come back here for happy hour because they have some good appetizer and drink specials that are not to be missed. But really, I am just dreaming about that curry. Nom Nom.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
Came last night for dinner and the ambience was nice, although a bit too dark, it couldn't save the meal.  I expected traditional fare not fusion.

Our server, Linda, was absolutely the sweetest and so cute!  

We ordered the green papaya salad and I expected a little heat, but there was none.  The tomatoes were also overly ripe and too soft.  

The seabass green curry with eggplant was wonderful and cooked perfectly!  The crispy tofu was nice, but how can you mess that up?  The sauce was a bit too sweet/rich for my taste. 

Coconut rice was good.  

A bit strange to have tv's in a such an elegant restaurant.
author: Coy T.

description: Came by for a business lunch and it was pretty good Thai food and friendly service. I'd definitely come back again.
author: Rowena L.

description: We had a groupon for this place and checked it out one week night. It was not very busy as it was around 8 or so. The $70 value did not apply to alcohol so we had to order a bunch of food to fulfill the amount. We had bags of gold for appetizer. It was ok. Nothing special and I wouldn't have ordered it on my own. I had this shrimp stir fry dish, my bf the the lamb, and we also ordered a pork belly dish and the green beans side dish to reach the $70. The portions were actually smaller than I had expected. I was able to finish my dish which is pretty rare. Everything was good, tho not amazing. I think I'd much prefer to go to a less swanky place to fill my Thai food cravings.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I've only been here for lunch and it was awhile ago too, since our office has now moved and Koh Samui isn't walking distance anymore.  We did go quite often though, several times a month, so I think I have a good grasp of the place.

Honestly, I haven't found too many places with the same quality of food as Koh Samui.  I mainly would order the Pad Thai or the Pad See Yew, but both were excellent and amazing.  I've tried various appetizers and the Thai iced tea and never once left unhappy.

Service can be a bit slow during lunch hour, but it's semi-expected during a lunch rush.  We'd get out a bit later than we'd have liked for lunch during work, but overall not much to complain about.  

Recommended to try it out if you're in the area and searching for some good Thai food!
author: Cassandra J.

description:
The ambiance is what makes this place a four-star; iIn reality, it's more of a 3-star. I came here with co-workers and then again with my friends and both times (during lunch hours), the place is PACKED. Because the food was expensed on the company, we ordered a crapton of food.

Ambiance: Very decorative- Thai statues, waiters/waitresses are all wearing traditional thai clothing. I'm a clean freak and judge a place based on the restaurants bathroom and Koh Samui fails in this area. So ghetto and ugly... And, it's in the corner of the restaurant. Meh... grosses me out. Besides that minor detail, the place itself is very clean and lots of open windows. 

Service: Kind of on the slow side. We always have to wait ~15 minutes before anyone comes by to take our orders.

Food: 
Appetizers
- Fresh Spring Roll w/ shrimp, mint leaves and noodles. They are really fresh but pretty miniature
- Crispy Imperial Roll stuffed with ground pork, silver noodles and vegetables-- basically your typical eggroll. I'd opt for something else given that they were $9.

Main dishes:
- Pumpkin Curry Chicken in red curry sauce with basil and bell pepper -- I just like pumpkin in general. I liked how there were big chunks of pumpkin and the sauce wasn't too sweet, which happens sometimes with pumpkin dishes.
- Madame Sea Bass simmered in green curry with green beans, bell pepper, fresh basil and eggplant -- Apparently this is a house special and a popular choice. I really liked the sea bass. It was well cooked and the green curry with it wasn't overwhelming. 

**For spicy food lovers, the spicy level on the menu is a lot lower than I expected.  I was intimidated and ordered the regular spicy level and ended up having to add in more of the pepper sauce (this in the perspective of someone that needs sriracha sauce on virtually all everything hehe)

Dessert:
- Monkey's Mummy (banana topped with flake coconut and orange zest served with coconut ice cream) -- if you have a sweet tooth this is a good choice.
- Monkey's Mango (sticky rice and mango slices) -- my favvvvv. I loved the fresh mango. Sticky rice was okay too. Less sweet than other thai places.
- Chocolate cake-- it was pretty damn random that they had CHOCOLATE cake at a thai place... but we ordered it anyway just for the heck of it. it was whatevers.... I'd go with one of the mango desserts than wasting your stomach space on this.

Note: you can ask for brown rice or sticky rice in replace of white. I tried some of this unique sticky rice off of a friend's plate (She went to Thailand for a semester studying abroad) and it was very interesting! I think next time I'm at a Thai place, i'll order it.
author: D S.

description:
They charge $2.50 for a single serving of brown rice -- Yikes!

On the other hand, each time I've been here, it's never crowded and you can actually talk to the person across from you without repeating yourself.
author: Lisa R.

description:
The food here isnt that great. The decor on the other hand is beautiful. We were welcomed by a hostess whom was wearing a traditional thai outfit. Very cute. We got the fried spring roll appetizer which was THE BEST I've ever had. The sweet and sour sauce complimented the dish quite nicely. Their Thai ice tea was sensational! Not TOO sweet, but sweet enough. I got the Pad Thai which was not good. It was too tangy with whatever sauce they use. The noodles seemed too soft. But the veggies were nice and crisp. 

I suggest this for a group of people whom can choose a bunch of dishes to share. Otherwise, I wouldn't drive down to SOMA, search for parking, and eat here. I could just go across the street from my house for good Thai food.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
This place sucks ____ . 

Stopped by for dinner and ordered the tom kha soup. The broth was good, but the chicken was flavorless. The chicken curry tasted like ass. Carrots were not fully cooked, flavorless chicken (is there a theme here), and the sauce was too runny. The firecracker seafood dish was spicy and the peanut sauce was nowhere to be found.

Thumbs down. Food was below average. I cannot believe Gayot gave it a 15/20 rating. Total discrepancy.

You like Thai? I like Thai, too.

What is wrong with the world.
author: Betty N.

description: Great food, really charming environment. The service is super. Some of the fish dishes are over cooked, but still with nice flavor. Would come again
author: Lee I.

description: very good and used to be my favorite but sometimes lunch quality is not as good as dinner.  just beware.
author: Maria L.

description:
We discovered this place tonight because, well, it's Thanksgiving and the person who was going to make Thanksgiving dinner fell ill a few hours before it was time to prepare. So at 6:30pm we were looking for a place; anyplace really, to go and have our dinner. My dining companion took her parents to a "traditional American Thanksgiving feast" for lunch, so we didn't want to do that again... so thought that something ethnic would be in order. We checked out OpenTable.com to see what places were even open on Thanksgiving night, and viola, we stumbled upon Koh Samui & The Monkey. Such an odd name, it stuck out.

We had the Tom Kha Gai soup; and it was spectacular. One of the best I've had. Though the portion was a bit small for $5.00. I also ordered the red curry beef, and it was flavorful and delicious, though the portion again was a touch on the small side, and you had to pay for rice so it ended up a bit pricey.

Service was average. Nothing bad to say. Nothing good to day. The venue itself was tastefully decorated and in a nice location. Didn't hurt that parking was easy because of the holiday.

If the portions were a touch larger and the prices a dollar or two lower, this would have been a five star restaurant.
author: Sean B.

description:
good for happy hour.  $3-$5 beers and nice mix of cocktails.  also conveniently located close to the ballpark and never busy during games.  

i miss max, which is why i knocked it down a few stars.  otherwise i would give this place 5 stars.
author: Tina L.

description: What a great find in Soma. Very good Thai food at pretty good price. Good service and the locations is light and bright. Great lunch time place. I rally like it.
author: Marc R.

description: Very impressed with their delivery service.  My order arrived within 20 min and it was delish!
author: Shivs B.

description:
I ate again at Koh Samui and the Monkey and found the food outstanding as always.  This restaurant and its sister places (Another Monkey as well as, way back when, Citizen Thai) have always gotten my vote as the best Thai food in San Francisco. But ...

The service was really bad in many ways.  It was a real disappointment because, based on past experiences, I expected much better.  For now, I would stick to Another Monkey as I've only ever had perfectly fine service there.

What went wrong?

1.  We requested a reservation through their web site and never got a confirmation back.  Sure enough, when we got there, they had no record of our reservation.  Fortunately, the place was not too busy and we were able to be seated right away.

2.  Within seconds (literally) of us sitting down and cracking open our menus, the waitress appeared and asked if we were ready to order!  Naturally, we said we needed a minute.  We got that minute and about 20 more -- even then, the server only came back when I asked someone else to fetch her.  Also, she hadn't even asked if we wanted a drink while we were deciding (I don't really care about that but it is standard practice usually).  

3.  When I ordered, I specifically said which 2 dishes we wanted to come first and which 2 dishes we wanted to come in a second round.  But all 4 came at the same time -- there wasn't even enough room on our table to fit them!

4.  It was another long wait after we finished before we again had to ask another staffer to fetch our server with the check.

I can forgive any one of these things in isolation but, coming all together in one meal (and, remember, the place wasn't even particularly busy, so that's not a factor),  the pattern seems to indicate a systematic problem.
author: pablo p.

description: Pretty, pretty yummy. Don't usually get calamari at Thai places but glad we did. A little upscale so a little pricey but they definitely do take care in preparing their food.
author: Mahsa K.

description:
Ruh-roh... My tummy is semi-angry :-/ 

I was prepared to give this place a 4 star review, but I had to deduct one because my stomach has been uneasy ever since I left the restaurant.  

Came here with two friends (Thursday night) and parking was ample and there was no wait.  Place feels authentic, but with contemporary decor.  Super cute place to catch up with friends or for a date.

Appetizer: we ordered the vegetarian samosas to share (comes w/ 4)
This was okay - portions were small and the ingredients on the menu made it seem so unique (yam, carrot, corn, wood-ear fungus, jicama) but it was all blended into a paste that was almost too thick.  

Entrees: I had the royal green curry (vegetarian) with coconut rice ($3), and my friends had the sesame crusted scallops and the pumpkin curry.

-Royal Green Curry: this was flavorful; sauce was a bit much given the small portions of the rice, but there was a good variety of vegetables (though a lot were canned...)
- Pumpkin Curry: my friend said that this was also bad curry to rice ratio and that while it was good, he felt like the spiciness detracted from the pumpkin taste.  This was served in an actual pumpkin (pretty large one, too!)
- Sesame Crusted Scallops: my friend said this was good - scallops weren't that big, but it was tasty and served with bok choy.

Service: In general it wasn't bad, though there was a semi-awkward moment when the waitress came and tried to take my friend's plate away but there were clearly some more scallops and she wasn't finished eating...

Hopefully my tummy feels better...but I won't write of Koh Samui just yet
author: Alvina W.

description:
OK so here is the simple version of what could be a complex review:

GREAT FOOD!
A little pricey- no lunch menu?
HORRIBLE SLOW SERVICE
 THe food is so great I will on occasion risk the timing to poossibly slide into my seat late at work . By no means should lunch  take over an hour, and you have to beg for your check. 

If you have no time limits this is a great place and the food is awesome- I love the pad thai, and coconut soup (can not think of the name) also my friend loves the green curry with beef- she and I get the same things almost everytime.
author: Tera T.

description: An update on this place- so not only did I get seriously sick for a few days after eating here, but I ended up with a more serious condition- only found out about it upon repeat visits to the doctor who suspected appendicitis. After multiple tests, an infection was discovered- and it turns out due to parasites in the food at Koh Samui.  It's taken a few months to recover from the effects of the infection and then the strong medication needed to alleviate it (lost about 10 pounds in 10 days)- so once again, try to avoid this place!
author: Romita J.

description:
Had the fresh spring rolls because  thought it would a safe bet for a place I've never been. They were nothing special but not terrible. 

I was so excited to try the Koh Tao Noodles but I wish I hadn't. The sauce had the texture of peanut butter. Which made it too hard to eat and wouldn't even give it another chance. 

The only thing I did enjoy was the prawns and cashew nuts. All the spices and vegetables blended well with the shrimp. We didn't even bother with dessert after though.
author: Becky B.

description:
Me and a friend stumbled upon this place while in the city and decided to give it a try. The place is very nice and welcoming. Everyone from the server to the bartenders are also very friendly and nice. The restaurant is quite spacious for something that's in the city. 

While dining in the intricate, dimly lit place, I was very satisfied with the service and the taste of the food, yet I did wish the portion sizes were a little bigger. The tom-yum kung wasn't spicy enough so make sure u let your server know if u like your food spicy.

All in all this is a nice place to take your date if u want some good Thai food on the town.
author: Sandeep R.

description: I was in that place during happy hours...The meal was delicious for affordable price. I liked the staff especially the asian bartender girl was very nice and smart.
author: Tereza E.

description:
3.5 Stars. I seriously looooove Thai food, and I know where to get it cheap AND tasty. I'm sorry, but if I'm going to pay $12 for Pad Thai, it better be out of this world...like orgasmic...and a lot of it....but this place disappointed. If I were a guy and knew what blue-balling felt like, that would be it.

The place was completely empty when we got there for Saturday lunch. And we proved our theory that only Asian places are open on holidays. They never rest.

The Thai Iced Teas and Coffees were really good. I'd definitely go for the Pumpkin Chicken Curry again (though it was $16!). It is beautifully presented in a hollowed out green-pumpkin shell, and the insides were so yummy. The Pad Thai disappointed and was a bit bland. The Grilled Bangkok Chicken BBQ was juicy but a bit too sweet. The Tom Yum Kung soup was not yum. It was so sour tasting or tangy or somethin'!

This place is just not worth the value. It is a nice little space upstairs w/ a lot of open windows, but other than that, I think our money could've been MUCh better spent elsewhere.
author: Gina C.

description: It's def pricey, IMHO, but this place is fresh, tasty Thai food in a really nice atmosphere.  Though oddly slow (esp w/ drinks), service is super friendly and you get the sense they all take pride in their work and earning happy patrons.  Since they're in my hood, I've gone a number of times over the years.  Have tried over half of the things on the menu by now, and everything has been consistently good.  The peanut sauce is killer, so be sure to order a side of that crack-o-yum-yum no matter what else you're getting.  Props for having grüner by the glass too!
author: Jen H.

description: 1/2 the food, 1/2:the quality for double the price!! Had the green curry because they recommended it since I said I liked spicey. I asked for no meat or tofu just extra veggies. What I got was a joke..just a few carrotts, brocolli and mild, almost tasteless curry. And $12! I left hungry and very dissatisfied!
author: Julie V.

description:
I've been to Thailand many times, love authentic Thai Food. Tend to be leery of the "California Thai Fusion" restaurants that have popped up like the Osha chain.  I went here cuz I had a Groupon with two of my friends. Not expecting much... But was blown away. Is it Authentic?  Well it IS very well done Authentic Thai Fusion.  It would hold it's own in Bangkok.  Tofu Meing Kom, very fresh, nice flavorful ginger, only thing missing for me were the diced thai chillies, but I can understand, this is San Francisco and even though we think we are "hip" we can't really stand the heat.  My Emerald Curry ( Keang Keow Wan Talay) was exquisite. I asked for it Thai spicy and didn't get it quite as hot as I wanted it, but it was hot enough and very good.  My friends ordered the Sea Bass Clay pot, and a spicy pork Belly dish. All cooked to perfection and very tasty. We had two really nice upscale  glasses of sake and a "Monkey in Paris". Hell I would come here for the bar alone.  I will be back, and I will bring friends.

Emmie,  sorry about the celebrity bug, some creatures will do anything to get on camera :)  I didn't see any.  I did eat fried crickets when I was in Thailand, maybe someone in the kitchen got carried away :)
author: Geoff W.

description:
I was totally looking forward to checking out this place after I recently purchased a Groupon for it. However, post-dining experience, I have severe mixed emotions about the place!

The food was fantastic....no denying it. My fav Thai food in SF is probably Osha, but this was hands down delicious. To start with, we ordered the chicken satay, which was slightly overcooked but the flavor was still good. For the main course, we ordered the tofu pad thai, asian beef, and the southern kur king (spicy ground chicken). We also ordered the spicy tofu, which NEVER SHOWED UP (and I forgot to check whether they billed us for it, because I had one too many glasses of wine at that point). Anyway, the food that did show up was fantastic. When they mean spicy, they mean spicy, so beware.

In terms of ambiance, I was slightly disappointed upon first walking in. The shades were all pulled up, he light was pouring in, and the not-so-attractive scenery of Brannan St. was quite visible. Basically, it was nothing like the pictures on the website, and not why I chose this restaurant. In addition, the AC was cranked on, so it was FREEZING like an ice box (we politely asked them to turn down the air, and they complied). Oh, and this was at around 6pm. However, after the sun finally set, the interior ambiance started to show up in dark wood, dim lighting, and asian decor. It turned out to be very trendy and romantic.

MY MAIN GRIPE: We went here for a birthday occasion, so upon making the dinner reservation via OpenTable.com, I indicated in the notes section that this was a special birthday dinner. Having completely forgotten about that note, I was completely shocked when they brought over a nice little plate of chocolate cake with coconut ice cream and a happy birthday serenade. It was very sweet! The cake was actually delicious (and I normally don't like cake), and the coconut ice cream complimented it quite well. We didn't have to go to our next spot for dessert. HOWEVER, and here it is...I got the bill, and they charged us a whole $9 for the cake!! WTF?? Who does that? First of all, birthday dessert is normally complimentary at restaurants, and when it's not, they specify....not just randomly bring something out to your table and then BILL you for it!? Especially on a tab that was already $80?? NOT COOL. Management needs to get its act together. Two stars for that shadyness.

I'm uncertain whether I'll be back at this point...
author: Mansi A.

description:
I've only eaten here twice.  It's a bit pricey and always busy, so I guess that's why our lunch crew doesn't go here on a regular basis.

This review adds on to Matt N's one star review.  My food was good, as it was the last time I was here, but I was appalled at how the waitress handled his order of clearly undercooked chicken.  He wasn't rude, or impatient, or any of the normal reasons why you could see a waitress getting snippy and not offering to comp the meal or at least his beverage.
For this to have happened at a restaurant of this caliber is simply unacceptable.
author: dan s.

description:
Despite a visit without a reservation on Friday night, we could easily get a table! Nice. 

FOOD
1) Tom Yum Kung Soup -Bit too sweet and sour. The sourness tasted like coming from some vinegar or something like that... I believe Tom Yum Kung sourness must come from lime originally. Also it was not hot nor spicy. 
2) Green papaya salad -OK dish. The portion was a bit smaller than expected. However I love green papaya salad at almost every place...so may not be able to give a fair judgment...
3) Pad thai -Mysterious sourness...and sweetness....

Decor / Atmosphere
Clean and modern with cute a bit accent of Thai taste. Tables are set decently but the atmosphere is casual.

Service
Good. Friendly and nice!

Price
Decent. Total $45 for above with an orange juice and a glass of red wine.  Red wine was actually the most expensive of all ;-P 

Over all..., I don't think I would visit here again...
author: Heidi M.

description:
Small portions, not much flavor and pricey dishes.  This is my second time here and I am still underwhelmed.  Two dishes that seriously disappointed me Southern Curry w/ Beef Stew and the Pork Belly with Basil.  Both are fattier types of meat if cooked the right way, but Koh Samui did it all wrong.  The beef stew was tough, dry and overcooked to the texture of liver, not what I was expecting.  Not to mention the curry was presented on a plate with a spoon, which I don't get how I am supposed to scoop it up and serve it with rice.  The pork belly was overfried, so I had a hard time chewing it.  I have to say that the waitress was very nice as we showed her the beef stew was close to inedible and she took it back and switched to some other dish for us.

Service is very slow.  We waited for about 10 minutes before someone came by to take our order and we had to ask for water.

The atmosphere is nice.  The candlelights with the thai decorations in a clean, industrial like space is a pleasant touch.  But it doesn't justify the underwhelming food presented to us.

Sorry Koh Samui, I won't be back.
author: Yun W.

description:
so glad my friend introduced me to this place!

love that they are clear about making the veggie options WITHOUT oyster sauce... this is often a problem as a vegan...

started with the Tofu Mieng Kum-- yum!  presentation was pretty, too :)  had the Eggplant Tofu as my main dish-- again, delish & a little spicy.  portions are smaller than your typical "down home" Thai place.

service was great.  nice ambiance.  good prices.
author: Virginia D.

description:
The pumpkin curry is the best I have eaten. The pad thai is the worst I have eaten. It makes it worse when I know I have spent a lot (as takeout thai goes).

Ok. The pumpkin curry is definately worth going back for. The curry is thick and tasty. They put in lots of "stuff" and isjust the right spicy, not overpowering. I HATE when I order pumpkin curry elsewhere (there are FIVE thai restaurants within 3 blocks of eachother) and I get a thin curry where I have to dig for "stuff" and only get a couple of pieces of pumpkin. I have actually saved the sauce, purchased some vegis and had another meal ... but it is not what I was paying for!

The pad thai was awful. It tasted off/old. The noodles were overcooked and because they are rice noodles, it ended up in just a bloob. There were also huge pieces of crispy,almost burnt egg. And unlike the curry, there were barely any vegetables. There was nothing fresh and bright about it.

Koh Samui & the Monkey is definately a hit and miss. It just annoys me when I know I spent more than some of the other thai restaurants in the area. I probably will not be adventuresome in future orders. It also means I will not bring anyone there.
author: Ginger K.

description:
The past few weeks have been a blurry of lunch meetings and early morning coffees, but along the way, I've been able to explore some great new spots.

Last week we sat down at Koh Samui and The Monkey, and if the aroma that drifts for blocks isn't enticing enough, the bustle of wide eyed eaters that pack into the venue will excite you.

The menu offers a wide selection, inspired heavily by the many spices that accompany Thai cuisine. Heat, distinct flavor profiles and rounded for the American eater, the menu is easy to navigate.

A lunch special of Yellow Curry with potatoes and curry came with a side of Crispy Imperial Rolls. 

The curry has a smooth tone, that was gentle on the taste buds and cooperated with the heavy and rich imperial rolls. Freshly pickled greens accompany the dish which offer a refreshing reprieve from the bold flavors on the plate.

Service is genuine and although the venue is busy at lunch, each server took great care of us.

A great lunch spot in the heart of SoMa, I'm glad to add this to my list of top Thai restaurants in the city.

( I still have no clue where and how they got this name... )
author: Mike K.

description:
This is the first review I have written because I absolutely had to comment on how amazing this place is! I went here last night for a work dinner and have nothing but praise for this restaurant. To begin with, we had a large party of 13 or so and our reservation was perfect. The service was phenomenal.  This was a celebration work dinner for the holidays and we weren't the quietest of groups. We even broke a plate (sorry!) but the bartender, waitress, and other staff were beyond courteous and the food came fast!
The food is delicious! It's a little overpriced in my opinion for the portions, but I will definitely be back for a number of dishes. I highly recommend this restaurant for a group dinner. You will not be displeased.
author: Paige F.

description:
I can't comment on the food, as I didn't get to eat it. Seriously; a 35 minute wait for some rice noodles in peanut sauce? I waited as long as I could. As I write this, the food is in the office fridge, untouched, because I didn't think to set aside the hour and 30 minutes that are required to eat lunch in this place. Maybe the kitchen staff at dinner is different, but I cannot recommend this place for lunch.

ETA: Try Ozone around the corner. The food is decent, they're prompt and polite and their $6 lunch special is generous and tasty.
author: Annelise D.

description: The service was great, the food was absolutely amazing, and the bill did not break the bank. I have actually been to this same location in Thailand, and the food was just as good if not better. I would highly recommend this place. :-)
author: Frank C.

description:
The drinks were great (especially the one that comes in a pineapple), the food was still pretty decent (especially the curry that comes in a pumpkin), if over priced compared to other thai restaurants. The issue was in how long it took us to order and how the food came out.

Each person was basically getting their own plate, and it should have been obvious because each person ordered a single plate. So when they brought out the salad my friend ordered first it was a weird mistake for a decent restaurant to make (you serve everyone their main course at the same time).  If you want to get a salad for yourself while your friends eat, you need to be extra specific about when it comes out because they just assume that everything will be split regardless.

After that, no food came out for about 30 minutes. It was rather inconvenient. The drinks were also quite slow to come out, both because it was hard to get the attention of someone to order it, they sometimes forgot the order and the general process was also a bit slow. 

It looks like they had too few waitresses for such a busy night and the side effect was bad service. I hope they fix this, because I like the food and the drinks there otherwise but it isn't worth going out and spending money is the restaurant isn't getting orders to people in a reasonable amount of time.
author: Jeff L.

description:
I don't do well driving in the city ... especially when it's the night of a ballgame.  I was flustered, I was hungry ... I needed a drink.  We ended up here ... which is really a very odd name for a Thai Restaurant ... and it's "The Monkey" part that I remember.  

Anywho, we had a waiter in "training" wait on us and he was super nice.  I know he was making every effort to be polite and do everything right.  I think he did a great job!  He seemed shy, so I didn't catch his name, he was a blonde kid, but I really respected that he wasn't all up in interrupting us so that he could take our orders and stuff.  I really dislike super aggressive waiters who interrupt you and get all up in your business when you're just trying to enjoy your friends.  Anyway, he was patient with us as we took forever on the wine list (and then ended up sending a bottle back ... prior to uncorking) and recommended the riesling which was delicious by the way.  

I was very pleased with the appetizers here.  We had the calamari, crispy imperial rolls, vegatable samosas, and Mieng kum.  All of it was delicious.  Great flavor, great presentation - very very tasty.  I definitely recommend all of the aforementioned appetizers.  Unfortunately, the rest of the meal doesn't inspire such rave reviews.  The pad thai was average, the spicy sirloin beef was alright ... meat didn't taste very tender, Fire cracker seafood sizzling hot plate ... didn't really seem to sizzle that much.  It hits the spot if you want a variety of seafood, but I had hoped for more flavor.  It is afterall, a Thai restaurant ....

In anycase, I wouldn't be adverse to coming here again ... but I'd probably stick to the appetizers.  Those are worth a repeat visit.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
Fabulous Thai Food for dinner

Fabulously dressed waiters and waitresses

Good atmosphere

Easy parking

The Pork Belly dish was amazing!  As was the duck curry

Bar area with NFL games on a flat screen tv

A very solid Thai option in SF
author: Curtis C.

description:
Like many of the restaurants in the SoMa area; they have a 7 day a week happy hour, which was quite impressive.
The food though was much more impressive.
Fried springs rolls were good with a nice presentation.
The Pad See Ew was good.
Pumpkin curry was plentiful in taste.
Service was good.
author: Po L.

description:
Ate here last night. Oh man it was delicious! Especially after a long day of first going for a walk around the park, and then going sailing. Wonderful!

We had the Pumpkin Curry, Duck Curry, Drunken Noodles, and Pad Thai. Everything was the bee's knees, the tops, and all that jazz. Note that the pumpkin curry is served inside a pumpkin.. how quaint!

I felt bad because we came here right before they closed. However, this seemed to work in our favor because all the dishes came out super fast.

So you may be wondering, why 3 stars? It's just too expensive for what it is. I've had excellent Thai food, exact same quality, for half the price elsewhere. Even though the food here was really good, and the ambiance was nice, and the service was good, it was just so expensive for what it was that I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Rachel H.

description: For the first time I can remember I walked out of a restaurant.  We ordered and 30 minutes later asked if there was a problem in the kitchen since others were served who came after us. Our server said she would come right back and didn't. We asked another server to talk to the manager.  She said she would get him.
