It eventually got so packed and busy. Everyone got into the game! Unfortunately, they did not expect such a crowd and they only had 4 people working the restaurant (including the one bartender). It took a while to get things but I still LOVED it!!! 

The appetizers are SOOOOO GOOOOD!!! My brother LOVED the calamari. My sister-in-law LOVED the tofu spring rolls. My friend and I LOVED the Pad Thai! The best Pad Thai I've ever had!!! I would definitely go there to try more of their dishes. They looked really good coming out of the kitchen and after reading some of the reviews on Yelp, I'm even more curious! 

The place is cute, nice size, and it would be a quiet place to enjoy a meal with a date. I definitely want to go back!!!
author: Tatiana O.

description:
Koh Samui has some rough edges.  First of all, they lost our reservation so we had to sit at the cramped and uncomfortable bar tables. 

Secondly, the place can't decide if it wants to be hip or kitchsy.  The decor is modern and clean, but the waitresses are gussied up in the most ridiculous Thai costumes.  And the drinks come with tacky plastic monkeys a la something you would find in the Tonga Room.  

Our waitress- who was in training- was just awkward.  She mixed up our order and had a hard time communicating.  She came at the wrong times, interrupted our conversation, asked awkward questions.... just odd.  This is bad enough, but the food could not make up for the lack of service.  Our green papaya salad came in a tall and narrow wooden coconut looking thing that was hard to eat out of.  It was tasty enough, but was accompanied by a random flock of butter lettuce chunks on the side- no dressing, just random chunks of butter lettuce.  Decoration?  We couldn't figure it out.  

The margarita was terrible.  What more can I say?

I ordered Tom Kha Gai soup- a perennial favorite of mine.   It was nearly inedible, however- terribly sweet as others have mentioned.

The main courses- seabass curry and pad thai were the highlights.  They alone nearly made up for all the other crappy bits.  Well prepared and very very good.  However, there are SO MANY other great Thai places in the city that I don't think I will return here again.
author: Nikki W.

description: The service is rude and slow. Will never go there again and advise you so too
author: Khash S.

description:
Tried to arrange for a bachelorette party dinner at this place and it was sooooo difficult.  The people didn't call us back after leaving three messages; we were told to call back a few times; we were hung up on; the language barrier made it difficult to convey we had a guest with food allergies.  It was just a bad start but we had heard so many great things about this place so we stuck to our plan.

Upon arriving, we were greeted by the host who took us to our table and the table was split in two so we requested for our tables to be put together.  The split table was not mentioned on the phone so we were a little disappointed they didn't tell us beforehand, making our entire party wait while they figured out what to do.  

We ordered and the food came fairly quick.  The food was good (order the papaya salad with shrimp) , but I've had better Thai food.  Our waitress was extremely nice but the manager looked irritated when we asked to have the tables put together.  Drinks are pretty good; try the mango mojito if you get a chance.  

Ambiance is nice, quiet (except for our table), good for a first date.

Overall the place was cool, but if we weren't hung up on and asked to call back after already leaving messages, it would've been a better experience.  

Definitely not a good place to have a large party unless you want to split into two tables.
author: KC C.

description:
3.5
the variety and quality of food and desert is exceptional. One of the better thai restaurants that ive eaten at. The prices are reasonable for the quality of food but the portions could be better. If you are looking for good thai food i would recommend this place.
author: Robert Y.

description:
I was in the neighborhood and in the mood for some Thai food, so i went in to the restaurant section, sat at the bar, and had lunch.  It's obviously a popular lunch spot, the place was packed.  The decor is nice, a good hip atmosphere without being overdone.  I was looking forward to a good meal, but I was really disappointed.  The service was weak...I sat for quite some time at the bar with no one around, finally walked over and found a menu at the front (no one there either), and went back to the bar.  Not much of a greeting when the bartender came back, no smile, just took the order.  Had to ask for silverware and napkin after food arrived, and for soy sauce and chili paste, which came in separate small open bowls on a plate.  I noticed later that they gave the same little plate with bowls to another party at the bar, which didn't seem very sanitary to me. 

The food was weak.  I ordered fresh rolls, which came with nice size shrimp but overall lacked flavor and didn't taste fresh...the sort of roll that I would expect in a grocery store deli.  The peanut sauce was odd, ingredients had separated, not the usual consistency I typically see in peanut dipping sauces.  For the main course, I got cashew chicken.  The chicken was twice cooked, probably deep fried once then sauteed with the rest of the ingredients.  The result was chicken that was chewy and tasted overcooked, the sauce didn't penetrate...not a good dish.  It came with white rice.

For that, and iced tea, the bill came to almost $24 plus tip....not a cheap lunch by any means, and given the quality of the two dishes I had, I wouldn't recommend this place.  In fairness, though, the place was crowded, so they must be doing something right...they missed with me though.
author: Rob C.

description:
I really don't know what is so great about this place. Been there twice...
First time I got tasteless food. Though I gave their Pad-Thai a try (can't really mess that up right?) Well they did... I got big fried greasy chunks of noodles so hard couldn't bite into them. I have to say this place is way overrated... :|
I really got monkey food...
author: Mar C.

description:
Going anywhere on a sunny day just seems to make a place better. I don't care if it's Westwood and the campus of UCLA or the slummiest ghetto ever.

Monday was my birthday and the sun was shining. Which meant that my birthday dinner at Koh Samui and the experience was better than would have been otherwise. 

The food here is good. That's the plus side. Corn fritters, beef and chicken satay, imperial rolls, and veggie samosas started us off and all were delicious - especially the fritters. Each came with a nice sweet sauce loaded with cucumbers and carrots. Yum. For main courses, we split the koh tao (like a chinese chow fun with gravy), honey duck (soooo tender and slightly sweet), mango salad, pumpkin curry, and my personal fave, the soft shell crab (steeped in garlic and salt and soooooo wonderful over rice - it also came with a creamy chili sauce which accompanied the rice with a light spice and a terrific flavor). The mango mojito I had was also yummy.

The reason why this place isn't 5 stars is the service and the entryway. The elevation of this place is seemingly pointless as the navigation from the wheelchair ramp is cramped. And the service. Oy. 

Do Thai restaurants have a requirement where their servers all have to be stereotypically thick accented Thai people? Also it took like 15 minutes for two cocktails. And I saw the waitress just shooting the shit with another server. Another mild annoyance was she asked how we were doing after half of each dish. Dude. Serve and check in with us in about a half hour...like every 5 minutes!

All in all I would come back here again. I just hope they recognize the deficiencies are NOT in the food. Keep up the AMAZING soft shell crab.
author: Aaron F.

description:
I love this place!  

I usually grab lunch here during the work week.  The food is prepared in a timely manner and they can accommodate a large group of people if you get there before the lunch rush or if you call in.  If you don't have time to sit, you can order online and schedule a pick up time-very convenient. 

No complaints with this place thus far.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Few ppl know my history with monkeys: I ran from them in the rain forests of Nicaragua and nearly got stalked by one in a temple in Agra, India. So I decided to take on the Monkey head on...on Brannan Street!

-Loved the chicken pumpkin curry! A+ for presentation, straight out of the pumpkin. Didn't realize pumpkin could be this spicy and tasty, they didn't skimp on the chicken either. 
-My fiancee had the spicy green beans and tofu, great seasoning and tofu was well prepared, also not too oily.
-Great tofu mieng kum; loved the spinach leaves, the coconut, and presentation!!!
- don't know how the samosa snuck into the menu, but vegetarian samosa was tasty, cucumber dressing had a nice kick, but had small portions compared to normal Indian samosas I'd eat.
-servers were very friendly and checked up on us, but were not overbearing. We got here at 5pm on a Saturday; early dinner, but best time before it got packed!
-great monkey theme, if they only included Donkey Kong...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Ja70QXfkr0&feature=related

Why no fifth star:
-loved the mango mojito, just a bit too much ice and not enough drink.
-make reservations by phone/opentable, place gets booked fast.
-loved the spicy green beans and ginger spice tofu, just a lil pricey for a small portion.

Would not believe from the exterior that it's a Thai restaurant. But really liked the place, big UPs for their presentation of food. Great reviews from the get go, so I'd say they lived up to the hype. I'd go here for a fancy Thai dinner, but if you wanted quick Thai food, look someplace else. Those that wanna have a nice sit down meal before/after a Giants game or in SOMA, a pricey but fun option. Would come back to try more monkey-themed dishes!
author: Neil N.

description:
Another great meal.  Started off with the crispy imperial rolls.  They come looking like a Jenga game, stacked on top of each other.  It looks like you're getting a lot, but in reality, because they slice the rolls in half before stacking them, you get 3 full rolls, and then the tower is topped with three rolls of basically fried carrot.  All of it delicious.

We shared a yummy curry beef stew and grilled BBQ chicken.  We also ordered coconut rice (dinky bowl for $3, really?), and Pad Thai as well.  Everything was really good.  The pad thai, while delicious, was the smallest portion.  Basically, it would give three people a small serving.  

The only bad thing was that from the time our 'take home bag' was packed and sitting on our table, it took about 15 minutes to get the bill, pay for it, and get our credit card back.  It's like we were done with our meal and they forgot about us.
author: Denise M.

description:
This is definitely a regular spot for me-- I love their food, the options are definitely not the typical Americanized menu you see everywhere. So many different types of vegetables, spices and offerings- it's hard to go wrong.  Love the Mieng Kum-- a great starter for any meal. Love that the pumpkin curry is served in an actual pumpkin.  Everything is appropriately spicy (a definite plus) and I'm always impressed by the ingredients and presentation of all of their dishes. There is such a wide variety of options, it's a new experience every time I go.

Had dinner with a group of 6 last night, and my only complaint was that they waited way too long to bring out the courses. I think they were attempting to be formal about the servings (appetizers followed by salads followed by entrees) but that ended up taking way too long and then we had too much food being served at the end. It was a bit frustrating especially when everyone was pretty hungry. But the service was very friendly, so we probably could have specifically asked for food to come out quicker.

Love the monkey.
author: Sonia S.

description:
Food was good - service was kinda slow but I think the waitress might have thought I was hitting on her.  

So we walk in - door isnt in your face, kinda nonchalant.  Decor in the place is a really neat....got a table by the window.  Ordered the beef satay - good but onl two small skewers....really?  Went with the pumpkin curry (recommended by fellow yelpers) ...was really good.  Dragon friend rice was good too - lots of additions (pineapple, mussels, squid) in addition to the rice....presentation of food was good - loved the pineapple display.  Would I come again....pretty sure!
author: Shel D.

description:
Definitely not a restaurant I would venture to for a date or any other special occasion. Sure the decor was nice, there was a nice bar setup and the food was decent... but nothing about this restaurant stood out to me.

Besides that I felt like I had to wait for EVEEEERYTHING. Ordering took forever. The coke that they gave one of the guests at my table was out of syrup and it was hard to get my busy waitresses attention to switch it out. I don't even think she came by our table once to check up on us and ask us if we needed anything the entire dinner. 

At the end of the meal she asked us if we wanted dessert. Me not wanting to wait any longer I said no. You would think common sense would be to bring the bill but she kept serving other tables, bringing their orders and taking orders. She could've at least dropped the bill to us before doing all of that. Service was definitely thumbs down. If you insist in eating here because you work or live around the neighborhood... I suggest you give yourself a significant amount of time.

And if you want suggestions on the food... I would see the sea bass in green curry was not bad. I also ordered the sampler appetizers... that was ok. Not anything to salivate over... I had better thai food.
author: Crystal S.

description: Got the papaya salad, jungle curry, spicy tofu. Watched game 4 of the World Series with excellent seating, great beer, and we still got to scream as loud as we could. This is a got-to-try, change up from all the other bars around the park.
author: Ben P.

description:
I have become an absolute fan of Koh Samui and the Monkey.  They really nail it!  Go here for an elegant meal at reasonable prices with consistently great food!

Lunch - Despite the upscale appearance, Koh Samui is a really great lunch choice.  Meals range between $7-14/person and they turn around the tables quickly.  Despite the appearance of a line, the wait is usually pretty short and the service is quick.  I'm a huge fan of the Larb Gai --mmmmmmmm meat salad!  Hell, the burger stand down the street runs $14 for a burger and fries.  Why not indulge in something far more elegant?

Bar - Creative cocktails and a rather comprehensive wine list --standard pricing.

Dinner - Koh Samui's pumpkin curry is a San Francisco dish not to be missed.  I'd put it almost on par with a plate of spaghetti from Emmy's.  Dinner for two with cocktails and an appetizer runs about $70.  Service is usually good but I've had to work to flag down wait staff a few times.

And what's up with the bathroom?  The bathrooms at Koh Samui are filled with photos of lost pets from all over the world, and each has a Sharpie inscription, "Belongs to Koh Saumi".  It's a little creepy.  I wondered if there was some Thai legend about some character named Koh Samui who cared for lost pets.  I finally asked the staff.  My waitress laughed and told me that the owner thought the posters were charming, but since people kept stealing them, the wrote on every photo!
author: Amy A.

description:
i had some bodacious pad kee mao here that left me thinking about it for weeks after...

spicy.  noodle'y.  oh so yum.

however, this place needs to be MUCH better at answering their phones.
author: Lauren P.

description: The coconut soup was great.  However, I ordered the Lamb To Die For and i WOULD have died if I'd eaten it - first bite and I knew that the lamb was starting to turn bad - I had to spit it out and ask that the dish be removed from our bill! Waitress did not offer compensation such as a free dessert.
author: Morgan S.

description:
Is there really such a thing as bad Thai food?  I would probably choose 
Osha for overall quality of food, but Koh Samui had cute decor, good food, and good drinks, all with the word "monkey" in them (the Pink Monkey was the bomb diggity, but you gotta get the very first one on the cocktail menu that comes in a giant coconut.  Fun!).  As others have mentioned, you do have to basically send a search party out to get your waitress, which is my lone complaint.  I guess it's nice to not be bothered every two seconds and asked if everything's okay, but quite frankly, there should never be an empty cocktail glass at the dinner table.  

Give it a try!
author: shojua p.

description:
I just had a late dinner here with my girlfriend and someone else.  It wasn't good at all, and I won't be returning.  Here's the break-down:

Atmosphere - nice
Service - OK
Food - amateur
Price - somewhat pricey, which is bad because the food is not good

I had quite a few items because we purchased the Groupon.

The corn fritters were heavy, fried dough balls with a sprinkle of corn kernels inside them.  Not good.

The Papaya Salad was flat in taste.

The Pad Thai, which is an easy "A" in any Thai restaurant was sub par here.

The Pumpkin Curry was probably the best dish, but was average.

The Fried Snapper was tough.

The Groupon would have been worth it if drinks were included, but they weren't.

There's so much better Thai food in the city, I would recommend just passing this place right up.  Maybe, just go to Brick House across the street.  That place hasn't failed me yet.
author: b p.

description:
A bit too fancy froo froo for my taste, but at least the curries were good (duck curry, chicken pumpkin curry). 

Also had some scallop peanut sauce dish that was okay although the scallop was overly breaded in my opinion. 

The Pad Thai was the most flavorless/dry/sour excuse for the staple dish that I have ever attempted to eat.  

Their take on the Tom Ka Gai seemed as if they forgot to add some key ingredients, shouldn't there at least be a hint of lemongrass?  It tasted like a bowl of room temperature coconut milk with some sugar.  I couldn't discern any lemongrass or other flavor at all.

The Avocado salad was my favorite of the night, a nice light crunchy dish with nice chunks of Avocado.

Another appetizer we had at the table was a leaf with some random ingredients on it, including a wedge of lime with the full rind attached.  This was hit or miss around the table. 

Flaming bananas were pretty good, not deep fried like many places.  I have to hand it to them for not coating the bananas with a crusy sludge that falls apart when you dig into it.
author: Stephen H.

description: There aren't a lot of options in Soma by the ballpark and Koh Samui & The Monkey is solid.  The food's great, setting's nice, and it's a convenient location.  The staff is also very accommodating.  Their sea bass noodle dish is yum!!
author: Tina T.

description:
"Fancy" and "Thai Food" in the same sentence?  Surely you jest!  No, and don't call me Shirley.

It's Thai food with a kind of posh flare.  Every time I've been here I've enjoyed myself.  If you know the right magic incantations for any sort of thai food that isn't on the menu, just ask.  They'll make you just about anything that you can properly name, but with ingredients that just sing.  Perhaps not as perfectly authentic as elsewhere in the city, but definitely a style and taste that is quite enjoyable.

My personal favorite is the BBQ chicken with sticky rice lunch set, yum!
author: Mason G.

description: This place is decent and affordable given the other Asian food selections near AT&T park. It's slightly better for curry dishes than the Ozone Thai, but the soups at Ozone are much better. This is a safe bet if you've got a business lunch since there's a decent selection.
author: Dana O.

description:
We had a disappointing experience. After recently moving to SoMa just down the street from Koh Samui. I had high hopes we had found the go to Thai place in our neighborhood. Sadly, we spent a small fortune on a meal that consisted of sub par Thai dishes and horrible service.

Our first mistake was ordering two overpriced cocktails that both tasted like Robitussin. Our second mistake was ordering the expensive appetizer sampler for two. The portions were tiny (they cut everything in half so they were technically serving an appetizer sampler for one) and with the $24 price tag I felt ripped off immediately. Next we moved on to the Pad Thai and Chicken Pumpkin Curry.

The curry dish was the best part of the meal, I would give just the dish alone 4 stars. Also it was served in a carved out pumpkin which was a fun presentation. The Pad Thai was flavorless and the noodles were overcooked and limp. 

To top if all off, there was one server in charge of all tables (8 or 10 were occupied) around 7:30 pm. We waited way to long for our cough syrup tasting drinks and food. 

We won't be back.
author: Elaine H.

description: Our company made a large order for dinner for pickup. I ordered Jurassic Prawns, which is served with a bed of asparagus. Only problem is that they were small shrimp served on a bed of plastic with two pieces of asparagus on the side. If by Jurassic they meant old instead of jumbo, then the description was spot on. Hard to see ever recommending this place to friends, as it would surely get me deleted from their friends list.
author: Ron L.

description:
Went here with my roommate for dinner. The place has a really neat decor, really impressive. The bar looks neat, and the tables are all white cloth with comfy chairs. 

Service - 1 star - HORRIBLE. We arrived and there were two dozen empty tables. Hostess said to wait five minutes and then just stood there chatting with the other hostess. We asked 15 minutes later, and she said she just forgot about us. I do not think she was trying to be rude, just lacked a little something up there it seemed. Still, stupid and really bad impression. Wet tray deserving. Waitress was along the same lines, never came back once even though the place was empty.

Food - Really good. Not authentic thai, but really good. The soup was fantastic, a must try. The curry was great too. The food was good enough to actually give this place 4 stars overall. 

Will return here again with expectations for better service. Price is okay, one entree and soup was around $40.
author: Ahmed S.

description:
I ordered skewers.. appetizers basically since I'm on a strict ass diet but nonethless it was flavorful yummy!  I had the chicken and beef skewers.. 

The restaurant ambiance was perfect but the service wasn't that great.  I'm not sure if the service lacked since it started to get busy but we ordered 2 items that we never got.. Jasmine rice and Thai iced tea.. 

I want to go back there to see if the service is really like that..
author: Tram N.

description:
i had been here once before and i dont know why i thought it was a more formal place than it really was.  then i learned its name was not just koh samui but koh samui and the monkey and all romantic visions of candle lit white table cloths and formally clad patrons disappeared.  their tables are dressed in white table cloths and they do have candles on them though they are battery operated.  but anyways how formal can thai food be ...

we came early before my friends bday dinner to have drinks at the bar.  they only had one bartender it seemed and he couldnt get to everyone.  he had to give my bf a free beer for taking so long.  not a bad deal i guess since we were in no rush.  i got a mango margarita which was good.  we also got the bar small plates of shrimp and duck.  these plates are really small.  the duck was missing the cucumber salad as the menu described and came with cabbage on the botttom instead.  the shrimp had a really spicy sauce which made my mouth feel like it was on fire. the bar meny also had noodle bowls that they didnt serve in the restaurant.

when we got to our table, our party of ten was stuck between the bathroom, the bar, and the kitchen.  not the best table, not the window view table but it was ok i guess.  our waitress was softspoken.  and i had to ask her twice for my drink.

we tried the beef and chicken satay, corn fritters, green papaya salad,  sea bass clay pot, eggplant and tofu, shrimp pad see ew, pumpkin chicken curry, and stew beef.  everything was good.  i thought i would like the sea bass a lot better but it wasnt as moist as i would have liked.  one of my pieces was all fat.  yucky.

i dont know if i like osha or kohsamui better.  i think osha gives bigger portions for the same price.  both of their pumpkin chicken curries are $16.
author: claudia y.

description: We have lived near Koh Samui and the Monkey for years and used to visit quite frequently.  Recently, though, the service seems to have gone downhill as has the quality of the dishes and drinks.  On our most recent visit, we found that the portion size of the pineapple fried rice has been cut almost in half of what it used to be (yet the price remains the same), the sizzling seafood platter was about 95% vegetables and 5% seafood, and the glasses of wine were about half the size of most other restaurants' glasses.  The service was extremely slow and the servers never checked on whether we needed more drinks (which we did).  Overall a disappointing experience for a local restaurant that we used to really enjoy.  We will not be returning.
author: Mark P.

description: Sat at the bar for lunch, left drunk, full, and satisfied.  The bartender is one of the finest in the city--made me a Rye Whiskey Sazerac with muddled Thai Basil and 3 kinds of bitters in an absinthe rinsed glass!  At a Thai place!?!  Yeah, and the food is great, a bit overpriced but awesome.  Recommend the Bento boxes!
author: Ryan H.

description: Right around the corner from my besties house, so a definite go-to when i'm in the city.  It is home to my absolute favorite yellow curry.  It is so tasty and I would seriously eat it every single day if I could!  Thanks for being on Mogl because every time I spend $20 a meal is donated to Feeding America.  Sign up here http://mo.gl/1fbinga2 and you get $5.
author: Leslie M.

description:
I've been to the Monkey several times, always for lunch. I really enjoy the food here and they always manage to seat the large groups I dine with, no reservation needed.

The service can be slow and spacey, but I image they have more solid waitstaff for the busier evening hours.

This is by no means the best Thai I've ever had but the place is really clean with great lighting. I do love their Curries and Imperial Rolls. In fact I'm a little addicted to the rolls, but that's normal for me. Last time I went I had the yellow curry which was delicious but on the side of heavy for a summer lunch. I like that they'll kick up the spice when you ask for it.

Also very cool is the ability to order online. Any time I can avoid a confusing phone call with a large order I'm a happy camper.
author: Samantha J.

description:
Working across the street from this place, its hard to miss this establishment, not only because of location, but also because their food is good.

I've dined here for lunch and dinner (both for work and personal), ordered take out for my team as well as had them cater company lunches (that was a year ago, before the economy tanked - company catered lunches!), and have been satisfied at all times.

The food is rich, flavorful and just the right sized portions. The soups are great, pad thai is good as are the individual dishes (garlic shrimp, string beans, chinese broccoli). Iced coffee is might good as well. 

Service can sometimes be a bit too good (your main course is served as you're mid way between the appetizers). Some of the tables for two are a bit too small to fit two main courses and appetizers... maybe they're cutting back on table size, who knows. It can get quite loud during lunch so if you're looking for a quiet and cozy dining experience, some in for dinner.

Nice place overall. Well priced and good food complimented with good service... what more could you ask for?
author: Amit S.

description:
The story behind the name of this restaurant is really sweet actually. Koh Samui = where the husband and wife owners met. Monkey = the wife was born in the year of the monkey. If my man and I were to open up a restaurant, I guess we'd have to name it Santana Row & the Snake. Hmmm... not sure what kind of food we'd serve there!

Anyways, while dining in is nice in this lovely, dimly lit (makes you look dreamy to your date) Thai restaurant that never has a wait, I love getting take out from here. It only takes about 15 minutes and you can order online!

My usual selections include the mango or papaya salad (get this mild unless you enjoy having your mouth on fire), sea bass clay pot and pad thai. The food is just as yummy as Osha, and the prices are cheaper than Osha's as well. And who doesn't love a cheap date place?
author: Connie C.

description:
Uhh...it's "AIIGHT"

Nothing to write home to Uncle JR about.

The pad thai is decent, and the spice selections is nice in some of their other dishes, but most of it taste like I paid too much for it and I should be angry about it.

Good place for lunch atmospehre. Nice neighborhood. Other than some tacky looking designs, I don't mind goin here every now and then, though it has been a while.
author: Elijah W.

description: like the other reviews, food was good but they're really cheap on portions. i ordered the panang curry, extra spicy, it came with 2 pieces of beef, a bit of the fatty side, after removing that fat, there' isn't much left.
author: Tiff W.

description:
First off, I love the ambiance, and the name of the place is so unique for a restaurant! I celebrated a birthday for a friend of mine. I called in ahead of time for a reservation letting them know this. 
We started off with the tofu Mieng Kum. They're little leaf wrapped, hand held goodies with a ton of flavor and killer sauce. I wasn't impressed by our grilled honey duck (as highly recommended by other yelpers) but the sea bass Mor Din was really good. The fish was done just right and I love the glass vermicelli noodles. They just soak up all the flavor. Finally, we ordered a dessert and they remembered it was for a birthday, so it arrived with a candle and a happy birthday song. I was impressed they remembered. Thanks for making this dinner so special.
author: Kathleen T.

description:
Had dinner here a while back on a Saturday night... we were able to get seats without a problem... When i heard the name, i kinda did a double take... "what monkey?" haha... but turned out to be a cute place for dinner...

had the pad thai here - which i almost never get. it was pretty good. we also shared the emperor steamed dumpling which was mixed chicken, shrimp with pickled ginger, ponsu sauce... yummy... almost dim sum like!

the dessert coconut ice cream is super good too! and they also had a full bar which was yummy...

Overall, it was pretty good and I would definitely come back here!
author: Cynthia C.

description: The food was creative but ok taste. BBQ chicken was too dry. the eggplant sauteed tofu was too oily and spicy. The service was friendly. The Deco was nice.
author: Jenny C.

description: eth, my Dad, and I were in the mood for some Thai and checked out Koh Samui & The Monkey in SOMA.  It's a modern, chic Thai restaurant; concrete walls with bright green paint blended with a rich assortment of Thai decorations ranging from large statues of traditional deities to elephants and monkeys .  The food was good, there were plenty of choices but not not an overwhelming amount.  We started with some stuffed mushrooms which hit the spot and then really enjoyed our entrees: a delicious pumpkin chicken curry, a seafood clay pot,  and a spicy grilled salmon dish.  Service was friendly and attentive from start to finish making this is a solid experience, I definitely plan on going back and trying more of the menu .  Oh, and it's SOMA, so parking was quite easy.
author: Saminda W.

description: The place was packed, yet it wasn't noisy. I was able to have a nice conversation over a lunch interview. The decor was interesting, especially their aquarium, that looked like a bird cage. I food was great, and the quantity was just right. I had Madame Sea Bass, which is sea bass simmered in green curry with green beans, bell pepper, fresh basil and eggplant, with a side of boiled white rice. Yummy!
author: Raza M.

description:
You know when a restaurant sucks?  When they cant even get ice water right.   

Davids bottom line-  Where da ice at yo?  I musta had 5 cups of tepid water.   Oh and the service is slow... Maybe all the ice melted on the way to our table.   I dont know.  I dont care.  I just know I wont be back unless the Thai womens bikini team happens to be there.  Foods ok maybe I'll do their delivery option.   I make a mean cup of ice water at home.
author: David L.

description:
If you like real Thai food, you won't like this restaurant. Our office used to order from here all the time, but now people gag when they hear "Koh Samui". 

The food is extremely greasy and though you order different dishes, everything somehow tastes the same...like Mc Donalds of "Thai" food. To make matters worse, the last piece of chicken satay that I had was pink in the middle -- couldn't even eat it. If I wanted to pay $50 for lunch, I'd rather spend the money on a decent restaurant that isn't trying to be something it's not. 

In my opinion, King of Thai is FAR better, more authentic, and cheaper than this place.
author: Monica C.

description:
Mmm- I got the pumpkin curry chicken for lunch takeout. Online ordering was so easy and I was able to pick it up immediately. The food was delicious. I wanted to save some for dinner but I couldn't resist finishing all of it. They also have a little lunch kiosk thing where you can pick what you want for $6.95. I will probably hit that up next time.

Edit: removing one star due to table service being consistently incredibly slow. Not a place to go if you want to keep lunch under an hour.
author: Jade S.

description: Very trendy for a Thai restaurant that sucks. I'm not trying to be mean but sometimes the truth is painful. Trendy, trendy, trendy, but the food is awful.
author: christopher c.

description:
This place was named after the island party in Thailand where the owners met + the fact that she is the Year of the Monkey.  

If I ever want to start my own "how-we-met" restaurant, this makes me think I had better re-evaluate the places I hang out to meet men. For example, "Las Vegas and the Dog" doesn't sound like a happening nightspot in San Francisco, now does it?  Entrees would be served Janney B. style, which means that delicious over-priced dishes would be presented to customers and right before they finished eating, we would rip the plates away and leave them wanting more.  My dating life is sadly conducted in similar fashion.

Koh Samui & the Monkey has a cozy, sexy feel.  The lighting is attractive.  The noise is loud, but not too loud - This is good thing if you don't want to hear every single word someone is saying, ie:  business lunch or date your mother set up with her best friend's gay "not out of the closet, yet" son.

Favorites:
Pumpkin Curry!
Side of Cucumber!
Bags of Gold!
Eggplant and Tofu! (given what it is...)
Chicken Pad Thai!

By closing time, my friends and I were the last ones here.  I'm not sure if this was because we were busy licking the plates clean, or because we were so cute & charming the waitstaff didn't want us to leave.  Probably the former.
author: Janney B.

description:
Koh Samui & the Monkey is just a few doors down from one of my clients, so we would stop in once a week for lunch. They have lunch specials [curry entrees with an appetizer and rice], as well as daily specials [some curry, some not]. 

The food is average/okay/edible and made fresh. Service is generally accommodating. 

One time, my colleague and I both ordered Thai Iced Teas. They came out at the same time, but looked completely different. We requested that hers be replaced, and they did so without hesitation. Of course, you'd think that they would notice when one of the two drinks they're carrying out looks like dirt...

It's also a little bizarre what happened over at their sister restaurant - something about closing and kicking staff out without explanation: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/12/26/FD05U08SL.DTL

And I did a bit of research for Adrienne G - no monkeys served here. In fact, in Lopburi, Thailand, there's a feast held FOR the monkeys each year [Lopburi Monkey Festival in late November - http://www.discoverythailand.com/Lop_Buri_Lopburi_Monkey_Festival.asp] - fruit, cucumbers, eggs, bananas - OH MY!

To avoid the crowd, 11 or even 11:30 seems to be early enough.
author: Tinna H.

description:
Wasn't impressed, a little grossed out by the noodles with vegetable and tofu plate. Vegetarian doesn't mean tons of bad cooking oil taste...

The drink was nice though, great happy hour price!
author: Yuchi C.

description: Larb, soft shell crab - generous, tasty, all first rate.  Recommended.
author: Walt B.

description:
I'm not very familiar with Thai food, but that just makes this review valuable in a different kind of way.  Think of this as Thai for Dummies and/or Unadventurous Eaters.

First and foremost, don't skip the Green Papaya Salad.  That was worth the trip alone.  Also, the Cashew Beef was very good.  One person in our party remarked that there wasn't really anything that differentiated its taste from Chinese food, and he was right.  However, it makes for a good transition dish for losers like me.  The Pumpkin Curry Chicken was interesting, but I didn't especially care for it.  Some other dishes I'm really looking forward to trying next time are the BBQ Chicken over even more papaya salad and the Red Curry Duck.

If I can eat there, anyone can.  Excellent variety, attentive service, and quality that's hard to beat for the price.  And who isn't at least a little intrigued by the name?
author: Adam W.

description:
Koh Samui & the Monkey -- what a posh little Thai joint! It's right up there with Osha as far as atmosphere goes...  and the food feels more upscale than your typical Thai hole in the wall. We just stopped in for a casual meal pre-fashion show, but I was pleasantly surprised at how date-ish it felt. Mew!

The pumpkin curry was served in the actual pumpkin, and had chunks of goodness floating throughout. The noodles with peanut sauce (though they sound boring) were actually fantastic, and mixed with lush greens. The mango salad was yummy and fresh, but suuuper spicy. A real kick in the pants, I tell you.

On our way out, we saw that everyone was chowing down on the same dish. Turns out they're "Bags of Gold," with minced shrimp and chicken in crispy rice paper sacks. Mental note to try those next time!
author: Nicole G.

description:
Along with my other "lunch hour" posts, this place pleases the palate for what it's worth.  The service is often quick and eager to please, especially for the lunch hour crowd.

The food is good - tasty and cheapish.  Mind you I don't come down on the weekend because I have to have it - we just don't have that type of relationship.  But on a Friday when it's sunny and I just have to get out - this place hits the spot.
author: Girls Named Cherise C.

description:
Everyone I work around raves about this place, but being a huge Thai food lover I would disagree. Each time I've gotten food from here, it has just been ok (good not great). Their vegie Tom Kha soup consisted of only mushrooms and not much else. Kind of a disappointment when craving this hot treat. Their Pad Thai was pretty good when ordering from the regular menu for our large party. However, when I went there today and got the 2 item combo to go in the lunch takeout section, it was bland and almost had an off flavor. The second item I ordered was the sweet basil chicken. It definitely was sweet, but the chicken seemed really dry. 
The only time I really enjoyed the food was when our office ordered a large catering order from them. Everything tasted delicious, and everyone really enjoyed the dishes. 
The inside of the restaurant is nice and it's really busy during lunch. Maybe I would enjoy it more if I was sitting there enjoying the ambience and friendly service?
author: Sonya D.

description:
Since moving away from the city, when I visit I find myself doing things I would never do while living there.  While visiting the boy's family this weekend we spent some time at their place in SOMA and ended up with takeout from Koh Samui & the Monkey.  Both spending time in SOMA and eating here count as things I'd never do on my own.

I thought the food was decent, but not particularly Thai.  Also, not top 100 restaurants in the city good.  I picked the pumpkin curry and I've had better in the city.  Hell, I've had better in my podunk little Sacramento suburb Thai spot.  But everything was spiced appropriately and the vegetables were all fresh and plentiful.  

I get the impression that part of the positive experience people have here is the atmosphere, but I don't know that I was blown away by the food so much that I'd go back just to sit in their pretty dining room to eat it.
author: Katie S.

description:
Brought my mother here and the food quality was not worth the amount I paid.  
We were done with our dinner and wanted to pack it to go and they never did it.  So then I went to the back to ask the manager where our food was, I saw it next to the garbage can ready to be thrown away.  Then the manager goes there and packs it up right there literally next to the trash can. 
When they brought out the birthday cake the waitress distributed our desert plates by throwing them on the table in front of us.  
Then when they boxed the left over cake the waitress chose the smallest box and jammed it in there.     
My mother was very disappointed and I'm not one to complain or make a scene.  But I spoke to the manager in private and told her how our experience was.  She apologized, but I would never go back there again.
author: Sylvia K.

description: This place is great ! I recommend everyone visit this place if you love Thai or you are new to SF. The hostess was so kind to introduce herself as soon as we walked in making the experience much more personable . Ashley then seated us at the bar  giving us a heads up that it was happy hour! Nice!!! The drinks are amazing! The bartender Max always does his best at making the drinks so good! I have been to so many bars and I have never got the level of service that I got from Max . This place is head and shoulders above any Thai place in San Francisco  . 5 stars
author: Enrique R.

description:
I've eaten at the main restaurant twice for lunch and once for dinner.  Each time I had an excellent experience and found everything both spicy (which I love) AND flavorful.  Their tofu and vegatable dishes are especially pleasing since I prefer to eat vegetarian at least half the time.

The real gem for me though is their "Monkey To-Go" takeout that operates from 11:30-2pm on weekdays only.  Lunch portion of two items and rice for under $8, and the dishes are always tasty, fresh, and satisfying.  Fantastic - I take advantage of it several times a week.
author: Justin W.

description:
Anyplace that can gracefully take on a party of 11 including two rambunctious kidlettes, some senior citizens, and a couple of picky-eater-wine-snobs automatically gets two stars to start with. Great food suggestions, fast service, adroit birthday present juggling, skilled cake cutting and serving (we brought our own from Miette, which they took care of for us in the kitchen, no problem), and kid entertaining (who knew those little plastic drink moneys could entertain a 5-year old just as effectively as a 21-year old at Bamboo Hut?!). And they did it all without looking as if we were trying their patience, which I am quite certain we were. 

It was my first time here and, though I am not a Thai food expert, was very impressed by the choices of curries, veggie dishes, and yummy appetizers. We shared a few of the sampler plates and I devoured my fresh Emperor Curry (scallops, shrimp, and eggplant served in a young coconut) as well as a good half of Will T.'s special sea bass of the day. I was eyes-rolling-back-in-my-head happy, YUM. 

The red and gold candle-lit decor is really sumptuous and they manage to arrange the space so each table feels private. I'm afraid I'm in danger of having cravings for this place!
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Hey lady, nice monkey!

Had a great meal here, fast and friendly service, nice presentations and great flavors. I had enough money left over to scoot over to Bacar for an after dinner cheese tray and wine flight! 

San Francisco ROCKS 'da monkey!
author: JayChan H.

description: First time I've eaten Koh Samui and the Money's food and they didn't disappoint.  Ordered 4 dishes at 7:32pm and their deliver driver was ringing our doorbell at 7:50pm.  We were absolutely starved so you imagine how giddy we were to be eating so much sooner than we thought.  Highly recommend the Basil Gai.  Delicious!  Will definitely be ordering from them again!
author: Ash S.

description:
Mostly I enjoyed the attention to detail put into the decor and service.  The seafood plate I tried was high quality and fresh, but just OK as far as seasoning.  The Thai style samosas were delicious, but the sauce was buried under a pile of cucumbers for some reason.  

I plan to return and try more dishes.  The bar looks fun too.  Maybe I'll just work through the list of vodka cocktails.
author: Jared L.

description: We had dinner here last NYE and they had a set menu. We ended up ordering all vegetarian courses and they discounted our bill and we got to pick out different entrees from the menu. Food was very good and service was awesome. The restaurant had very nice decor and ambiance too, nice place to bring a date.
author: Christian C.

description:
On the good side...

-Environment is very clean and well decorated, but not too cheesy.
-Lunch is nice; good food for a good price.
-Really delicious seabass.

Not so good..

-Service is never attentive for me. Some may like that, but when you're trying to get the check to go back to the office, time is an issue.
-The vegetables I get in curries always seem to be undercooked.
-Dinner is a bit pricey.

Overall though, this is a decent choice. I still go for lunch every so often.
author: Ryan V.

description:
I give this restaurant a sold 3 stars. This Thai restaurant has pretty solid food. I wouldn't say its the best Thai I've ever had, but for a quick bite at lunch it's not bad. Speaking of lunch, during the week you'd best go before 12:15pm when the lunch crowds converge. Otherwise you will be waiting for 20+ minutes for a table.

They don't make their Thai tea themselves, which I thought was a little strange for a Thai restaurant. As a result they dont always have hot Thai tea. 

So eh... Not bad, I'll go back one day.
author: Anisha W.

description: This is my local restaurant. I had guests coming to town from Europe and due to the Giants game coinciding with their arrival from the airport we were late for our Saturday night booking. I called the restaurant to let them know we'd be late, maybe 15 minutes but wasn't sure (not knowing how long it would take them to get through the traffic). The lady who took my call said 'no problem' 'it's fine' 'whenever'.  It turned out that my friends were 30 minutes late getting to my house & we had to walk 4 blocks to the restaurant.  When we arrived the door was locked however we could see tables still occupied through the window.  I knocked on the door & no one answered so then I called them and the person immediately recognised me as the person who had the booking and told me it 'too late' now 'we are closed'.  She refused to open the door to speak with me even though I was standing right outside. I was shocked that they behaved in this way and even though I could understand deciding to close the early (earlier than listed operating hours), refusing to talk to me face to face and not calling to let me know they be closing early was disappointing to say the least.  I won't be going back.  It's such a shame as use to love going there.
author: Helen F.

description:
I went here a while back for a friend's going away party, and I still remember what I ordered and that it was delicious. That is truly a testament to how good this place really was. Not only that, but they reserved 4 tables for our party of about 40 people. That is a hefty order to fill. This place is cute, it doesn't look huge from the outside, but can seat many. The lighting was that normal dim  and classy thing, thankfully whenever I go to the city I am always dressed for the part.

We ordered the fresh spring rolls, corn patties, and satay to start and I believe we had the mango salad. What I know I ordered was the Sea Bass clay pot. It was so delicious. I still remember how amazing it tasted and how the fish was cooked to divine perfection. Sections of the fish easily separated off and the flavor was magnificent. We also had a duck curry and some other noodle dish that I can't remember. Those were good too. 

I also remember that the men's bathroom was clogged and as we waited for the women's room we were chatting with random patrons who were also waiting for the single stall men's room, and a little appalled that they had to actually wait for a men's room. Because seriously, it is unheard of that men actually have to wait to pee.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I'm a picky eater. I don't like seafood, I don't like food I can't pronounce, and I usually don't like more than two flavors competing for my attention at once.  So, getting me to try ethnic food is usually an exercise in futility.  But, you know, I'm a pretty good boyfriend and at some point you have to give in to try new things (even if they're old things that everyone else has been doing).

Enter Koh Samui & the Monkey.  

First let me say that I still can never remember the name of this place.  To me, it's either the "Thai Restaurant", or the "Monkey Thai Place", or more recently "Kofi Annan & The Monkey" (which sounds like a great children's show).  Apparently there's another Thai restaurant in the area called Citizen Thai & The Monkey, which I think means either a) they're owned by the same people b) adding "the Monkey" to your name means good luck in Thailand, or c) there's a lawsuit on it's way.

The decor of the restaurant is authentic looking (at least from what I remember in my dreams of Thailand) and serene (minus the prerequisite flat screen TV at the bar).  It feels a bit crowded at times and your ass will hurt from their chairs if you're there too long, but overall the dining experience is a pleasant one.  The drinks are pretty strong and you get a nice, plastic monkey with most of them that you can play with while you wait for your date to return from the bathroom.  

For dinner I went with the American staple of getting Pad Thai along with their Pumpkin Soup.  The soup was up first and I have to say I was a little disappointed by it.  I'm a HUGE pumpkin fan and will generally eat anything made from it, but this soup was perhaps a little too authentic for me.  Not that I was expecting a mashed up pumpkin pie served in a Green Goblin pumpkin bomb bowl (but, yeah, how cool would THAT be?), but it left me wanting something a bit sweeter.  

The Pad Thai, though, was excellent!  A generous serving and just as good in leftover form the next day.  I have since ordered carryout from here and found the quality of the food to be great.  I'm not adventurous enough to try most of their dishes, but if you like Thai food you should definitely check this place out.

Craig D. & The Monkey
author: Craig D.

description: Great lunchtime spot. Enjoyed the curries. The restaurant looks nice, but I've never sat down to eat.
author: David E.

description:
I was excited because it's located right by our 4th & Brannan location...I'd heard all the hype & was prepped for hopping on our shuttle to experience some true deliciousness...drumroll...and then reality hit...

HATE-TED IT!!!!  Can we say tourist/yuppie trap?!  To start it off, if's loud...HELLA loud...can't hear yourself think or your conversation loud...

I was HIGHLY disappointed with my meal; while the presentation was pretty, the price is excessive for the portions received & the flavoring is blah, at best.  I tried the imperial rolls; the lil house that they made from the 3 lil rolls was cute (that they cut up in halves...what, to make it look like more?!), but the rolls at TU LAN are WAY tastier.  For my meal, I tried the Noodles Peanut Sauce with Shrimp; how is it that I paid $10 for mediocre peanut sauce, wide noodles & 3 SHRIMP?!?!?!  Are you serious?!  Why am I still hungry?!?!?!  Had a thai iced tea to wash it all down...please help me understand how Korso's not only costs less for a larger serving, but tastes better?!  It's whatever...count me out, I won't be wasting my dough up in here.  If I want GOOD Thai, I'll just go out of my way to Modern Thai on Polk!!!
author: Amoura B.

description:
This place used to be my favorite Thai restaurant in San Franciso. And coming from a Thai person, that's a big deal! But recently I went here for lunch and had the most disappointing experience.

First of all, I ordered the Tom Kha Gai. It may out so thick that it was almost like yogurt! I couldn't take more than a sip. Then to make matters worse, they were so slow in bringing out my mango and sticky rice dessert that I had to cancel the order.

I'm never coming here again.
author: Jon C.

description:
Yum, YUm, YUM, YuuuuuuuuMMMM

In my effort to still try and get to know my work neighborhood better I depend on co-workers to get me out of the office, get some sunlight and remember why I am so lucky to work in SF!

I can't believe such great Thai food is less then a block from my  building. The decor is cute and comfortable, the price is more then right, and the food....well, AMAZING!

I highly recommend the prawns, chicken satay, and the spicy chicken basil with rice.  I can't wait for Jessie K. to come for lunch soon so I don't have to recommend the subway at the Cal Train station.
author: Alicia K.

description:
Named after one of my favorite islands in the world.

Tasty food, good service, and cool ambiance.

Bonus: owner is USF alumni.
author: Francis M.

description:
Ok, it has the word Monkey in it. Of course I like it already.

i had lunch here a long time ago and it wasn't that bad, but I wasn't super impressed. The thai iced was dee-lish though.

The papaya salad was interesting and appetizing. The apps weren't bad and the noodles were ok, but didn't blow me out of my chair. The curries smelled amazing though.

It's decent if you're in the area, but it wouldn't be first on my list to hit back.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I've eaten here many times and I've only been disappointed once (one dish was very oily - the spicy chili rice noodles).  They are consistent, even if they do get your order wrong every once in awhile (we would order take out usually).  For what it's worth, one of my colleagues was from Thailand and she liked this place.

I also enjoyed dining at the actual restaurant as the decor is charming and it has an upscale feel.  The servers are attired in traditional Thai clothing (and they change outfits often) and the dining room is filled with interesting Thai art objects.  The dishes are plated so prettily.

My favorite lunch special is the pumpkin curry but I've enjoyed all their curry dishes.  You can also substitute brown rice.  You can ask them to make your dish spicier too (it still isn't very spicy, but I appreciate how accommodating they are).  I also recommend the tender and flavorful BBQ chicken salad that comes with a wonderful, fresh and tangy green papaya salad.  And I like the won ton noodle soup and lemongrass tofu.
author: Lolia S.

description:
This place could easily have 4 stars, maybe even 5. But wow is it overpriced! Unbelievable how much they can charge for rice, meat and fruit. However, the food is really delicious...the bbq chicken, the papaya salad, the fried rice. Man, I think the whole menu is probably amazing, though I will never know because trying every dish on the menu would lead me to the poorhouse for sure. Dinner prices at lunchtime? Boo!
Also, they have the most rude employees ever, I don't know if it's the stress of serving crazy whitey all day or what, but most Asian restaurants have those sweet, soft spoken servers that seem to sincerely want you to be happy. And I am happier at those, more economical lunch spots!
author: Colleen B.

description: Ugh tried this place again and the food was just ok, but what was really off-putting was the fact that they charge you $2.50 for white Jasmine rice!
author: Melissa W.

description:
This place is really clean and the chairs are REALLY heavy.  It's a pretty fun place to go to with friends.  The lunch specials are really good and there is a good variety.  I look forward to eating here.

The last time I was there though, it seemed like the people who work there didn't understand what I was talking about.  I ordered Spring Rolls there and they never came out, so I told a waiter and a waitress about it.. and both of them said "ok.", smiled, and walked away.  My friend and I were kind of confused because we weren't sure what that meant.  Then finally another waitress came to explain that they took my order to the wrong table.. and people at that table just ate my spring rolls... then she brought me some to go (which was sweet of her) ... but when I opened them at home.. she packed me imperial rolls and not spring rolls.  That's okay.... at least she was nice about it and I'm not allergic to anything.
author: Suzanne S.

description: Very fresh and tasty food, nicely presented. Good service, nice ambiance.
author: Pax G.

description:
Had the Pumpkin Curry like everyone said. It was delicious!! I wanted a thai place that delivered near my office. It didn't disappoint. The rest of the office had the Chicken with Red Curry and Vegetables, Pad Thai, and the vegetarian version of the Red Curry. 
 It was a hit all around! Definitely would order again. 
Cons- A little bit on the pricier side, but what do you expect in SOMA?!?
Pros-Delivery was prompt. Utilized the online ordering system and it was great! Delivery man was polite and quite happy for a delivery man?!?
author: V. P.

description: If you like Thai food, this is probably as good as it gets. I had the Rice Noodles with a coconut sauce made exrta spicy. If you are into spice, it wasn't too spicy. The Thai tea was good and they have Chima on tap :)
author: Shahram L.

description: I think the ambiance and feel of this place is fun and hip. i would definitely take my out of town friends here for the scene.. but, on a regular weekend night, I wouldn't frequent this place unless it was for a special occasion.  food is good but i've had thai food that is way more authentic, flavorful, and cheap (shout-out to marnee thai!).  it's been awhile since i've been here but the only thing i remember standing out is the pumpkin curry. i got a bloomspot coupon for this place some time ago so i'll be back again to do another review i'm sure :)
author: Joanna M.

description:
Happy hour update:
Happy hour is the best value in the area: $2 beers, $3 happy hour cocktails, $3-4 munchies. The drinks are pretty small as are the munchies, but still good for the price. If you can, try to talk the bartender into using good tequila for the $3 margarita. Best part is that happy hour lasts till 7 instead of the standard 6:30. 

Orginial lunch review:
Seems to be the only Thai place in the area, and when I walked in, I was impressed. However, I was quickly frustrated by the awkward heavy chairs, and the pricey lunch menu.

But then I got the fresh roll appetizer and was really impressed. Fresh rolls are great in theory but rarely live up to my expectations. These did. The duck curry was standard. The duck meat was good, but there was too much fat and skin to pick through. But then the Pad Thai showed up, and I was appalled. It was tomatoey and completely unacceptable. The only reason this place gets three stars and not two is that I loved the fresh rolls.
author: Lauren H.

description: The food was ok. We went on a weekday, there was only one server with quite some tables. The lady server has no smile at all! I walked in and smiled to her, and she just look away. Over price. Nice decoration. could be better
author: Cyrus T.

description:
It should be NO star really.

Twice now, we have received v bad service. We have had to chase the waiters to order, where is my drink?, can we pay?

We called up in advance to ask about MSG in their food and the answer was that the stir-frys can be made without MSG but not the curries as they are pre-cooked.

When we made the order, we specifically told the waiter that no MSG should be put on the food, however today the ones that are sensitive to MSG are not feeling well - you make up your mind, I already have.

Last time, a friend with a peanut allergy was with us and again we made sure that the waiter was told about this. What got severed? Peanuts sprinkled on top of his food.

This place used to be good, not anymore.

UPDATE: I have been charged twice for this visit AND the amount was too high.
author: Sofia K.

description:
Another visit to a new restaurant in SOMA, we chose to try Koh Samiu & the Monkey. An elegant thai restaurant with elegantly priced dishes puts nicely a fine thai dining experience. I really enjoyed their sample appetizer for 3, a combination of eggrolls, springrolls, lettuce wraps, and chicken skewers with several different dipping sauces. Each plate we ordered was very good. Unlike other thai dishes, sometimes the curry flavor can be too bland or too salty, but not here, it was just right.
Their fun and unique cocktail names drove me to order a "Thai Kiss," a kettle vodka-orange-sparkling wine drink with two little monkeys hanging from the straw. It was all fulfilling and pleasant for a Friday night.
author: Oanh N.

description:
We had a star discussion all the way home.  I settled on 4.  Our tab was 60 bucks for appetizers, soup, 2 main courses and 2 glasses of wine.  I call that damn affordable.   So this is a review from the perspective of "I ate and my wallet doesn't hurt."

The food was good.  We had fried corn ball thingys, tom ka gai soup, basil chicken and BBQ chicken (YUM!).  All the dishes were good and pretty much what I expected.  The soup came as a serving for one??  That was odd.  I have never been to a Thai place and received a cup of soup.  Its always a big ass bowl that can be shared.

The space is nice enough too.  The decor is kinda modern crammed into an old building with lots of Asian stuff tossed in.  It was comfortable.  They did have really pretty plates, white linens, real chop sticks and cloth napkins.  That goes far with me.  As did the big bowl of flowers floating in water at the door.

The service was interesting though.  We were kind of left sitting and reading the wine list for a long long time.  It was a good wine list, but we wanted to drink it not read about it.  When someone did approach us she asked if we are ready, we said yes.  She left.  What??  We are ready!  She came back a bit later and said "OK I get your waitress."  Then a few minutes later a boy came to take our order.  Was this an FTM or MTF?  I'm confused.  Anyway our order was taken and things were smooth from then on.
author: Ian M.

description:
Koh Samui & The Monkey is one of our frequently visited restaurants in SOMA.  I would recommend the Thai basil chicken stir fry with green/red bell peppers, onions, green beans and chilli sauce.  It's only $10 plus $3 for brown rice.   Service could be a bit spotty at times, but I would say that Koh Samui is still decent place for good Thai cuisine.  

P.S. their imported chairs are really heavy, so there's no chance of them losing any of their chairs unless you get a gang of body builders in.
author: TK W.

description: I've got about a 100:1 ratio of times I've eaten here for lunch (100) versus times I've eaten here for dinner (1). All 101 times were wonderful. The food is highly predictable and for the $13.50 quick-set lunch you get a reasonably complete lunch complete with a thai iced tea, thai iced coffee or thai beer. Gets busy, go early. I've never tried the to-go.
author: Brandon P.

description:
My family came here for dinner on a Sunday night and I'd have to say that the service was just terribly embarassing.  Like they weren't ready to be open that night.  First, we arrived on time for our 6:30 reservation and the hostess stood back to us and on the phone for a good 5+ minutes.  How rude!

When we're finally seated, service was uber-slow and unattentive.  The worst was when we tried to pay and after 15 minutes of trying to flag someone down with our credit card, we finally gave up and scrounged up some cash instead.  

On top of the bad service, the food was only mediocre.  The royal curry (veggie green curry) was bland and not so delicious.  The spicy tofu was ok, but not really the shining beacon needed to pull this restaurant up.
author: Olivia T.

description:
Fantastic Thai food. Perfect spot for a special occasion. Won't break the bank. Fast and friendly. Clean and enchanting, especially the buddah sculpture and photos in the WC. 

Getting here is pretty simple too. 

An SF FAVE.
author: Michelle S.

description:
The Thai place with a funny name. I've had 2 parties here (bachelorette & my birthday) & they both went well. People remember the name, but the location can be a bit difficult to find.

The waiters have always been nice to our large parties & have brought extra drinks or dessert on the house for special occasions. They didn't seem to mind when my friends were all covered in typical bachelorette party penis paraphernalia, they even joined in some photos!

The food is not amazing, but it's damn good! Standard Thai food & expensive fancy drinks. The decor of the place is nice, which is one of the reasons I have parties here. They have funny lost animal posters in the bathroom & they don't want you to steal them! 

The downside is it can take awhile to get a drink & if you order something not on the drink menu, they might come ask you "what was in it again?" 4 times or so. Oh well, I'm not a big drinker, so I'll go back!
author: Melisser E.

description: The food is not horrible - it's actually pretty decent.  But with so many delicious thai food restaurants to choose from in the bay area, this would definitely not be on the top of my list.  Aside from mediocre food it's overpriced and the portions are so small.  Like really small and they seem to get smaller and smaller every time I go.  I hadn't been there in a while but I was in the area running a lunchtime work errand so I stopped in to get the two item "to-go" lunch.  The person behind the counter literally put 3 bite sized pieces of chicken on my rice and when I asked for a little more she rolled her eyes at me (I am not kidding) and put one more tiny piece of chicken on my plate.  I don't eat a lot but this was ridiculous.  I wish I had taken a picture.  In my opinion ozone, which is just two blocks away is a much better option for a to-go lunch.  The food is better, the portion is bigger, and it's only 6 bucks.  I would give this place one star based on how aggravated I was that I was treated so rudely but I feel as though I should be fair...and since their food tastes fine I'll give it two.  But I won't be going back, especially for the to-go lunch unless I'm on some crazy diet where I'm trying to only eat a few tiny bites for my meal!
author: Annalise V.

description: Besides my rating being based on the convenience of this place being near the train station, this place is just really good.  First of all, they serve coconut rice, which is always a win for the restaurant.  I didn't actually try much, but the vegetarian panang curry was really tasty.  I also tried the Mieng Kum, since it seemed a little different from the traditional appetizers.  It was basically a spinach wrap with peanuts, roasted coconut, fresh lime, ginger, onion, fresh chopped Thai chili peppers, and a sauce.  It was super delicious.  I'd definitely get both again, and actually hope to go in a larger group so I can try even more off the menu.. and maybe save room for dessert!
author: Rachana S.

description:
Here are the positives you can expect from Koh Samui - Great service, easy to get reservations, great decor, good for groups or a one on one dinner, great service, good food. While I've heard mixed reviews about the food, my experience there has always been positive. That said, I'm a creature of habit and tend to stick to the same dishes. On that note, I would highly recommend ordering the basil chicken and the Tom Yum Soup. 

I consider this a great local hangout. Only notable negative is that their take out isn't very good. And for someone can't cook but can order like nobody's business, this came as a blow. Nonetheless, Koh Samui is solid. Definitely worth checking out.
author: Shreya C.

description:
You can't really find a restaurant closer to my office than Koh Samui and the Monkey unless you want to count Zeke's.  That being said I guess that I'll be eating here plenty as I am lazy and prone to convenience.

Lucky for me the food here is above average in every way. It is always fresh hot and flavorful with a few twists that make this place not a throw away 'Thai place' that can be interchanged throughout the city (think of all the places in the TL).  The lunch specials are cheap and huge with the only disappointment being the imperial rolls... they are WAY too greasy and small. I like the imperial Rolls at Tu Lan so that is what I compare these too.

All this praise and 3 stars you say?  Yes.  When I come here I come alone and want to sit at the bar to take up as little space as I can.  Only problem is that the bar seating here is like torture for me.  The seat is a piece of plywood that is about 13"x13" and FLAT... It takes all my concentration to not slide off these things... forcing me to want to eat at a table for 2 by myself... I can't give a restaurant that makes me lonely 4 stars. Ain't gonna happen.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Eh, the food was ok.  I've had better.  The look of the place is very cute.  IT's warm and inviting.  Food presentation is well done also.  Very creative and cute.

The taste of the food was just ok, nothing memorable.  I tried the spicy pasta.  Basically spagetti in a spicy basil sauce.  I don't think I'll order this dish again.  It wasn't bad but it wasn't that great either.  The corn patties, the pumpkin curry, the tofu in basil sauce...all just ok.
author: C A.

description:
Yum!  I have been here twice now and I keep looking for excuses to be in inner SOMA just so I can eat here again.
The food is delicious.  This is no hole in the wall, usual-menu Thai fare.  This is the real deal for not much more than you pay at a hole in the wall place.
And the drink menu is awesome.

I recommend it for a night when you want something that makes you feel fancy, but not so fancy that you have to go broke.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I have to say that I like Koh Samui a lot. The price is a tiny bit on the expensive side but not that bad compared to a lot of other places in SF or SJ. The ambiance of the place is nice, not too noisy, not too packed in, and just enough interior decor touches to remind you that you're in a Thai restaurant.

The curry selection is pretty standard fare (red, yellow, green) though I like the fact that the coconut flavor in it is not overwhelming compared to some of other Thai places. The basil chicken is quite good (though you can't really go wrong with that at any Thai place) and so are the rice noodle dishes like pad kee mow though in my opinion it should be a bit spicier. The appetizer is what shines though but I won't spoil it for you guys, just go try it for yourself. 

All in all I would give this place a thumbs up. Of all the restaurants in the Soma, ballpark and Financial District area, this is the only one I frequent.
author: Gordon H.

description:
Pumpkin Curry = gift from the heavens above! I hail from LA where Thai food is plentiful and this still goes down as one of the best Thai restaurants I've ever been to.  The Volcano rice (I think that's what it's called is also nothing short of amazing).  

AMAZING FOOD in this amazing city!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
EDIT 6/18/07: And now I am receiving harassing messages through Yelp from the wait staff at Koh Samui.  Namely, Ricky S..  Thanks Koh Samui, for reminding me not to eat there ever again.  Ricky would probably put some bodily fluid in my food if I looked at him cross-eyed.
**********************
I believe in karma.  I believe that negative action has immediate consequence, and that it should.  Thus I feel impelled to write this review.

I used to love this place.  (Note the past tense.)  The food was fabulous, and the waitstaff, while less than spectacular, was at least mentally present.  I never had a dish there that was not at least great.

However.  Something has changed dramatically.  The waitstaff is now completely incompetent.  A co-worker ordered vegetarian Beef & Broccoli the last time I was there, and got Broccoli.  Only.  When he asked for the tofu it was brought cold.  Refrigerator cold.  And, the waitress would not look at anything but the walls and her note pad (upon which she insisted on writing every single word spoken, and got our orders wrong).  She also insisted on muttering at a barely audible level, except for when she would blink rapidly and exclaim, "What?!?!"

Today we decided to try again.  On the way there another band of co-workers asked where we were going, and warned us that  the day before they had gotten metal filings in there meals.  We kept on anyways.  Mistake.

The waitress was the same.  This time when asked for more water she dashed off and brought back warm water.  She got our drinks wrong, and they tried to bring us an appetizer we did not order.  They also put white rice with my meal, and the gal next to me, after we both asked for sticky rice.  When our pumpkin curries (my favorite dish) came back the waiter elbowed me out of the way while making a study of looking the other direction, and the sticky rice was dry, crumbly, and brittle.  Oh, and not sticky.

Another co-worker got green curry that wasn't.

And, they brought a water with things floating in it that looked strangely like sea monkeys.

They have spent money on a bunch of new tables for the bar area.  Metal tables... now I know where the fillings came from.

Goodbye monkey.  The pumpkin curry isn't that good anymore, and the staff is horrid.  I wish you joy of it.
author: Travis E.

description:
Here's me, sitting on my couch, writing this review, mouth agape. (I'm not sure exactly what mouth agape actually looks like, but I can only imagine it's exactly how I look right now).

I'm blown away by the negative reviews I've just read for this place. Perhaps I've just been lucky the half dozen times I've been here, or perhaps I'm just a shitty judge of what constitutes good Thai food, or I'm a lame country bumpkin (I'd actually rather not know the answer to that), but let me say it out loud so that both the people of Koh Samui and the monkeys that they love so much hear me - I LOVE THIS PLACE! (Full disclosure: I actually have no idea if there are monkeys in Koh Samui, and I think that the 'monkey' portion of the name is actually based on one of the owners being born in the year of the monkey, but please read on in ignorance of these heartfelt confessions).

The pumpkin curry makes me want to cuss in front of my grandmother without apologizing. I love it so much that for days after I eat it I have dreams of it's coconutty goodness and visions of the carved decorations on the green pumpkin in which it's served dance in my head. Spooned over the sticky jasmine rice it approaches the sublime feeling of kissing the girl you've been crushing on for months for the first time, or taking that first shower after you've been camping for a week. Love is not a strong enough word.

Add to that some very good and eclectic appetizers, an honorable selection of the traditional pad thai-ish-type selections, an impressive menu of 'house' drinks, and a very cool, very relaxed, SoMa-style ambience, and you have the makings of one of my favorite San Francisco destinations.

So, for what it's worth, this lucky, shitty judge of Thai food, bumpkin of a boy gives 5 stars to Koh Samui....but make sure to get the pumpkin curry. And call me first, cause I'm hungry and will meet you there.
author: Kevin K.

description:
We were the first diners to arrive at 5:00 to sample the happy hour. We were shown a table and had a ton of starters (half price during happy hour). We were presented with a full price bill since we hadn't asked to sit at the bar in the empty restaurant and the happy hour didn't apply to tables. What a terribly dishonest bait and switch. We were stunned. 
Also the calamari was very tough and heavily battered. Yuk.
They really took advantage of us.  I won't go again.
author: chuck r.

description:
Highly recommend:
-Appetizer platter (fresh spring rolls were just O-K tho. but the warm peanut sauce comes with it was delicious!) 
-Pad Thai with prawns
-Aromatic Pumpkin Curry with chicken 
-Firecracker dish 

Don't forget order a drink! It comes with a little cute plastic monkey cup clip! i love this place not only because it's one block away from where I live but also I enjoy so much the friendly service and cozy environment. Not to mention reasonable pricing! Love it!!
author: Penfan S.

description:
What a business model.  Take a regular cheapo neighborhood Thai place, upgrade the decor, add some fancy plates and a nice drink menu and then double the prices.  That's exactly what you get at Koh Samui & the Monkey, but, all the same, I still like it.  Its nice to eat pad thai out of a nice bowl every now and again.  Also, when you order drinks they hang these little multicolored plastic monkeys on the side of your glass.  A nice touch - especially when you then have the little plastic monkeys do a variety of cirque de solei stunts (maturely, of course).  

Bottom line: there's nothing wrong with a little sweet monkey lovin'.
author: Jason S.

description: I was impressed with this thai restaurant. They have great pumpkin curry and a cool drink called monkey island that is served in a real coconut, yum! It's not the best thai I have ever had, but it;s definitely worth going to. I'll be going back there again :-)
author: Marie Josephine B.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots for lunch near the office.  The service is great, even during busy lunch hours.  The dish I order most of the time is the Garlic Chicken with extra garlic.
