I love me some garlic and they definitely hook it up.  I have noticed that my dish isn't always the same every time.  Sometimes the portion is smaller than other times.  

I've had better Thai food but this place hits the spot when I'm in the mood while working in the SF office.  Especially with some sake on the side.
author: Flory T.

description: Great food as always...but service was pretty slow on a Wednesday night with not that many tables.  AND BRING BACK THE PUMPKINS FOR THE PUMPKIN CURRY!  Seriously...not sure why you got rid of the actual Pumpkin.  It was great presentation!  I always told people about this place and the pumpkin!
author: Justin R.

description: Mixed bag with one great dish (spicy basil tofu curry) and one mediocre (noodle dish with peanut sauce and tofu). Too much peanut sauce and it was starting to separate. Waitstaff was attentive, in contrast to some reviews I see here. I'd like more vegetarian options. The tea was decent though.
author: Jason A.

description:
Argh.  That about sums it up.   But if you want more detail, here it is....

So i live two blocks from KSM and have often ordered their chicken fried rice because it's pretty bad ass, cost about $9 and is an easy dinner pick up after my jiu jitsu class.  So today I went for my usual and was extra hungry so got the stuffed mushrooms.  My expectations were $8.95 for the fried rice just like I have paid 3 dozen other times and stuffed mushrooms (published on their website for $4).  

So by default every retaurant I eat at gets 5 stars by default.  For every fuck up, I take a star (just like episode of Seinfeld).

F*ck Up #1
They charge me $20 for the two items.  Well that doesn't add up.  $8.95 + $4 is only $13.  Not a big deal but I inquire anyhow.  Apparently the friend rice now is now $12 (33% increase) and the stuffed mushrooms are $6, not the $4 as advertised.  The hostess said that the prices just changed.  Technically, that's false advertisement, but ok I'll let that slide.  Shit, I have a restaurant too and I know prices are going up across the board and they need to survive.  I'm hungry.  $20.  No big deal.  Nonetheless, -1 star.

F*ck Up #2
So when I got there the hostess said they were packaging it up.  So I waited and waited and waited.  15 minutes passed.  Then the hostess informed me that they gave my meal to someone else and it would be another few minutes.  Grrrrrr.  I was understanding but still a little peeved and i'm pissy when hungry.  She was nice enough to order me a complimentary cocktail but all I could think about was my CHICKEN FRIED RICE!  Nonetheless, -1 star for not getting a simple pick up order right.

F*ck Up #3
So I got my food.  I get to my boy's place and ready to devour the food and there are peanuts in my fried rice.  I have been to every city in the asian continent and not one of them has ever put PEANUTS in my fried rice.  WTF?  Are you kidding me?  You mind as well put M&Ms in my fried rice!  This place has truly been bastardized.  No wonder there were no Asians eating up in there!  But that's fine.  I just patiently picked it out one by one and continued to chomp.  Nonetheless, -1 star for putting peanuts in a dish that should NEVER have peanuts.

F*ck Up #4
Stuffed mushrooms were basically mushrooms stuffed with some weak ass meat filling, wrapped in some dough and deep fried with the funnel cake batter.  $9 for 4 of these mofos?  But that's ok.  I was hungry and continued to scarf it down until i got to the last stuffed mushroom which was SOUR and uncooked.  As hungry as I was, I spit it out and that was the end of my meal and it was insult after insult after injury.  Minus 1 star for almost food poisoning me!

KSM is a great place if you have never had Thai food...ever.  But if you think that Pad Thai is the Egg Foo Young of Thai food, then go somewhere else to get better tasting, more affordable, non-bastardized Thai Food.

To that end....don't f*ck with my chicken fried rice!  Word.
author: Caesar C.

description:
Is it bad that my favorite part is the bathroom, which is covered in framed flyers about lost dogs and cats?  Because it is.

The room reminds me of the random warehouses the contestants on Top Chef are supposed to turn into fancy restaurants with a budget $5000 to spend at Pier 1 (read: it's a big room with a lot of tacky crap in it).  At first I thought it was pretty... but then after being there for 10 minutes I changed my mind.  

The food is very tasty... but the portions are a little skimpy, especially considering they price things above comparable spots, including Osha's 2nd street location.  I always spend more than I want and am usually not terribly full when I leave.  The service is perfectly good, the menu offers a few items that aren't ubiquitous Thai fare (which is fun), but this monkey has not gone to heaven.
author: Laura F.

description: Great food with excellent staff and unique interiors - Koh Samui is definitely not a place to miss. Best person in the restaurant was - Beer who was not only polite and humble but very creative. She prepared a delicious orange cake which was not very sweet. Perfect compliment to green tea. Would love to go back and try her other creations next time.
author: Devang S.

description:
It's a great place to go to. The service is good and that goes for the food.  It think the prices are a little on the higher side $$$ instead of $$.

Great ambience., try getting a seated on the front window. It's enjoyable.
Another interesting thing is that they cater for vegetarians by substituting soy sauce for fish sauce.
author: Ram S.

description:
Out of curiosity, I did a Yelp search to find out if ANY Thai restaurant in SF had a five star rating.  None.  Three have 4.5 stars.  And then a bazillion have 4 stars.

This is the problem when it comes to Thai food: it is really hard to mess it up.  Thai food tends to be both budget and vegetarian friendly, and so generally everyone wins.  Who doesn't love Thai Iced Tea?

The dilemma then becomes how do you differentiate between Thai restaurants in SF?  Sure, there's the ever important how far is it from your house factor, and the do they have unlimited supplies of Siracha (rooster) sauce factor, or do they have anything other than Geyser Peak wine factor.  But really, when it comes down to it, they are testament to that especially San Francisco of problems: they are all so good.

However, for me, none stands out above the crowd more than Koh Samui and the Monkey.  Here's why:

1) Atmosphere: at Koh Samui, they've taken SOMA warehouse/office building and turned it into a lush, bubbling fountain, Giant Buddha kind of place, but without being tacky.  The decor doesn't overwhelm nor underwhelm: it just fits.  The end result is when you go to Koh Samui, you feel like you're doing something a little special, but without paying "special" prices.

2) Presentation: The Fresh Spring Rolls (with shrimp, mint leaf and noodle) come out in a little dish that reminds you of a boat, with an umbrella that suggests a long lazy float down a river.  The pumpkin curry (chicken with red curry sauce served in pumpkin) is served in an actual green pumpkin.  Bags of Gold (minced chicken, shrimps wrapped in rice paper sacks) look, indeed, like bags of gold.  Even the dish I get most often, the "Tofu with peanut sauce topped with crispy basil" looks like someone thought about where they would ladle the sauce, not the standard mashup of ingredients you find elsewhere.

Wine List: A Pinot Noir from Central Otago. A Spanish Tempranillo. A lovely Chilean Reisling.  These are not your average Thai restaurant wines.

Food: I think about the Tofu with peanut sauce when I am away.  Plus a plethora of rice choices: white, brown, jasmine or COCONUT!

It is these small things that really set Koh Samui apart from all the other wonderful, but predictable, Thai places in the City.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I have three words for you: BAGS OF GOLD.

This is a great spot for a group dinner. Inexpensive share plates, but none of that small plates crap. You got a few apps, everyone can pick an entree and let the fun begin. It's a little hectic in the beginning with a group, but as long as you take one minute to get the group on the same page, then you're golden. Speaking of golden, get the bags of gold. Since we ordered almost everything on the menu, of note is the cashew chicken, the duck dish, and red curry with chicken. 

Don't drink too much and have one of the members of the group tell the waiter it's your birthday. They dim the lights in the entire restaurant and sing for you. Semi-embarrassing for me, but kinda more embarrassing for the person who told the waiter it was my bday. Who does that?

Go go, have fun!
author: Defne A.

description:
My friends and I were actually hoping to try some chicken and waffles at Farmer Brown and the Little Skillet but ran here once we saw the line...

First of all, parking is a PAIN during lunch hour on a weekday.  That's what the -1 star is for... Actually, let me rephrase that. There is ample street and lot parking... $12 flat rate for the lot (I don't remember the hourly rate but I think it was something ridiculous) or meters that only give you 5 minutes per quarter. There goes my lunch money!

The restaurant itself is cute.  Good ambience. The waiters are friendly and helpful and didn't make us wait an hour. 

The food was yummm.  They have lunch specials too, which were about 13 to 15 dollars for an entree and an appetizer.  Not cheap, but not over the top.  I would definitely come back again... but prob not for lunch, just because it's nowhere close to where I work and I wouldn't want to deal with parking again.
author: Celia L.

description:
I'll be the first to admit that I am not aconnoisseur of Thai food given that my only previous Thai dining experience was "King of Thai" and "Thai Stick".  However, I have really enjoyed the food at Koh Samui each time I've eaten there.

I usually opt for the lunch special (Imperial rolls, Satay Chicken, and Beef with Panang Curry over rice), the Pad Thai or the Pad Kee Mao.  Either way, these tasty plates have left me content as I make my way back to the office.  Throw in that I'm a sucker for Thai iced tea and you can understand why I have a hard time turning down an invitation to Koh Samui.
author: Drew W.

description:
This place is just a block from our house and we got a Bloomspot deal for $20 for $40 so thought we'd finally try it out. I already sort of had a bad taste in my mouth about the place as I had bought a Groupon deal for this place back in the summer when we were looking to move to SF and specifically looking at places in this area. Unfortunately it took us until May to find the right place so as the expiration date approached for the voucher to be used by, I called them to see if it could be extended. They were rather rude about it and said no. I understand they can't make exceptions but for someone who lives a block from this place and would potentially be back over and over if it had been a good experience, it's too bad they couldn't help.

So anyway, gave them one more chance and while it was okay, I really wasn't impressed. The service and the food was a bit slow, we ordered 2 apps and they took a while, coming out at separate times, then still a wait for our mains. i was disappointed by the apps, while they tasted okay, they looked like they were out of a box, everything was perfectly uniform that it didn't look homemade at all.

The curry that arrived in a pumpkin or squash was pretty good - I asked for it spicy and it had a nice kick, but wasn't too much. I don't blame them, typically at these places they don't spice it up as much as I like. It took us a while to flag a waiter down to bring us some of the hot chili sauce. My husband was happy with his pad thai.

So will I be back, unlikely, but maybe eventually. There are a few other Thai places in the neighborhood I'll give a try.
author: Lauren M.

description:
my friends and i came here for the happy hour and it is quite the bargain. beers are only $2.50 and food is less than $5. portions are not smaller for the happy price so coming here during that time is the perfect bang for your buck.

i ordered a pad thai and some calamari. the padthai wasnt bad, it had a lot of chicken and tofu. the calamari was not your average plate of calamari full of legs and bodies but just 6-7 pieces of the calamari body (whatever its called).  that was different but it was not bad. i suggest getting the spring rolls instead.
author: edward k.

description: My days working near The Monkey are numbered, so it's time to reflect on these last few years... there were good times, there were decent times, and there were times when I couldn't imagine stepping foot in this damn place again.  All in all, it served its purpose quite well in this food-starved SOMA pocket.  Here's to The Monkey.
author: Laurence W.

description: I came here on a Sunday at 5p so it was empty. We ordered the rice beggar's purse, pumpkin curry, chicken with wide rice noodles, and a seabass green curry. Everything was really good with a lot of the typical Thai flavors. Their Monkey in Paris cocktail was really good as well. Our server was attentive and friendly, especially since we were practically the only ones there. It's pricier than your typical Thai restaurant, but it's in SoMa. The interior had nice Thai paintings/statues and the space was very bright and airy. Hey, someone's gotta pay for the rent and decorations...
author: Freckles H.

description: Great food, awesome service, good location. Always a good place for a drink or food before a Giants game or anytime. Been coming here for a couple years already now and have never been disappointed, feel free to go and check it out for yourself. Pumpkin curry is always delicious.
author: Carlos V.

description:
The place feels a bit cheesy, and the service is overeager (which is far better than inattentive).

But the pad thai (w/ seafood) was some of the best I've had.  Amazingly flavorful and not as monotonous as that dish often can be.

The portions are a bit small, but I prefer that.
author: Hans G.

description:
Really average Thai food for way too much money--the food here isn't really distinctively delicious in any way.  They do serve fun and tasty cocktails made with fresh sweet and sour (the Lemongrass gimlet was tart and sweet, there was another sugary cocktail with raspberry and mint, the name of which currently escapes me) and the decor is nice, especially given that in most Thai restaurants the ambiance is solely comprised of fluorescent lighting and vinyl chairs.  I will say, having traveled in Thailand, the service is rather "authentic"--that is, really bad.  But, come on now.  If you're going to charge "American" prices for Thai food, pick up the pace, would ya?  

One extra star for serving my favorite Thai street food--mieng kum (fried coconut flakes, ground peanuts, chili, and a slice of lime or lemon served on a spinach leaf).  Yum.  Otherwise, though, a rather underwhelming experience.
author: vicarious c.

description:
This place opened about five years ago when I worked nearby. I quit soon before or after (like I remember five years ago that well), and never made it.

Now I'm back in the hood, and went here today to a pleasant surprise.

It wasn't too packed when we got there shortly after noon, but the food took a bit to get to us. No complaints here, though. One of us had to get back, and seemed put off. Evs.

The spring rolls were spot-on tastewise, but a tad poorly wrapped. Not white-guy levels, but not expert Asian, either.

I got spicy basil chicken, and it was delicious. The spices could've been a touch more intense, and I prefer Thai restaurants who leave the spices on the table in a lazy suzette. Again, evs.

One of my party had pumpkin curry with chicken. Pumpkin curry has to be my favorite new dish, in any cuisine. Koh Samui's was delicious.

I tasted another friend's peanut sauce (hello, Thai staple), and it was really good, too.

Not too pricey, solid cuisine, not bad wait, decent location. Altogether a nice place I'm glad to go back to.
author: Jeff H.

description:
I think the food here is just a tad overpriced.  I didn't realize it was the same company as Citizen Thai until I saw the grocery bag.  Perhaps it is a little too trendy for my style.

Even so, they do have some interesting flavors.  I had the BBQ grilled chicken and it was tasty.  The papaya salad is also good in this hot weather.

Parking is impossible.  We did a take-out order today and there was a Giants game starting soon.  Omg.
author: Dong T.

description:
Great food, fine service, and the prices are not bad for the quality and presentation of the food in that nice a setting.

A suggestion:  do what we did, go with a group of four or more (there were five of  us) and order lots of different things.  Yeah, the pumpkin curry is to die for, but there is lots of other good stuff too.  I particularly liked the sirloin in green curry, myself.  

Service was attentive but not intrusive.   I want to go back and check out the interesting looking drinks, as well -- I was Designated Driver last night, so that had to wait.

A fun place!
author: Ruth A.

description:
So, I just moved here from Boston, and let me tell you, it's a different WORLD. I think my rating system needs to be revised for all things Boston, because I have been in food heaven since I got here. Anyway, about this place:

FOOD: Oh so yummy. We started out with the Veggie Samosas and they were delicious. Perfect amount for 2 people. Then I got the pumpkin curry (with tofu), and it was sooooooo good. Plus, how can you go wrong with any dish that is actually served in a pumpkin? It was very easy to be vegetarian here, they let you substitute tofu in for just about anything. And, it's well done tofu, not some soggy lifeless mess. 

FUN DRINKS- YES! There are many. And hellllooooo I can have a flight of wine. A FLIGHT of WINE. Oh, what a good idea. Booze, booze, and wine to go with it. Very niiicee.

Atmosphere: Lots of cool stuff to look at. For a somewhat small space, they've made it very interesting and authentic-looking (ahem, not that I've ever been to Thailand. But, it looks like it might be authentic-ish.....anyway, it's a fun atmosphere, trust me). 

I shall return!

An update: We have returned, many a time. My go-to, must-try veggie item: The Pumpkin Curry with Tofu. I love how you can substitute tofu for just about anything on their menu. Makes it so easy to be veggie. Also very easy to order out, good for delivery or pick-up.
author: Kristen L.

description:
Our mission was to check out Limn's showroom - first we needed sustenance.  KS&TM was close by and seemed generally liked, but ....

Thai restaurants.  So often the food is a disappointment.  But this cuisine, when in the right hands...!   THAT'S why I keep going to Thai restaurants!  

We arrived just ahead of the lunch hour, and the place was mostly empty.  One glance and I thought - this is probably a favored lunch spot for business types.  It's nicely appointed, but not luxurious - pleasant touches that go well with business attire.  I was thinking it should also appeal because its offerings are safely ethnic - superficially interesting, with exotic names on the menu that don't correspond to threatening food.  And sure enough, when the clock struck 'lunch' the place became completely packed with nicely dressed employees of near-by businesses.

The food?  Unexceptional.  It caused no distress, but it's not the kind of Thai Cuisine that I favor.  Or remember.  With so many other restaurants in SF there's no reason to go out of my way for a return trip.
author: Ren P.

description:
The tofu and eggplant has to be one of the best veggie dishes in town. And the yellow curry is pretty good too. Still my favorite Thai in the city, and, surprisingly, they have a good wine list, too.
I did the Monkey wine flight (it's the one with the three whites) and it went perfect with all the food and it's affordable and big pours.
author: Chris D.

description:
Back when I lived in SOMA this was a solid spot to enjoy Thai food.
The Bag of Gold are a treat and the service was spot on.
Parking is somewhat of a pain, especially if you forget that the Giants are playing that night.
A hidden gem in SOMA for sure.
author: Steve B.

description:
Could it be? A Thai restaurant that doesn't loo like it was decorated by the guy who decorates most every Thai restaurant in the US? 

In short.... I really like this place. I was one of the first to go here when they opened back in like... '03 but I'm sooo late in Yelping it. Mea culpa! 

The decor here is kind of minimalist modern with a slight Thai edge.... there is a decent long bar area where you can grab a cocktail if you're waiting on a table. The tableware is nice and very contemporary. 

The dining area offers a lot of window seats and the tables can be moved around easily to accommodate groups. 

The food! Well... really that's why I'm Yelping! 

IMHO.. the best quality Thai in the Bay Area. The curries are flavorful and can be easily modified to your spice liking. Whether you're a veggie person (and like the salads/pumpkin curries) or are more into the carnivorous mainstream.... the options here are safe in that they'll be tasty! 

Feel free to try something new here! When I'm not feeling adventurous... I'll get the Tom Yum Ka Gai (Chicken Coconut) soup and a simple green or red curry.... I've become a fan of their beef red curry because I've found their beef to be very well prepared. Definitely not dry, but nice and tender. 

The noodle dishes are great! I drift between the Pad Thai and the Char See Yew 

Long story short... I've never been disappointed here in over 20 visits over six years. I miss that I no longer live in the neighborhood and try to go when I know I'm going to be up in SF for dinner or have things to do SoMa. 

I'd encourage this as a good place to go for on a date.... their wine list was surprisingly good for a Thai restaurant! 


Treat yourself and leave room for dessert too
author: Claudio d.

description:
My favorite Thai restaurant in the world.

I love the yellow curry, pad thai, spring rolls with awesome peanut sauce and thai iced tea!
author: Chris W.

description: Yum!  A very cute, scrumptious lunch option.  Service was solid, food was good.
author: Tasha D.

description: We like to go & sit in the bar.  We sat in the dining room once.  The food is great & Thai spicy.  It's great.  The happy hour is the best & the drinks & bartenders are wonderful!  The bags of gold & jungle curry are my favorite.
author: Donna W.

description: Lovely cocktails... Great staff. A bit loud tho. 3.75 stars.. & Will give it another try, sometime.
author: Morgan D.

description:
I have such mixed feelings about this Monkey. I really liked my first experience there... even though the two drinks we ordered at the bar took about half an hour - uh, and we were the only ones at the bar that night!  I let that pass because the drinks, food and atmosphere were all good.  

I went again this weekend out of my love for the pumpkin curry, but I didn't like the way they made us feel like we were being rushed out of there.  I guess eating at 9:30 is a bit on the late side for San Francisco, but c'mon!  We weren't the last ones there quite yet, and we weren't being slow, and it just made the dining experience un-fun.  We were saving both the curry and sea bass to take home, but when we looked up, the fish had magically been whisked away into the kitchen land of the unknown, way beyond our reach.  By the time we asked them if we could take our dishes home, the bass was long gone...

It was a sad, sad moment.  I was looking forward to savoring the delight again the next day, but alas! Thus, I am not looking forward to going back again anytime soon... or at least not too late at night.
author: jenn h.

description:
went here for dinner with ace. he purchased a yelp deal online and decided to take me here. we ordered a bottle of a french burgundy to start the evening. had the fried tofu, the seafood salad for starters. we also tried noodles with peanut sauce and the duck curry. we also tried the rice sampler. for dessert, we ended up with the jasmine creme brulee. it was really good. i'd probably want to come back and try other dishes especially their lunch specials. 

thanks for dinner!
author: Mika D.

description: This Thai restaurant has yet to disappoint. Ive had the jungle curry and just last night the beef curry. Both were excellant, just make sure to get rice with the curry. They also have free delivery if the order is over thirty dollers. While I have yet to eat in the restaurant, the interior is very charming, with a popular looking bar.
author: Scott C.

description:
My all time favorite Thai restaurant. Here's why: 

The fresh spring rolls are over-the-top-orgasmically-delicious. The rice paper they use is the freshest I've ever had, every time. The peanut sauce they are served with makes for a match made in heaven. 

The pumpkin curry is sooo yummy. And I am not a curry person. It's delightfully light with chunks of squash and, best of all, it's' served in a little pumpkin. It goes well with the jasmine rice. 

The pad thai is very good, which is a must for me. 

The ambiance is great. It's situated in a warehouse building with large windows give it a very open, airy feel. The lighting is gentle, great for a date. 

The service is ok (why I gave 4 stars instead of 5). Sometimes I wish it was a little faster, but the food definitely balances that out. 

Anyway, I'll be back here many many times. It's my first choice when it comes to my birthday dinner, etc.
author: Elise L.

description:
Great food, great service, great price.

If you are looking a reasonably price thai meail in a place with a nice atmosphere, go here.   However, I would not recommend getting it take out as someone it tastes half as good as the eating at the restaurant.
author: Jason B.

description:
This has got to be THE WORST thai restaurant I have gone to.  It's all based on that pretentious foo-foo thing about being in SOMA.  Just because you are in SOMA does not mean the restaurant will be a hit.  I like "upscale" restaurants, this place just gives you the feeling of such.. but the food is awful.  I've had real thai food many times over and it sure didn't taste like this.

Service was slow.  Staff was rude.  Food was mediocre.  I can get this same stuff for half the price at the random mom & pop thai places all over San Francisco.

For better thai food, try going to Osha Thai (San Francisco), Citizen Thai, Bangkok Garden (Daly City).. or even King of Thai Noodle (low-budget SF). 

Seriously.. I was SO disappointed with this place.  They only get 1 star because I can't give ZERO stars.  Seriously, this place needs to get over itself.  It's all hype.
author: Nancy H.

description:
I love Koh Samui! Whenever we go here, I always enjoy their very flavorful Thai food. From their fabulous Pad Thai noodles with tofu to their kicky Tom Yum soup, this place really satisfies. Service is prompt and accomodating. The atmosphere and decor are also pleasant; I love their celadon colored walls and earthy logo design. Highly recommended if you enjoy well prepared Thai food. I like the green plastic monkey that sometimes sits atop of drinks, one of them came home with me...Off topic, their website does not work on Firefox.

Oh, their fried rice is to die for!!!!!
author: Michelle G.

description:
I am not at all a fried rice fan, but the Monkey has great fried rice to satisfy my taste buds.  Two dishes I always order are Crying Tiger Salad and Fried Calamari.  Other dishes are great, but not Wow.  So food wise, I give 4 stars.

Environment was alright.  Tables are packed together and I always knock my knee against their 200-lb solid wood chairs that give me bruises next morning.  So, 2 stars.

Service varies.  The entire restaurant is served (seemingly) by 3 waitresses no mattter how busy or not busy it is.  I got back late to the office one time because we were just waiting for food for over 45 min.

Do I recommend?  Yes and no.  Yes because you won't be disappointed by the food (besides the small portions) but no because you will find more surprises in nearby Thai restaurants.
author: Alex T.

description: A friend took me there a couple of years ago, and I remember the food and atmosphere to be divine.
author: Memory E.

description:
they serve really really little. I was like "THAT's ITTT??
and not cheap at all. one Appetizer +  one main dish won't even fill my stomach but you pay $$$
I need 2 Appetizers + 2 main dishes + one desert. 

Seriously... I have read some of the comments left here, A lot of them commented " portions are small" YES INDEED 

don't go there if you are hungry..

oh and I found out my ex goes there, so I dont go there
author: Cindy N.

description: I live right near this place, but somehow hadn't tried it until recently.  It's actually terrific.  While they have the basic Pad Thai, they have some really unusual and good stuff.  Try something different when you come here, you won't be disappointed.  The food is a little pricier than standard Thai food, but nothing crazy.  It has a nice ambiance and they have a lovely, friendly staff.  Great for a weekday date.
author: T.J. H.

description:
What is up with all these mediocre reviews!?! Maybe I just love food too much :)

This is definitely a place for people who like their Thai food on the sweet side. Also, be prepared to pay about $3-8 more per entree than an average Thai restaurant. If it wasn't for the prices, they might have 5 stars, considering that their portions are smaller than most aforementioned Thai places.

I've never had a problem with the service and love love love the food. Pumkin curry? Yes, please! Corn fritters with sweet chili sauce? Heck, yes! The presentation is lovely, the dishes are unique (not your typical basil chicken and pad thai option), and the atmosphere is hip, though definitely not intimate.

I am a sucker for creative sweet cocktails especially if they have lychee, so this place is a winner for me.
author: Olga A.

description:
We went as a big group on Friday lunch time. Thanks God we did a reservation as this place is very busy during the time. 

The lunch set is a steal! A choice of several appetizers and a Thai ice tea (or a Thai beer!) come with your choice of entries cost only$13! The Bento box ($17) which one of us ordered was even better. In addition to the above mentioned items, you get Mongo Salad and some pork all in one box!! 

My set included a spring roll, Thai ice tea, and the famous pumpkin chicken curry.  I think the Thai ice tea was TOO SWEET. But I am not sure if this was because I requested not to have ice in it. At the end I had to add some water to it.  My spring roll was pretty good.  Disappointingly my pumpkin curry was not served in a pumpkin bowl as other people said although the curry sauce was really yummy.  

The waitress was really sweet and nice.  They remembered everything everyone ordered (there were 11 of us!) and did not make any mistake when serving food. I was very impressed by their service!

Overall speaking I would come back again as the food is delicious and the price is very reasonable!
author: Jasmine C.

description:
It's difficult to review Koh Samui since I didn't even get the opportunity to try the food.  This review is for their service alone.

I visited the restaurant for the first time today around 2pm.  Two women were placing what appeared to be a large take-out order for their office.  Another group of three women with reservations were in front of me and were seated.  I continued to wait.  

Not once was I acknowledged.  In the half-empty restaurant, no other employee bothered to approach me.  After 5 minutes, I walked out.

Not a great first impression, KS&M.

[Edit: 9/17/2007]

I went to KS&M today again with Rand.  This time, I got food.  Yay.

I ordered the Red Curry with chicken and a Coke.  The curry was fine.  It didn't blow my mind.  The Coke was $3.00 and I was never offered a refill.  Since it's the only game in SOMA, I'll probably visit again, but the 3 stars are hanging by a thread.
author: Todd X.

description:
This is a great place if you like to overpay for food.  The food isn't all that bad, but it's not commensurate with their pricing and service.  The atmosphere is good, though I'm not sure if a big flat screen monitor with visitors bureau looking scenes playing on a loop is the most elegant treatment.

But for an area that used to be barren of good restaurants this place is a welcomed option in the neighborhood and adds to the diversity of cuisines.

A great plus is it's close to PacBell Park (yes, I said PacBell), so it's a convenient stop before or after ballgames or if you're just walking to and from Caltrain.  And if they want more stars from me, all they have to do is kick the quality of their food up a notch and give the service a bit more urgency.  At that point, food, service and atmosphere will catch up to the price.
author: Arvey S.

description:
Very cute decor. The chairs are super funky, a little uncomfortable, but definitely fit the scene. My favorite part of this place was actually the bar area. It was darkly lit with candles and had a urban, modern feel plus a super hot bartender.
Anyways back to the review, the food was good, authentic and fresh. It was fast and service was pleasant. Overall a nice place and would go again...although parking can be a bitch.
author: S. M.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night with a small group and didn't have any problem getting a table.  We arrived at around 6:30pm and the restaurant was pretty sparse, but by the time we left at 8ish it was already quite full.  That's a good sign I suppose.  

Now onto the food: we ordered the following dishes and shared family style:
- Whole Snapper (fried and coated in a sweet sauce, it wasn't bad but the fish did not taste especially fresh)
- Crunchy Tofu (with \spinach and mushrooms covered in a thick peanut sauce - this one kind of sucked)
- Belly Basil (pork belly with basil and bell peppers, portion was very small and the pork belly was tough and greasy)
- Chicken Pad Thai  (how can you go wrong with pad thai at a thai restsaurant? this one unfortunately was pretty dry and bland)
- Duck Curry (with pineaples, again, portion is tiny with a couple meager pieces of duck floating around)
- Tom Kha Gai soup (more sour than it should be, and not at all spicy or flavorful)

The thai iced tea tasted a bit watered down.

Overall, the food was very underwhelming. As much as I hate to say it, you should just go to Osha instead.  And if you don't care about service or atmosphere, go to King of Thai.
author: Nancy J.

description:
Short version:  SUCKS.  Go to Grand Pu Bah on Berry & Division instead (just 4 long blocks south of this place) - similar prices, better food, better service, similar ambiance.

Long version:

You know you're in trouble when there's a line out the door to get in, even when two people are behind the counter:  one who is jabbering to a customer, and the other who is ignoring the people waiting to be seated.  5 minutes to have someone seat you - and there were plenty of open tables.

This place puts emphasis on style/presentation and none on actual food prep.  For entrees, we ordered Southern Curry (chewy beef that had brown sauce slapped on at the last minute - the beef was utterly tasteless and the curry was bland), Sea Bass Clay Pot (bland, and to top it off, the vermicelli tasted like it was processed in an oil tanker), and sticky rice (I kid you not, the bf had to cut his sticky rice with a knife.  Like, sawing motions.  Let's actually cook the food the day of, shall we, instead of using a microwave?)  I will give them this - they'll give you sizeable portions... of inedible food.

No booze in my Mango Mojito.  I ordered booze with my syrupy sauce, thank you very much.

The service was awful.  We asked for a second beer and it literally took 10 minutes and 3 (yes, THREE) requests from our server for it to arrive.  Dude was nice, but c'mon.  If your busboys aren't bringing the beer, and your customer has requested it 2x already, why don't you go up to the bar and I don't know, retrieve it and serve your customer?  I know, it's a brilliant idea!  

Bottom line - go here if you want to look trendy, and don't care how long you wait for your food/beverage.  Or how your food tastes, for that matter.   Maybe we caught this place on a bad night, but I after reading a few other reviews, I don't know how this place stays open.  Haven't had such a crappy dining experience in a loooooooong time.
author: Doreen S.

description: Wow! This is an amazing place to eat and take in the SF culture. The staff was great, the food was amazing  and the prices were right on. I had the Crushed Sesame Scallops in a yellow curry sauce. It was soooo good. My friend had the vegetarian samosas and the  Tom Kha Gai Soup adjusted to her vegetarian requirements which by the way they were happy to do.  Great art work and a clean bathroom. I can't wait to go back and bring friends! Next time I'll order something from their extensive drink/wine list.
author: Amara R.

description: This place is great. It's the closest place to our office, with by far the cheapest happy hour. I guess that's why we like it. Bar menu is decent, but I'm not there to eat dang it...I'm there to drink!
author: Coco F.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants!

The food is really good, especially the tofu curry and the chicken with green coconut curry! They also have good coconut milk soup and a wide variety of cocktails that look delicious. The decor of the place kind of has a green theme with monkeys and ethnic looking decorations all over the place. 

I've never actually sat at the bar, but it looks like fun!

This restaurant is delicious and has very reasonable prices!

Also, parking seems like it may be difficult (i'm not sure, b/c I usually walk there)
author: Elaine S.

description: I've tried their various dishes and the food is overall great. There were a few times when I felt they added either MSG or some other additive. I felt VERY dehydrated. My favorite is their Pad Thai!
author: Mashimaro M.

description: Having been to Koh Samui in Thailand I really wanted to try this restaurant. My friend, Kelly, works 3 blocks from here so I invited her to lunch. I've heard her rave about the food for awhile so this visit was long overdue. I had duck noodle soup & she had pad kee mao with chicken. I loved my soup, great for this rainy weather we've been having. It was the perfect portion size for lunch. I wanted to order tom yum kung but the waitress said the lunch portion isn't big enough to have on its own. I couldn't decide what else I would eat so I ordered the duck one. Overall, a great lunch place -- only if you have more than an hour for lunch because the food took awhile to come out. I will be coming back for dinner soon!
author: Sara P.

description: I've walked by this place hundreds of times and it's always packed but I have never been there until today.  The service was nothing to write home about but the food made up for it.  There was a good lunch selection and everything had generous portions.  I would try the monkey box for lunch as you get a good amount of food and it's not that expensive.
author: Blake B.

description:
I have worked near this restaurant for almost 5 years, on and off. It's my go to place when I don't know what to eat. Additionally, they have a great online ordering system that keeps me working and efficient as I place my lunch orders.

For later dinners, have them delivered! :-) Pumpkin Curry, sweet rice, and throw in something exciting. I can say, I am a fan.

They also have ttly comped me when they messed up my order, which I appreciate.
author: Erin H.

description:
I meant to give 3.5 stars... but I guess it's either 3 or 4 so I'll be generous and go with the 4.

This is refined Thai food. Everything we ordered were made with very fresh and tasty ingredients. I can't say anything made me say "WOW" though.... but the pad thai was delicious and I did like the red curry very much. We asked for very spicy... but it tasted only mildly sweet spicy to me. Next time I'll have to put the emphasis on the "very very" spicy.
author: Alice C.

description: Mmmmmm ordered for the 3rd time for delivery from this place.  LOVE love love love love the Grilled Honey Duck, which comes with steamed rice and spinach .  Meat is tender, moist and soooo good.  I admit that I'm still disappointed on the small portions, but it's such a good dish.  You can also order online for delivery which is so much better than calling in your order because 1/2 the time I usually get a busy signal.
author: Emy B.

description:
The restaurant is better than your average "authentic thai restaurant" in terms of ambiance and decor.  However, I've had much better for far less money.

First the waiteress spilled a portion of the diet pepsi that I ordered on me.  Apologies were given, fine.  However, I would think that maybe they would have comped the $3 soda.  Nope, they didn't.  To top it off, I said yes to a refill and was charged for another $3.  Seriously, $6 for 2 thin/tall glasses of diet soda?

We got the pumpkin curry and spicy tofu, which were both okay, nothing special.  

I won't be back - there are many more places in the city to get better thai food.
author: Jules L.

description:
YUM!  I don't know why this place is rated in the yellows.  I can imagine it's underwhelming if you came out of your way for dinner.  However, getting a brown-rice melt-in-your-mouth eggplant tofu in their basil chili sauce for $9 for lunch is just ... heavenly.  And, seriously?  $9 is how much you would pay for a shitty pre-made salad at Cafe Cento and then get hungry 2 hours later. 

I also love their Duck Noodle Soup, but I'm really overzealous and bad at using chopsticks so end up with a scalded mouth and soup all over me.  Sort of gross, I know. Their crispy spring rolls are also delicious if you're with a group. The Pad Thai was sort of boring... I would stick to the dishes that have a spicy symbol (sadly, sometimes "spicy" equates to "has flavor").
author: Jenny B.

description:
Good, but not great Thai food.  It doesn't quite have a kick to it that would really put it over the top into being a destination restaurant.  That said, it's in an unassuming location and the decor is pretty nice.  

I remain a bit thrown off by their chairs though.  It's not that they are uncomfortable, but they always look like they are going to be right before I sit down in them.
author: Beau G.

description:
Okay kids. I work in SOMA and there aren't a whole lot of dining options. Koh Samui is a pretty solid choice when I'm craving something other than a Subway sandwich or a "sushi" roll from Safeway. The yellow curry with chicken is a safe choice, but I also enjoy their duck dishes. Standard chicken satay, but they sure are generous with the peanut sauce!

They tend to get really busy during lunch, so it's best to call your order in and pick it up.
author: lindsay w.

description: The cocktails were pretty phenomenal. The waitress recommended the Pink Monkey for my friend and I spotted the Lychee-politan so I had to give that a try. Neither of us were disappointed. We started off with the fried calamari. It wasn't the typical fried battered calamari rings, rather small little calamari steaks. Very delicious with the sweet & sour sauce. For our entree, we had each ordered and shared a variety of different rice, coconut, brown and sticky rice. For our entrees, we shared the pumpkin curry, beef mango and jurassic prawn. I REALLY dislike pumpkin and the combination of meat and fruit, but they managed to make it not only edible, but so good I'd order it again. For dessert, we had the coconut panna cotta. It was a tasty and light way to end our meal.
author: Adelina W.

description: Decent thai place in deep SOMA. Imperial rolls were great. Service was excellent and atmosphere is nicer than a Cha Am. Always seems to be pretty busy but we didn't have to wait.
author: Jeremy S.

description: What a cute little place...  It looks so average and kind of industrial from the outside.  I was pleasantly surprised by both the quality of food and the price; the wine list was really reasonable as were all of the dishes.  My friends and I had a red chicken curry, imperial spring rolls and tofu and green beans.  The dishes were all great, and they had my most favorite dessert - mango and sticky rice.  I've met very few mango and stick rice dishes I don't like, but I did think this was mango and sticky rice was particularly good.
author: Wendy L.

description: One of the best happy hours in the city. The happy hour is seven days a week, too.  The happy hour items are actually entrees. Some days after leaving from the gym, I'll order two beers, one chicken pad thai, and one bbq chicken...with tip and taxes, $22.
author: Michael C.

description: Just ate here.  I made it before the noon rush but the service was slow.  The peanut sauce for our chicken satay was oily and watery indicating it was probably left over from last week.  The chicken was pretty good though.  We also had the green curry with chicken.  The chicken was really rubbery and the green curry was bland.  The pad see ew was probably the best part of the whole meal.  I doubt ill be back.
author: Brandon M.

description:
I'd actually say 2.5, but I'm being nice and rounding up.

The service is lousy.  I thought it might just be during lunch, but I went for dinner last night (when the place was quite busy) and was equally disappointed.

It took far too long for our waiter to even acknowledge us and bring some water.  Then he mixed up our order.

Something positive? I actually like the tom ka soup (not as much as Osha, but it's close) and the name is cute.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
Excellent date restaurant, and the thai food is top-notch. The ambiance, staff service, attention to detail, quality of food, and location all contribute to this four star rating.

Located on Brannan right off of fourth street, this place is pretty close to a friend's house. He had recommended it in the past so I tried it out - instantly enamored with it, and have returned on several occasions and recommended it to friends. The interior is really well done - the restaurant and bar are separated by a medium height wood wall. Plants and other wooden artifacts are on display everywhere, giving the impression that they care more about the diners' experience than cramming in as many tables as possible to maximize profit. Thats always an immediate plus.
Then there's the parking - this side of SOMA you can park on any of the streets, and the spots opposite the restaurant rotate out fairly frequently on weekends. Another plus for not having to circle the block like a vulture. They take plastic, so automatic plus for that also.

And finally, the food is excellent. No words can do it justice, just try it out for yourself. I usually get the red penang curry, and it has never failed to disappoint. Ditto for the Pad Thai and the Satay.
author: Maxx L.

description:
Too Americanized.  Totally different from what a ate in Thailand.

Too sweet and focused on presentations.  There are other places to eat Thai in this city.
author: Yuko K.

description:
*************************************************
RICK'S QUICK RECAP:
Great upscale Thai with strong drinks - go here before painting the town red!
************************************************* 

Been here twice now so it's time to put my thoughts down....both times have been for gatherings of 6-8 people....first, the environment is just great... not your run of the mill mom and pop thai restaurant...they focus their efforts to being more modern, and upscale in decor and service... black is the standard color for hostess to bartender....

Did someone mention alcohol??!!!  They have a full stocked beer with signature martinis and other drinks....good options and strong...

Now the food...Best Thai food EVER!!! not really but right up there with the best of them... Brown rice is offered...and it's not your basic lumpy brown rice...this one is quality...also offered are sticky rice and regular steamed....

Our group ordered a variety of stuff from duck curry, pad thai, fried rice, corn fritters, papaya salad and other standard thai fare....and though we didn't order everything, the menu was extensive and had quite a few seafood dishes...How was everything?  Well I'm a huge fan of the Panang Curry with Duck...and it delivered...the highlights were the loads of duck (they don't skimp like other places) and the pineapple chucks were huge and fresh....did it come from a can?  I'm not sure but it didn't taste like it....again...lots of it...they ain't messing around...

I didn't have everything on the table but the consensus overall was a very good meal...and I had some pretty hardcore Thai food eaters with me.  

Maybe due to the upscale decor and the high quality of ingredients used, the prices needed to be a bit higher than your average Thai restaurant... Most entrees were in the $9-15 range....

In short...if you're in the Soma area and meeting a group for pre-party dinner...this is a must option... strong drinks and a good meal....enough said....also, the majority of the party was over 30 minutes late....but they were so cool about not enforcing a 15 minute limit.....they are Asains...come on now, they understand tardiness!

I would definitely come back...
author: Rick N.

description:
All that I find soothing about this place is the decor. I've been here several times for lunch. The food is good and comes out fast. They do also have a nice express menu at lunch that is a good value. Though your food may come out fast that doesn't mean it comes out in any particular order. On several occasions I have received my food before my beverage, and sometimes we have wait about 10 minutes for the entire party to receive their orders.

I guess that's why it's called express. Fast & Furious only!
author: Aubrey W.

description:
Here's a quick checklist to see if you'd like Koh Samui:

1)  Do you like curry?
2)  Do you smell like curry?
3)  Are you infatuated with all things monkey?
4)  Do you get excited by the prospect of having soup poured on your jacket?
5)  Are you not bothered when the bill arrives when you realize the apps cost more than some killer entrees served at lesser known hole-in-the walls?

If you answered yes to any of these questions, visit the monkey.  If you answered an emphatic NO, to all of these questions, save your money.  Yes, they do serve decent food, but only 10% of their extensive menu is worth a taste.
author: Sy K.

description:
Disappointed.
I was expecting more from all the good reviews.
The ambiance is a mix. On one hand they tend to be classy with the way the tables are set and the drinks and service. One the other, the RIDICULOUSLY loud house music of the bar made me wondered where the hell I was.
 
Yelpers should know what sophisticated, chic and fancy is. That is 
definitely not Samui & the Monkey. And it's fine. Just don't over rate it.

Nothing incredible with this restaurant. Food was good but it's not large portions. Drinks were good but not enough that I wanted another one.
It is not a date spot. .
author: Marc L.

description:
I can't imagine why this place has only three and a half stars.  I ate there this week and can't begin to tell how delicious it was.  First thing, they offered us a complimentary bottle of champagne (possibly because we're so darn cute), so you know that started us off on the right foot.  

I ordered tofu in peanut sauce, delicious, and my non-veggie, EXTREMELY PICKY eater of a friend ordered the pumpkin curry.  We were both delighted with our choices.  The portion sizes were perfect.  Not too big, not too small.  There were several vegetarian choices, always a plus for me, and especially since Thai food is often cooked with fish sauce.  

I ordered some sort of drink (a lemongrass gimlet maybe?) with lemongrass infused vodka that was divine.  Phillygirl liked her mojito too.  

Finally, they offered us a complimentary dessert of our choice, which of course had to be sticky rice with mango, my favorite food EVER, and a complimentary dessert wine.  

The waitresses were SO nice and so adorable.  

Delicious, highly recommended.  Yum yum yum.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
ok, the food is ok and the decor is nice!  Let's face it, there are not a whole lot of good restaurants around so once we moved to the neighborhood, my husband and I went there a couple of times.  Maybe it was our luck, but everytime something happened!
First time, there was a strand of hair stuck on my drink glass.  I told the waiter and he looked at the glass looking for the hair, i mean what the heck? once he finally saw it, with no apology, he simply replaced it.  We expected a simple apology but didn't get it.
Another time, they mixed up our order and we had to wait a while.  Anyhow, we have given up on them.....I'd just go a bit further and go to Thai Basil....
author: Shima N.

description:
pumpkin curry.  pumpkin. f'n. curry.  this dish is life changing.  it's monumental.  it's just f'n good.  

kind of a weird place inside, but the super friendly service and the f'n pumpkin curry more than make up for it.
author: Ali L.

description: Easy parking, plenty of seating, hostess and waitresses are courteous and cute too.  It was packed but the rate of goers and comers evened out so waiting for a table was nearly nonexistant.  I tried the pumpkin curry based on a few reviews here and yes, it's very good.  Try it.  It has a typical SOMA feel to it, nicely decorated, hip, and modern.
author: A t.

description:
I have to give this place props for delivering our meal a whole mile away! They told me they only deliver to nearby places since the deliverer WALKS to the destination. 

Goes without saying, but our food still arrived warm and with a friendly smile... EXCEPT for the tad-bit-cold corn patties, which were probably the highlight of my meal even though I didn't order it. This is something normal people would share, but next time, I'm ordering this for myself. 

We ordered almost half the menu for a late night work night and most seem pleased. Though, Pad Thai could have been a little bit tastier. 

I'm a fan for its service and giving it an A-OK for food. 

Thanks,

-Matt
author: Matthew C.

description: Good, I actually like the food better here than Ozone around the corner, but the lunch service is slow! I had the lemongrass chicken with brown rice, and it was tasty and fresh with just the right amount of spice.
author: Jessica G.

description:
All in all, very happy with Koh Samui & the Monkey, the food is good, the service excellent, and the atmosphere is pleasant.

If you like your Thai spicy, be sure to ask for it very spicy - we asked for "American hot, but not Thai hot" and had no hint of spice - some chili flakes and pepper oil took care of that though.

The service is excellent - friendly, attentive, but not too much so. Ask for opinions and suggestions - the staff seemed to have a great command of the menu and made good suggestions.
author: Ben K.

description:
The food is good. I mostly go here for lunch and the new take out counter is great. What sucks is that their to-go trays are the same price but much less food. A chicken red curry order is a tiny skimpy portion - some shreds of chicken, big chunks of vegetables, and little soup. They give you lots of rice with it though. For the price, feels like a rip-off. 

Second, I pride myself with being a really good tipper. But when I go to pick up a take out order and the hostess expects the rest of my money as tip, it feels even more of a rip-off.

Third, the to-go boxes are made up of a lot of of plastic - all to waste.

Please use less waste with the trays, give normal portions to match the price, and don't ruin tipping for everyone by making it feel like it's required for a pick-up order.
author: Esso E.

description: Great food, great prices, great place to sit and relax or get in-and-out in a flash. All around a great deal meal if you're in the neighborhood. And, you can actually eat healthy here if you try. Kudos to their fried corn appetizer. INSANELY yummy, always.
author: Meredith R.

description: Not bad for a Thai restaurant in SF, but not great either.  Nice space and bar, but the food was a bit band and oily.  The pumpkin curry was my favorite dish here.  The bags of gold appetizers (minced chicken and veggies wrapped in rice paper) looked nice, but was a little too greasy.  Crushed sesame sea scallops were also on the heavy side, and the pad thai was not bad, not good, not memorable.
author: Peter L.

description: I love the name.  Food is good and the service was attentive.  When we were here it was empty but I can see how it could get noisy.  Atmosphere is nice and if you are looking for an upscale place for Thai food, I'd recommend it.
author: Karen C.

description:
This spot can be summed up in one word: tastynesss! 

Had the pumpkin curry, one of my favs, and was the best I've had so far.. nice ambiance and good service.
author: Ava K.

description: Loved the thai food; prices are incredibly reasonable. Will definitely return; staff was very friendly.
author: Eric F.

description: Pad Thai was very weak/mediocre. The curries were good. The apps were pretty good. Atmosphere is great for a date but the bathroom was a let down and the fact the prices were more matching the atmosphere than the quality of the food... for sure, the more expensive thai spot i've been to and one of the most mediocre in terms of actual flavors. I wouldn't go back.
author: Jordan S.

description: Koh Samui & The Monkey is a little more expensive than other Thai restaurants in the city and a little fancier too.  Nice ambiance.  Service was great.  The pad thai was a little bland, nothing too memorable. The fish cakes were yummy, but small in portion.  The eggplant and tofu dish was good, can't really mess up a dish like that.  The highlight of this restaurant would have to be the pumpkin curry.  SO DELICIOUS and full of flavor!!  I couldn't stop eating it.  They serve it in a pumpkin.  Such great presentation!  I'm getting hungry thinking about it.
author: C E.

description:
At first glance, you'd think it'd be a pretty expensive restaurant given the dark lighting and the decorations. But it's pretty decent and the food portions were a bit small but good. We had the Chicken Mieng Kum, the Garlic Pepper Shrimp, and the Golden Triangle. 

The Mieng Kum was an interesting appetizer with many flavors to savor. The ginger was a bit strong and the lime had a kick to it, but the sauce was perfectly balanced. The Garlic Pepper Shrimp was pretty standard, nothing too special about it, but at least it tasted good. As for dessert, we wanted to try the more unique dessert and went for the Golden Triangle. It was a strange dish, the egg yolk spun cocoon thing had a good texture and yet it tasted like Filipino nan bread. Then, it had these little fruit-looking things, but it was mung bean filling with a gelatin covering to look like cherries and other fruits. Interesting, but not a standout.

Overall, pretty good Thai food, service was pretty quick and efficient, and the ambiance was subtle. We went on a Wednesday, which seemed like a slow day since there weren't many people. Still, a good choice for decent Thai in SF.
author: Jess W.

description: The sea bass mordin is delicious. Nice environment, decoration, and great food.
author: Marcos S.

description:
As is so typical of restaurants in SF, the outside of this restaurant doesn't do the inside justice.  It was open and airy inside, with just enough decor to be decorated without being tacky.  There was a TV with "asian music videos" my fiance had in his view (I couldn't see it) that didn't need to be there, but that's my opinion.

We started with the fresh spring rolls.  They were the largest I have ever had and were a bit lacking in flavor without the sauce on the side.  But the sauce was terrific!

There were many things on the menu that tempted me, but I ordered the chicken pumpkin curry since it was so highly recommended and was very glad I did!  It was rich and creamy with tender chicken pieces and yummy bits of pumpkin with just the right amount of spice (for me, which I think is on the milder side), served in a hollowed-out pumpkin!  Awesome!  My fiance got the pad thai with chicken (his usual) and the cashew prawn entree.  The pad thai was good (no spice), and was pretty typical.  The prawn dish didn't have as much spice as you would have thought since you could see the peppers and red flakes all over the dish... but it was still flavorful.  My honey got some hot sauce on the side that kicked up the spice for him nicely.  If you like things spicy, you should probably order them enhanced from the start.

We also had a bottle of Malbec (don't remember the name, but I think they only had one) which was... warm.  As in, seemingly warmer than room temp.  Still was tasty though!

Service was great!  Very nice waiter who was attentive and always had a nice smile.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Overpriced and microscopically portioned, the restaurant with the corniest attempt at a cool name I've heard in a while somehow manages to bring customers in droves. Mostly white people. The service staff is all costumed, which is either endearing or cheesy. Cheesy because it really feels like they're trying to bring you some sort of "Journey to the Far East" experience... or something.

You'll find much better Thai food without all the atmospheric cruft down at Basil on Folsom...
author: Stephen L.

description:
I've only ordered take away and it's always been really good.  The decor in the restaurant looks really nice and cozy - would love to go there some time for dinner.

Their noodle and curry dishes are fresh tasting and delicious.  We love the pumpkin curry and spicy basil meat dishes.
author: Gina C.

description:
Very good thai food! The place is clean, the people are nice, it's a great place for lunch. The thai iced tea is amazing, and so are the imperial rolls. The yellow curry chicken was good, but the chicken could have been cooked a little less. 

I really enjoyed this place and will definitely be coming back soon!
author: Sabina Y.

description: Ammmmazing chicken pumpkin curry! Also got the beef satay, pad thai, and coconut rice. Enough for two plus take home.
author: Saquib P.

description:
Ah... the Happy Monkey. 

Considering I can see them from my apartment window, and that they're a block from the office, I'm there at least a couple of times a month. 

The decor? Industrial chic. Substantial wooden chairs and the bathrooms have "lost pet" note cards from all over the world (you need to see it to really understand).

The lunch specials are a little pricy, but you get a tremendous amount of food for the money. For $10.95, I can get a good portion of Panang Beef, two chicken satay skewers and rice. The barbecued pork and chicken lunch specials are also quite good.

For dinner, the prices are about the same as most upscale Thai restaurants - but the portions are about 50% larger. Gai Grapow (chicken and basil) is also very good.
author: Avery G.

description:
I've been here a few times, now.  The food is unique, the house drink concoctions won't be found anywhere else by the same name (Red Monkey - yum, Thai Kiss, Melon Monkey Mojito), and the atmosphere is in line with the SoMA vibe.  

It's attracts a trendy crowd, but isn't pretentious.  The bathroom art is a little weird for an asian restaurant, given a certain stereotype (lost dog and cat posters - uhhhh...) but again, whatever.  The chicken is chicken, the sea bass is sea bass, and the tofu is tofu.  I can't speak to the beef.  They're all labeled with "Property Koi Samui" flanked by signs that say, "Hey lady, stealing is a crime."   

Skip the samosa - not fantastic.  Try the fried tofu triangles in peanut sauce!  Try the pad thai!  And the pumpkin curry is pretty darn tasty, too.  This is basically a menu that I try something different on each time I go back because of its quality consistency. 

Koh Samui & the Monkey embodies all the best of my loftdustrial hood... and SCORE - the food is reasonably priced.  At least something is in SoMA!
author: Jessica M.

description: This is a pretty nice Thai restaurant. I like a lot of things in the menu but mainly butter chicken! If you are a large group make sure to make a reservation.
author: T I.

description:
Lunch time was a bit crowded, but we got seated right away. Pretty good start since there were 6 of us. But, the place was warm and stuffy - they need to open some windows or something. Ambiance was a bit weird, too as I had to listen to the self-important geek proselytizing at the next table about something fantastic he'd just done that day. His voice just echoed throughout the place.

I ordered the Thai BBQ chicken, and the waitress confirmed it'd be all white meat. Well, the meat wasn't white. It was dark and undercooked. And, a few pieces were so strange that I couldn't figure out what part of the chicken they came from - one piece looked like a knuckle all bloody and weird. I didn't want to gross out my coworkers, so I kept quiet and ate around it. The flavor was quite good once I got over the strange chicken part and undercooked bits. If it had been all white meat and well done, I'd be giving 5 stars. But, mysterious dark chicken parts that are undercooked just don't pass muster. And, one of the other people at the table had an order of Pad Thai that was so small - we all thought it was an appetizer.

All in all, very average with plenty of room for improvement.
author: Maren P.

description:
What a nice surprise!

This restaurant sits above sidewalk level, so the floor the ceiling windows  create a feeling of elegance that many other restaurants don't have.  You don't see anybody walking by, so it's private and nice.  

The service is good, the food is great, and the lunch prices are the best! I had a lunch combo and walked out for $15 after tip, feeling very satisfied.  

The curry was delicious, and the serving size was just right - individual serving rather than a shared portion.
author: Alice H.

description:
I think I could create my own Thai blog after being to almost every Thai restaurant here in SF :) Koh Samui would rate 4 stars overall with the combination of great service and presentation.

1st star - Service was great considering it was prime time dinner crowd on a Friday night - prompt, polite and they were able to cater to my client's needs when she wanted to change a sauce of her seafood dish.
 
2nd star - Yummy appetizer platter included all the Thai staples - fresh rolls, crispy imperial roll, prawns, sweet Corn, mieng kum, satay and mango salad - can't go wrong with that.

3rd star - Atmosphere and presentation - somehow with all their sculptures and decor they didn't over do it. Has a nice feel to it and i love their tea cups! Jade shaped elephants..so cute. 

4th star - They carry Tiger Beer :)
author: Charlene A.

description: my friend's birthday recently passed, and for her birthday we went to a late dinner at Koh Samui & the Monkey. This place was recommended by the hotel concierge, since we didn't know where else to go in the city. we found parking right out front, and the place wasn't hard to find. Once inside, we found the place had a nice ambiance, great for conversation. Their was 4 of us, and we order chicken pad thai, firecracker seafood plate, a tofu dish, and an appetizer, fried imperial rolls to start us off. We also ordered a couple of drinks. The drinks weren't as good as we expected, 1 out of the 3 cocktails we had was good.. and that was the mango mojito. The  food was all pretty good though, and all of us enjoyed our meals. i would go back and sample something else on the menu, it's affordable too.
author: Lily S.

description:
I can't say enough great things about this place. Our server was so incredibly friendly, she made our meal enjoyable. To start we had the beef satay and the papaya salad. Beef was  great, could have been a tad more tender, but the flavors were good and I liked the peanut sauce that it came with. Papaya salad was good, but watch out for the pepper! I accidentally bit one and it was so hot. Besides that though, it was really good. My bad for not catching it I actually saw it but underestimated its spiciness.

For dinner we shared the sea bass, scallops with squid ink noodles, with coconut rice. These were just yummy...yummy yummy yummy. Flavors were great, everything tasted fresh. I just loved it. I would order it again.

My wife and I don't often order dessert but we were in the mood for something sweet. We went with the chocolate cake and it didn't disappoint. What we liked about it was that it wasn't a really thick, rich, overly sweet, chocolate cake that you typically get at a restaurant. This one was chocolatey, but also fluffy and light and just the right amount of sweet. To top it off, it was served with BiRite coconut ice cream. It doesn't get any better than that. Seriously. good stuff.
author: Davin A.

description: Food is about 3.5, service is a 2. The food is good, some of the dishes were the best Thai I've tasted in SF (spicy Tofu) and others were blah (Pad Thai, have had much much better). The service was pretty poor, not rude but VERY slow and then we were rushed out of the restaurant.
author: Elzabeth G.

description:
I went here last Thursday with a group of 12: it's a nice Thai Restaurant in SOMA... more *upscale* than your local mom/pop Thai restaurant and I think it's worth checking out at least once. 

Koh Samui has a good size modern space with a large bar and extensive cocktail/wine list. Dishes were all great, although I wasn't crazy about one of the curry dishes (the meat chunks were HUGE) and on the extra sweet side in my opinion. Other that that, we enjoyed everything else (which were at least 10 dishes). 

If you like this place definitely check out Citizen Thai and the Monkey in North Beach.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
I was here for a friend's birthday and they were able to accommodate a large group with reservations.

They have a lot of specialty cocktails that all have a "monkey" theme.  I sampled a couple and they were pretty good -- basically tasting like alcoholic punch.

The food was mediocre.  We shared food family-style and this is what we ordered:

Stew beef -- good flavor in the curry, but the beef was really dry.  It didn't seems like the beef had been stewed in the curry since the meat didn't really capture much of the flavor.

Mango salad -- Yummy!

Spring rolls (not fried) -- Yummy! I thought the peanut sauce was particularly good.

Other things we ordered that were good, but not memorable: Prawns in garlic sauce, Green chicken curry, Calamari, Lemongrass chicken, Spicy rice, Chicken pad thai.

Overall it was an okay dining experience, but as other people have stated it was nothing spectacular.
author: Katie M.

description:
I just had dinner here last night and enjoyed it. I've eaten at a lot of different Thai restaurants and while the food was good, it wasn't anything special. Except for the Tofu Mieng Kum appetizer, which was awesome. This appetizer is a lettuce leaf containing a small piece of fried tofu, a tiny lime piece, onion, chopped peanut, chili and ginger. You simply put some of the accompanying roasted coconut dip on top of the other ingredients, wrap it up, and devour. I joked to my friends it was a "flavor bomb." Each bite of this wonderful appetizer packs an incredibly flavorful burst to the taste buds.

We had a chicken dish that was good but pretty basic - just some chicken with red and green bell peppers, onion and basil. The portion was pretty small. The green vegetable curry tasted good but was very watery. We also had tofu and shrimp pad thai (tasty, with noodles that were more al dente which I prefer) and pea sprouts sauteed with garlic. I loved the pea sprouts, which were flavorful and garlicky. I don't see pea sprouts served at many restaurants so this was a real treat for me. 

All in all a good meal in a restaurant with pretty decor, a full bar, and very nice ambiance and service.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Woah.  Talk about a lot of bad reviews.  I actually had a pretty good meal there last night.

I got back from Thailand about a month ago with a newfound love of Thai chilis, and I've been hitting up as many Thai restaurants as I can to find something comparable to what I had on the beaches of Koh Samui.

Koh Samui and the Monkey is actually the best Thai meal I've had in the city so far (ok not saying much).  Whatever the considered spicy was far from what we wanted, but fresh chopped red chilis immediately remedies that situation.  Pumpkin curry was solid (excepting the overcooked chicken), and the grilled prawns had a really tasty curry sauce and I liked the fried basil leaves.

Decor was cool, service was not great but not too bad.  I'm sure I'll find better but for now, I know I can go there for an acceptable capsaicin fix.
author: Jenny S.

description:
Rubbery/leathery scallops.
The food looks better than it tastes. Overpriced.
author: Mark C.

description:
Have to admit - tried only one dish there, not enough to really judge, but it was the most expensive one (whole snapper with cashews and chilies, $22 for entry), so being rather disappointed by its preparation and taste accounts for a lot.

However, it's good at accommodating large groups (lots of tables they have no problem moving together), and there is Bacar across the street to balance out Koh Samui's early closing time.
author: Sasha M.

description:
Pretty good food with a cool atmosphere.

Been here 3 times now: once years ago, once as take out, and a Friday night in a 40 person group.  The food has been consistent each time, and the staff have always been very friendly and accommodating.

Food: pretty good menu of selections differing from the typical Thai restaurant with sea bass, pumpkin curries, and other seafood and meat dishes.  Everyone seemed happy with their orders, but portions were small.

Service: excellent!  With a group of 40, they patiently waited for us as members slowly arrived.  They got all our orders in quickly and my cup of water was refilled at least 5 times that night!  The staff are well dressed, very friendly, and had great service.  The toilet got clogged and immediately 2 staff quickly came to the rescue and in minutes all was at peace again.

Price: the food was good, but portions were kind of small to be charging $12 for a little plate of noodles with some chicken pieces.  Slightly over priced, I feel, so this is why they get 3 stars, not 4.

Atmosphere: very cute (the cartoon monkey logo and other cute pieces) and posh.  If all the food weren't around, it could easily be a great bar spot to go out to town with friends and laugh next to the decorative Buddhas and dark wood finished floors and furniture.

Restroom: one single-occupancy restroom each for males and females.  Speaking only for the male restroom: very clean, well lit, and the cutest decorations of various framed "Lost Dog" or "Lost Cat" ads from around the world with handwritten inscriptions saying the dog/cat belongs to Koh Samui.

Location: the restaurant's kind of out on its own in SOMA, but it also allows for lots of available street parking.  The restaurant is raised from ground level, so you need to go in and walk up 10 steps before seeing the restaurant.
author: Jason K.

description:
I came here twice -- both times for lunch on a weekday. I only came here because it's close to my office.

First off, the decor was pretty nice. I could do without the TVs, but I guess they come in handy at the bar during happy hour.

That's where my compliments end. The food was pretty bland. I ordered the seafood pad thai during my first visit and the chicken pad see ew during my second visit. While the presentation of the dishes were aesthetically pleasing, both dishes lacked flavor. I wanted to ask the wait staff for soy sauce, but they weren't very attentive.

Which brings me to another complaint -- the service. During my second visit, the service was subpar. Our waitress came to our table only once -- in the very beginning when she took our order. After that, we were basically ignored. In fact, I had to ask the food server for water since our waitress never came by and did not respond when I tried to get her attention. After we finished our meal, the food server promptly cleaned off our table. We then sat there at an empty table for a full 20 minutes, wondering if our waitress was going to come by with the check. Eventually, I had to flag her down to ask for the check and she gave us an annoyed look and did not address us as she put the check tray on the table. I left my Discover card on the tray and waited for her to come back so she could swipe my card. After 10 minutes, I had to flag her down again. When she came by, she rudely said, "We don't accept Discover." So, I replaced the Discover card with my Visa only to realize that she had already walked away. Couldn't she have waited a mere 2 seconds for me to give her a different credit card before leaving our table? Or, at the minimum, couldn't she have said, "I'll be right back." Nope. So, once again, we were sitting there wondering if she would ever come back or if we would have to get her attention again. After yet another 10 minutes, I had to flag her down so she could swipe my card. She was not very apologetic. Sure, the restaurant seemed busy as it was during the lunch hour, but I do not think that is an excuse for not being attentive.

Overall, the tasteless food wasn't worth the prices and the service was pretty bad. I was also annoyed that they did not give free refills of my iced tea! It wasn't even Thai iced tea -- it was just the plain, unsweetened iced tea. C'mon, they could give free refills for that. It's not like this was a fancy restaurant whereby the concept of "free refills" might damage their reputation -- I mean, hello, they had TVs on the walls on the ESPN channel right next to their fancy elephant tusks and Buddha statues. Pretty tacky if you ask me.
author: Tita L.

description:
So I eat here once a week.  Every time I get takeout, I ask myself  WHY?  The servings are TINY and the prices are HIGH for food that is just OK.  I must say that the service is hit or miss!  

On the positive, the decor is pretty cool!  I do enjoy watching Thai Pop videos when I wait for my food. and I love the name :)
author: Che P.

description: We found this Thai restaurant during a random walk since the queue was awkwardly long in the other place where we intended to go originally. For diner, the place has a well balanced charm and huge bottom-to-ceiling windows where you can enjoy a spectacular view of the industrial buildings of this area when you're staring at the opposite side of the street. My basic Thai kitchen test is always to try the Tom Yom Kung soup, which is my personal Big Mac Index, and I'd say this restaurant passed the test way above average, at 8.5/10 on the TYK-index.
