The service is fast and super polite, and the waitress girl with the braces absolutely super cute. If you like Thai food and atmosphere and looking for diner, you can't go wrong here.
author: Tamas K.

description: On the taste level, Ko Samui is pretty legit. They're flavor profiles are delicious and light. I personally recommend the Bags of Gold (minced pork wrapped in light shell of dough deep fried) and the pumpkin curry--it's out of this world. They also has a great cocktail list and happy hour (food and drink) from 5-7 everyday. I appreciate the attention to detail from the food presentation to the interior design. It's not over the top and maintains an intimate eating setting. Prices are average. Definitely a go-to bar if you live in SoMa, otherwise it's definitely worth checking out if you haven't been.
author: Alex H.

description:
I love Thai Food!

This place had exquisite Thai.   we had the mango beef and honey duck with the volcano rice and the sampler for two.   The bill came out to be just under a hundred bucks, so basically 120 with tip.   Good thing we passed on drinks... cause that's pretty pricey for Thai... But worth the enjoyment.   

I particularly liked the Sample for twor, which was $22t, and the server took the time to tell us about each of the 6 items them.  I particularly liked the Mango Salad in the center.   My Beef was a bit overdone, and her Duck was very fatty and slightly overdone as well.    The volcano rice was a nice presentation, as it comes served in a pineapple, with the rice pouring out the side like lava down a mountain.   But unlike a traditional Pineapple Fried Rice Thai dish... which is sweet and retains the Pineapple flavor... this dish had a lot of yellow curry seasoning.  It did however have a load of sea food in it, and was $15 Ala cart.     

I was also a bit disappointed that they did not have Nam Tok beef salad on the Menu, and only had a pork version of it.   

But the best part of the meal was the Tam Kha Gui coconut soup appetizer.   it was very rick and rick with a nice taste of sweet and hot Thai spices, but agan, pricey @ $6 per small cup.   At any other Thai place you get a big bowl o it for $6.

I probably won't go back because it's a bit to she-she for me, and I like my Thai a bit more Native and a lot less expensive.   Even though we did have a lot of food, it was at least twice as much as any other Thai place would have been, less the upscale ambiance and stuffy atmosphere.   Despite that... the service was great.  

If  you're on a first date and you wana impress someone... take them here.   But if you just want good and tasty  modestly priced Thai this is not the place for you.
author: Vlad C.

description: I spent 15.00 on a Pad See Iew with beef If there was any sauce in it, I couldn't  taste it. I will say that the vegetables were perfectly cooked and that is the only positive thing that came out of this dish restaurant. Well that and I know never to take any friends there.
author: Jason M.

description: Tatooed women, average food, convinient take out. Check it ou. The ribs are great.
author: Numa R.

description: 3,5 stars. It's a good place with a very good ambiance for dinner. Had the aromatic pumpkin curry chicken, that was very very good, bit spicy for me though. It's just a bit expensive for a thai restaurant. the meal is around 15/16USD.
author: Fabien S.

description:
I've eaten here for lunch with co-workers four times now, and once along with my fiance, so I feel confident in saying that it's not just I who really likes the food here. I generally get the Panang Curry dish with chicken, but I've also tried the Red Curry and Yellow Curry dishes, and I would say that they are some of the best Thai food I've had. They have lunch specials that run around $13 which include spring rolls, (I believe) soup and some other items, but I find that the dishes alone are enough food for me, and those generally run under $10, which is quite reasonable. I know one of my coworkers really likes the salads here, in large part because the non-vegetarian ones come with a good portion of meat.

I'm still hoping to discover even better Thai food in San Francisco, but if I don't, I won't be all that unhappy because Koh Samui is VERY good.
author: Alexander O.

description: this is one of my favorite lunch places. It's often slightly too crowded, but the food is consistently good and the service is too.
author: Fred A.

description:
IN THIS MONKEY BUSINESS, there's no need for Pad Tai - typically the safest dish to order at any Thai restaurants.  You'll be blinded by a variety of colorful dishes on the menu that you'll feel compelled to challenge everything on the menu.  Commence your evening  w/ cocktails, I gave in to the Red Monkey and Drunken Monkey, both were yummilicious.  If you're too manly for cosmo-lookin drinks, give in to the Thai Beer.  It'll taste like any other beer, but at least the name sounds exotically drunk-able.  The interior decor is awesome, modern contemporary yet oozes of Bangkok.  Waitresses are embellished with costumes that are comparible to stewdesses on Singapore Airline - HOTNESS!!  
This was yet another night of hitting 5 spots, KS&M was a fantabulous kick start for some crazy-ass Monkeys like us :)
author: Wendy H.

description:
Solid Thai spot in SoMa. Went there for dinner last Friday before seeing a movie. Had to get in and out in an hour and it took them 45 minutes. Good combo of speed and quality. 

Food and drinks were well above average but not especially noteworthy. Had the bags of gold, spicy seafood soup, and curried sea bass. All were very good. Monkey-drop (lemon drop with a restaurant-theme-appropriate name) was ok at best.

Atmosphere was what it was: sitting by a window seeing the deranged walk by is part of what you get South of Market. Didn't really care since I was in a rush. Like someone else said, apparently it's always busy but we didn't wait more than a couple minutes.

Overall, good place to grab a meal but don't expect too much more.
author: Ahsan M.

description:
UPDATED:

$2 a person for rice. Really?

---

I'd give 3.5 if I could... the menu was ok for veg stuff. They do have veggie fresh spring rolls, even they aren't listed on the menu (why??). They were EXCELLENT. Each bite had fresh mint and lots of flavor. The spicy green beens were good, but a little overcooked. Also had the tofu in peanut sauce, but it was really just a vehicle to eat peanut sauce. I'm not saying that's necessarily bad. I'm gonna check out their sister restaurant next...
author: Shal J.

description:
Mediocre Thai food for way too much. The prices are outrageous for the quality and portions there. Also, service can really suck, slow and impatient, and it is incredibly noisy, can't hear any conversation at all. Pad Thai was greasy, salty, no good flavors, and small. Curry also lacked any real flavor, tasted too sweet. 

Update: 
So you think that at most restaurants when the staff finds a negative review, they should ideally try to improve. Not with Koh Samui+Monkey! I got nasty messages from someone working at Koh Samui (Ricky S., apparently he did this to other people who gave negative reviews as well). He basically called me an idiot and hypocrite for my review, somehow assuming that even though I hate the restaurant, I have gone back (which is false!). When that's the attitude of the restaurant staff, don't go!
author: Ben B.

description:
Eat here!!!!!

The decor alone should lure you into this place, all the decorations are authentic thai pieces and they're beautiful....ok now for the food. Its good, i mean, really good. The bags of gold are a must as an appetizer and the spicy green bean dish has become a staple of me and my family. Sometimes we just get spicy green beans to go. The lunch rush can be a bit overwhelming, dinner is the best time to go. 

It can be a dress up or dress down kind of place, well priced and pretty much anything you order will be tasty.
author: Morgan E.

description:
I have been eating here for years. It was great after the dot-com bust as you seemed to have the whole place to yourself and everyone knew you. Things change.

The food has been consistently good, if you know what to order. Best bets are the Corn Fritters, Larb Gai, Crying Tiger Salad and anything grilled. Curries are hit and miss. True, it's not the most authentic Thai food in the world [ you need to actually go to Thailand for that ] but it is tasty and usually doesn't disappoint. Also, while not authentic, the Nigori Sake with a nice spicy salad is a great paring.

Koh Samui can get noisy when crowded. It seems to have been "discovered" by many of the hip and cool people in the SOMA area [ and people from the Marina who pretend they are] so your best bet is to go on a weeknight if loud parties and all black outfits aren't your thing. 

I will say that the service has taken a nose dive in the past couple of years. Waiters do seem a bit spaced out or uninterested.

Food 4
Decor 4
Service 2
Other sporadically abysmal parking situation, especially on game nights 2
author: Allan H.

description:
I wanted Thai and I got Thai! This place has it all! The minute you walk in you feel the authenticity of this restaurant but it also has a cleaner appeal than some Thai restaurants. I was a little concerned when we arrived that only a few tables were occupied but it quickly filled up as the night went on. 

Let's start with the drink menu - it's enormous! Not only do they have a full bar but all the drinks are monkey related...and boy are they tasty! Wine and beer are also available at very reasonable prices.

The food menu is extensive as well. It felt like 5 Thai menus jumbled into one. Well you can't have Thai food without the staple pad thai and it was yummy. Portions were good on all the other dishes and the service was fantastic!

Definitely visit the bathroom for some interesting "art" on the wall. Go and see it for yourself.
author: Josephine H.

description:
I love Koh Samui.  Good vibe, tasty food, fun drinks.

The best dishes I've had are:  Bags of Gold, Mieng Kum, Pumpkin Chicken Curry, Madame Sea Bass, Pad Thai, Penang Beef (YUM!!).

I've been a little underwhelmed by the specials but consistently pleased by the standard fare.

Service is very accommodating - they set a table for us in the extra room when we walked in and they were chock full.

Love the Monkey!!
author: Miriam W.

description:
I work just down the block from this busy/fast paced Thai resty. 3 or 4 years ago it was great but the quality of the food has slipped and waitstaff has gotten downright rude...

I was there 10 min ago and the place was empty but the food took 4 times as long and the waitress actually visibly rolled her eyes at us for asking about it. That said, we walked before the food came out. 

Never again.
author: A W.

description:
This place is a bit hidden. I drive on this street all the time but I never noticed this restaurant. There isn't really a big sign or anything, just a banner. The place was small but intimate. Service was average, nothing extraordinary. Food was good, but I have had better Thai food. Here's what was on our dinner menu:

To start off...

Bags of gold: minced chicken, shrimps wrapped in rice paper sacks
The name made me think that it would be really good, BUT is was just OK...it was a bit dry inside....but the dipping sauce was yummy....
 
Fried sweet corn Patties:  crispy corn spiced with curry paste served with cucumber vinaigrette dressing
I actually really liked this appetizer....


Main Couses...

Classic Yellow Chicken Curry
This was OK.....wasn't feeling the carrots in it though...

Sliced chicken wok fried with fresh basil
Can you say SPICY!?! 

Overall, this place is OK. I'ld go back again....
author: BrElla4eva H.

description:
This place used to be ok, not great, but ok.

However we had two appalling meals here in the space of 10 days and now won't go back.

Meal #1
After experiencing poor service throughout the meal, the final straw came when we went to pay our check.  We split the meal on two cards but later on I found out they had billed *both* of our card twice - one for the amount with tip and a second time without tip the following day!

Because they were separate transactions, of different amounts and different days we had big problems with the bank trying to get a refund as they asserted that it must have been a different trip.

Meal #2
Assuming the card mix up was an unfortunate accident, we came again with some friends.  Into the meal we wondered whether the chef wasn't working on a Sunday, as the food we were served was definitely reheated and not cooked from fresh.

Our suspicions were confirmed when multiple members of the dining party were unwell the following day.


I've been a regular diner at Koh Samui for sometime, even though I had already experienced one serious fault with them when a friend of mine asked for no peanuts on his salad as is allergic to peanuts and they bought the salad out with peanuts sprinkled on it.  When we queried it the waitress simply said "yes, peanuts". My friend could have died if he had eaten them!

Well, too many bad experiences and I find that Osha Thai on 2nd to be a great alternative.
author: Ben M.

description:
I'm so picky about asian food. I was happy with our meal. Last night we ordered beef w/ mango, basil chicken w/ string beans, and tom kha gai (chicken coconut soup). The flavors were clean, fresh and delightful. The vegetables were bright and crisp. The meat tasted fresh and the sauces were not overwhelming. They also have brown rice. 

We called in the order and walked 2 blocks to retrieve. It was ready, no wait. It was really clean inside. I wish they delivered, but I can walk a couple blocks to avoid being grossed out by the other sketchy asian delivery places. I'm looking forward to trying other menu items.
author: cali c.

description:
Decent thai food in a nice setting. I've been here many times for lunch and its always predictable yet slow service. Now that their sister restaurant (Citizen Thai and the Monkey) has vanished into thin air, it kind of makes me wonder about the ethical practices of this establishment. Apparently the restaurant closed suddenly and the staff wasn't notified until the day of the closure. Conveniently enough the owners weren't available for comment:
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/12/26/FD05U08SL.DTL
author: Nicolas H.

description:
I guess its a little pricey for what you get.  The food is good but not fantastic.  I'm getting real picky nowadays.  Yelp isn't helping to discourage this characteristic trait.

There's a pretty pleasant environment here.  Its classy enough for a date and casual enough for a quick bite.

I'd rather spend my money elsewhere but won't be devastated if I have to go here again.
author: Chester R.

description:
Koh Samui is really beautiful, with some incredible Buddha artwork.  I especially love the Buddha fountain, which divides the bar from the restaurant.  I always, always order green or yellow curry, so I can only comment on those two dishes -- they are the tastiest curries in the city.  

However, I would really like to know what is up with the creepy and sad 'Lost Dog' framed adverts all over the bathroom.  I found this so bizarre I tried to pry one from the wall to bring back to the table as show-and-tell, but they are firmly super-glued to the wall.  You must go to this restaurant just to check out this twilight zone experience in the bathrooms!

As an added bonus, street parking here is always very easy to find.
author: Kimberly B.

description:
I had a really yummy sea bass clay pot stir fried with vermicelli noodles and napa cabbage. I was actually pleasantly surprised, having had a so-so experience at its now closed sister restaurant, Citizen Thai and The Monkey. The sea bass was extremely tender and flaky, with a perfect buttery flavor.

I'm docking 2 stars bc the fried apps probably could've been better, as chichi thai food, it's pricier than it should be, and I'm taking into account my food at the sister restaurant which was subpar.
author: serena l.

description:
Was up in the city today and went to lunch with my bro....we decided upon Thai food and came upon this restaurant.  Nice selection.  We had the Seabass lunch special.  While the portions were somewhat small, the fish was tasty as it was cooked in a curry base with vegetables and served with rice.  

This place does get pretty packed and we happened to have gone in at about 11:30 before the rush, so plan accordingly.

It also looked like there was a good selection of different dishes and I have to go back to try some of the others meals.

Overall, it was a good experience....food, service and ambience was nice.
author: Kurt W.

description:
This is a nicer upscale Thai restaurant.

1) Atmosphere is nice - great for birthday gatherings and nice occasions.
2) Fancy drinks
3) Friendly and professional staff
4) Pumpkin Curry that's to die for!!  This is where I discovered great curry.
author: Gina K.

description:
There are 2 reasons for me taking off that one star. They were out of the Thai Iced tea by 9 pm when we reached there and the portions were not as big as I would have thought.
The food was excellent, not one of the best Thai places I have ever been to... Chicago had a better one. We started off with the Thai fish cakes and the papaya salad. Both were excellent. This was followed by the Pad Thai and the shrimp and cashew nut wok. Overall the food itself was very tasty, and flavorful staff was extremely friendly and accommodating. The ambiance is cool too with lots of Thai antiques and dim lighting. Definitely going to be one of the go-to places when I don't feel like cooking.
author: Pooja S.

description:
The quality of food is great and the reason customers pay premium for their thai food.  Problem: the service.  I live in South Beach/SOMA with about 10+ different thai restaurants around the neighborhood and I have to say that Koh Samui and the monkey has one of the best quality food.  But the owner must learn to hire better staff.  The person who answers the phone to take orders or reservation sounds incompetent and half of the time messes up the carry out order. I would have ordered from here more often despite the more expensive menu had the person on the other line been more professional and validat orders before hanging up the phone.  I was just here for dinner tonight at 6:30 when restaurants was half empty and yet it took a long time for the first round of drinks to arrive.  then when our party ordered a 2nd round of drinks to compliment our entrees (restaurant still quite empty), they never arrived.  We were just about done with our dinner and asked the waitress to cancel the drinks, that was when she finally said the drinks were coming...we were too nice to agree to the '5 min' wait. but still the drinks didn't come for another 20 minutes.  We literally were drinking after all the food were gone..and we kind of expected she at least would apologize or give us some discount even just $5 as a 'nice' gesture...like we care about that for a $130 meal.  but no, the check arrived quickly, and she picked up the credit card quicker than she had every paid attention to us throughout the entire meal.  no discount and no apologies. we were still gracious enough to give her a 10% tip even thouhgh she really deserved nothing.  She only came by the within the first 10 minutes of our meal and that was it.

Owner of the restaurant  - please read these reviews.  the food is AWESOME!  Kitchen staff is excellent.  however, half of your staff and service need to be changed/improved. unlike  Osha Thai - their food is not good as yours but they are efficient and the service is impeccable!!  the reason they are getting all the customers in this area in South Beach ahd SOMA (and the reason the are still profitable after opening up 3 chain locations all within a few miles in this area).  you need to interview and train your staff more carefully and get the right folks to work for you.  then you will see the difference.  I go to Osha all the time for their efficiency, customer service and I know if the same situation happened at any of their locations tonight, the GM would have came to apologize offering half o the meal on the house.

good luck with the business. this is San francisco - we expect great food (it's a given) and most importantly, customer serivce and you certainly need to train your staff better.
author: wen y.

description:
I come here mostly for their to-go counter at lunch and haven't been disappointed yet.  The good stuff goes quickly, unfortunately, so I have to be here before 1:00 or it's not worth it.  Pad Thai is always a go-to.

I've only eaten here for dinner once, and that was because of an open-table deal.  Certainly good food, but I wouldn't want to come here full-price too often.  Bags of gold were good, and everything else wasn't too memorable after the few months it's been since we went.

On the whole, solid Thai food, highly recommend the lunch counter, but out of my budget for regular dinning.
author: Lea G.

description:
3.75 stars.

i've always enjoyed my meals at koh samui and their previous sister restaurant, citizen thai.  my go to is usually the sea bass with green curry.  sea bass is melt in your mouth. most of the other dishes i've tried have been really enjoyable and they offer some different items you wouldn't normally see on a regular thai menu.
author: Helen T.

description: Food was good but ambiance was quite horrible.  Tables were too crowded together.  We ended up too close between two other parties, who were incredibly loud.
author: Tracy H.

description:
Not in the prettiest locations. It's not horrible, but you just wouldn't think good eats by the looks of the outside. But, walking in, I couldn't think the place was cuter. The hostess was dressed in a traditional Thai dress and the rest of the waiters were dressed very according to the decor. I felt like I was in a total different place.

Service was very polite. A little unattentive which could have been due to the heavy lunch rush of the city. But, they were very nice and did the best they could. I couldn't complain.

Almost everything had a spicy warning, which I'm not a fan of. But, it definitely wasn't too bad. The food was very tasteful and light. I didn't feel like I was eating for a whole family, as I usually do. Portion control! That's what I feel a lot of restaurants lack in. It's good that they give you enough food, but really...I don't need to eat like a pig on a quick lunch date in the middle of the week. So this place does a good job of giving you just enough.The rice was a little old/dry tasting. But, that could just be my rice snob coming out. Overall, very good and I would definitely come back.
author: Jon C.

description: A group of coworkers headed here for lunch. We'd called ahead and made a reservation knowing that this place is usually busy. After waiting about 15 minutes past our reservation time, we were finally led to a table that was not big enough to seat all of us. We informed the hostess of this, and she then led us back out to the waiting area, where we waited for another 10 minutes before finally getting sat at a large table THAT HAD BEEN OPEN THE ENITER TIME. 35 minutes into our lunch break, we were finally at a table. 5 minutes later, our drink and food orders were taken. I'll admit this openly: I'm not huge on Asian cuisine. So consider the source on the following food review. For the price, I felt  like the portions and quality were quite poor. For $11, I had like 5 small strips of battered chicken in a tangy sauce and a few pieces of onions and peppers over a medium scoop of rice on a (guessing) 6" plate. For $11, you better bring a full damn plate and that plate had better be bigger than my fist! I have not tried their lunch to-go buffet option, but with my general disinterest in the style of cuisine, I'm not feeling like that will happen anytime soon.  I'll pass.  Thanks anyway.
author: Lance H.

description:
i love the decor of this place!  the food isn't bad either.  
i often came here for lunch since i worked up the block.  it does often get busy during lunch, however the wait isn't so bad.
the prices are okay but on the higher side.  i've had better thai food elsewhere but since i can't really take too long of a lunch, this place will have to do.
author: Serena L.

description: I was impressed! The place looked elegant, and the food was great! I went there on a Sunday for a friends's birthday dinner then came back on Monday for another dinner.
author: Adrian D.

description: Koh Samui is best for lunch---the food is not always consistent.
author: Wendy B.

description: We came here on a whim when there was a 45 minute wait at the restaurant we intended to eat at. We pretty much picked it because it's called "The Monkey". The ambiance is really nice, another high-end Thai restaurant! Pricey but the food was good. We ordered fresh spring rolls, "bags of gold", a spinach duck dish, pumpkin curry, and mango beef. All the dishes were great. Also, the pumpkin curry comes in a pumpkin! The servers were all very friendly and attentive.
author: Jamie W.

description:
(Edited to reflect terrible experience.) - I used to really love this place, but the last time I went, they took nearly twenty minutes to tell me they were out of my noodles, and then they gave me the wrong dish. Just as I was about to chomp down on that, they whisked the dish away and gave me the correct dish ten minutes later. I was given a free Thai iced coffee, which would have been great except for the fact that I DON'T DRINK coffee. The dish I had was also way over-salted, so much so that I could barely choke it down.

Expensive for Thai food.  On the other hand, I love the decor, and the waiters' uniforms.  The food in general is good, but not amazing.  I love the imperial rolls, and their noodle soups are excellent.  Their seafood clay pot was one of the highlights of one of my visits - huge, almost overflowing, and filled with lots of different types of fish and crustaceans.
author: kimberly l.

description:
I am gonna start out by saying that I don't really like Thai food.  This place, I LOVE!!

I have only been here for lunch & go back repeatedly.  They meet my major lunch criteria:
1. close to office
2. tasty
3. cheap

In addition, the decor is great & the service is very efficient.
author: Charlene E.

description:
Decent take-out that didn't blow me away.  Not a lot on the menu is vegetarian, but they say they can make anything vegetarian.  When we phoned in our order, though, the special I wanted was unavailable for carry out.

Deduct one star.  I'll try them again, though.
author: Apollo L.

description:
This Thai place is one of SOMA's better restaurants in terms of food quality.  The spring rolls are quite good, though the best of the appetizers is probably the grilled corn cakes.  I've had duck- and pork-based entrees here, and both were excellent.  The grilled pork comes with a sweet sauce that complements the tart mango salad quite well.  The bartender can make a decent mojito, as well.

I highly recommend this place and will certainly go back.
author: Rajiv B.

description:
My parents were visiting, their first time in San Francisco, and I took them here. Some San Franciscans swear by Thai food and the food here probably isn't the best Thai in the city. I knew this beforehand too; I hadn't been to many Thai places and was more interested in the elegant atmosphere that I knew they have here.

I'm not sure how the food compares to other Thai restaurants but it was good enough for me. It came really quick too which was a plus. We didn't have the best server which cost them a star. At one point he mixed up an order and brought us someone else's food.
author: Joshua G.

description:
aka Monkey Thai. awesome offerings. GREAT food plus great chopsticks. plus plus. miniature, beautiful tiny food replicas! Neat bathroom papered with lost dog, cat, and sandwich bulletins.

note to veggies -- strong offerings in the meatless style, here.
author: John M.

description:
Price-shmice, when it comes to the food quality, I've never had anything at this place that wasn't tasty and good.

I've come here many times, for lunch, dinner, with cow orkers and friends, and no one has ever gotten anything that was sub-par.
author: Asya K.

description:
I hate to see a place start to slide, but it is happening.

The food used to be better, and there are still some hits.  The pumpkin curry still rocks.

Still love the atmosphere, except, what's with the TV's, do I need to see the Giant's loose again while I am out to dinner?

Service, eh, not a strong point.  Quality of food, like I said, used to be better.  I would suggest Grand Pooh Ba before here, or Basil.
author: Ken p.

description:
So as any good yelper, I checked out some of the reviews below before heading off to this place and...yes, the sweet corn patties were exactly the doughey deep-fried delicious I was hoping for. Other items on the evening line-up:

- Duck noodle soup: sweet, tasty, and loaded with chunky good stuff.
- Pumpkin curry: though a bit on the bland side, they do have really nice detailed presentation (this particular dish was served in an actual pumpkin shell with monkey carvings).
- Litchi martini: each drink comes with plastic monkeys hanging off the sides! 
- Sticky rice: beware of the extra layer of seram wrap - that resistant reflective sheen is not just the rice being "super sticky".

Our server was very attentive and the service wasn't too slow. The interior is exotically decorated too. All in all, this is a great get-together place for drinks with the girls and romantic enough for a semi-casual date, but maybe take a pass if you're feeling picky with the palette.
author: Kathleen K.

description:
If I were to rate Koh Samui & the Monkey based on my most recent visit on Thursday, it would be 1 or 2 stars, but I'm giving it 3 based on past visits there. Overall my sense of the restaurant has been tasty and even sometimes unusual Thai food (and I've tasted a lot of Thai food in the city), in a more upscale atmosphere with GREAT cocktails -- that is if you can get your cocktails. On Thursday we waited (and I'm not exaggerating at all) over and hour to get our cocktails. Our previous visits this year have been slow with the cocktails and service but not quite that slow!! Definitely order your second round the second your first round comes! 

Food service was almost as slow, though it did seem that our server really was doing his best. The hold up was probably the kitchen and, in the case of the cocktails, the rookie bartender -- we were told. After all the waiting and waiting for drinks and foods, the wait staff who brought out the food almost literally threw the plates at us (and threw the wrong plates at the wrong people) and wouldn't address our confusion. "This doesn't look like Pad Thai. Is this his beef curry," I asked only to receive a blank reply.

My pad thai was totally forgettable. The curry dishes are more flavorful. 

Given our bad experience, we asked to speak to the manager and complained. He comped us our drinks, which was very nice and took responsibility for the problem. His professionalism probably made the difference between never eating there again and giving it another try in a few months.
author: Mark V.

description:
This is a great place for lunch.  They have awesome Pad Thai noodles and curry.  

Pro: Food is excellent.
Con: Portions are a bit skimpy.  My Pad Thai noodles were actually served over a big bed of beans sprouts.  I hate bean sprouts and they were not supposed to be in the dish that I ordered.

I'd love to come check this out for dinner and drinks!
author: Spicy T.

description: Tasty  affordable and excellent customer service. Very clean. They don't accept American Express.
author: yira e.

description: Good Thai food just & ambiance, just a bit pricey.  I went here since Groupon offered a deal. Good for a date, etc, but I'll stick the the authentic hole in the wall Thai spots. If you like Osha, you'll probably like this spot.
author: Nazli P.

description: Wanted this food experience to be a good one, but with the wide array of Thai to choose from this one drops way down the list. From the start the staff was friendly enough, but distracted from the entrance to the dining room - aside from bus service staff that was actually more attentive right down to keeping water glasses filled. Waitress actually forgot that we had just ordered drinks 10 minutes earlier when she came to take our dinner order (note that the room was only about 40% capacity). Appetizers were quick to come (with a rushed thump on the table and a description of the "dropped off" items on her way from our table practically. Mains came nearly 20 minutes after that clearly some dishes had been waiting for others (we ordered three dishes) and temperature-wise they showed it. For the food . . . fish cakes - over-salted, calamari steak - a take on fried rings and less than successful, pumpkin curry - where the heck was the pumpkin or did the chef mix up chicken for the pumpkin?, basil pork belly that was sadly lacking in some called . . . BASIL!, and . . . Pad Thai (something that should be a no-brainer get it right) and it did the best of the lot, but marginally. Biggest overall food issue was over-salting the dishes to the point where the spice is taking a back seat. Wait staff needed to be flagged down for cleanup and service after we watched a previously seated family of three get served and finished up and out fifteen minuted faster than us. Mixed bag this place at best, and not worth another pass unfortunately. Head out to the RIchmond or Sunset for a truer Thai food experience.
author: Tristan C.

description: Food was okay, bar tender nice, but the ladies standing in front waiting to seat you.... TERRIBLE. Enough to ruin my appetite.
author: Miss G.

description: Went here for lunch on a weekday - which was great.  We were seated right away.  Co-worker and I both had one of their lunch specials which came with crispy imperial rolls, a curry dish and sticky rice.  We also had a glass of wine and I think the bill was barely over $20.  Plenty of food, I polished mine off, co-worker couldn't finish hers.  That, topped with the decor and friendly service makes me a fan.
author: Matt L.

description: Great food.... Probably the best Thai food I had.  All the waiters and waitress wearing thai's traditional outfit.  wow!  Okay, back to the food.  The food here are expensive for Thai food. My personally favorite is the pumpkin curry.  It's hella good!
author: Mikey D.

description:
While this isn't the best Thai food I've had in my life it's pretty good.  Imperial Rolls along with Pumpkin Chicken Curry are worth ordering.  I went on a Saturday night at around 7:30ish, so parking was a breeze.  But I can imagine parking would be a nightmare if you wanted to go during lunch or after work.  

I think this place is better than its sister restaurant Citizen Thai and the Monkey.
author: Josh B.

description:
May get prize for most uncomfortable chairs ever (big heavy flat wooden chairs), dinner lighting could be considered romantic

Great
- madame sea bass, exceptional (+ the veg and the green curry are great)

Ok 
- fish cakes
- larb gai
- roast duck in red curry
- singha beer on draft, thai ice tea, melon mojito, red wine

No go
- papaya salad
- chicken and veg
- chicken satay

To try 
- po sod (some kind of spring roll)

The place gets quite busy for lunch, dinner should be ok
author: xo x.

description:
I love thai food, but I was not impressed.  I can't even recall what I ordered, or what the other two people I ate with ordered.  I remember saltiness and grossness, and not finishing my food, and wanting to walk across to Brickhouse for a burger instead.

Service was bad, it took ten days to get water (and that's with five requests), and it wasn't even busy at the time we were there (lunch).

Friends of mine have allegedly  heard good things, but I won't be going back.
author: Kristen H.

description:
Me no likie... I'm not a huge fan of food with peanuts in it. Just about everything on the menu has peanuts or is cooked with peanut oil or has some special peanut sauce on it. But, if you're a fan, you may like it. 

Our service wasn't the best either.
author: Rebecca J.

description:
http://www.kohsamuiandthemonkey.com/

Website is well done and slick...now to the food...

Atmosphere:  I've only been here for business lunches.  If you are there around Noon or so, the place is busy.  If you show after 1, you may have the place to yourself and thus easy to talk.  Mix of tech folks and middle managers running around at lunch time.

Food:  One dish does is right for me - Pumpkin Curry in Red Sause...if you haven't had Pumpkin Curry, you must.  It's unique like the Pumpkin Ale you get in winter.  It has some kick to it too.

Sometimes you have to go backwards to go forward...appetizers - Chicken Satay in the peanut sauce...I could drink that stuff...

Dessert: Get the Fried Banana with Coconut Ice Cream.  I am not into Coconut anything (drank from the Coconut itself in Mexico/Hawaii, did nothing for me...maybe I needed the lime...) but this combo is deadly.

Comparison?  Next to Basil, I'd chose Basil first, but this is a close 2nd.
author: Mike B.

description:
My first experience here after my gf was looking on Yelp for a new Thai place to try.  I was very hungry and grumpy but I was down to try it out.  Looking from the outside in I thought it was a Shi-Shi place.  The prices didn't look too bad from the menu.  So we ordered the imperial rolls, spicy chicken w/ basil, green curry w/ beef, and garlic shrimp.  The Imperial rolls were presented in a unique style. It was log cabin style!  They didnt taste any different tho.  The Garlic Shrimp was very good but the portions are on the light side.  The spicy chicken and curry were good but nothing to die for.  

In hindsight, this restaurant is great for a girls night out dinner.  It isnt made for the blue collared guy with a good appetite.  The decor and presentation is great but I don't see anything here that makes me scream eat here. My girlfriend loves the place making me think, this place is more for the women.  One point of interest would be the happy hour between 5-7pm.  I am sure the appetizers and drinks would be a great bargain.
author: ed c.

description:
I just got back. The decorations in the restaurant are pretty nice, the service was good, they refilled my water very often which I always appreciate. The air conditioning seemed to be blowing full force into my freshly shaved head so I was pretty cold.

We ordered larb gai, pad thai and the sizzling seafood platter. I love larb, and it lived up to my expectations but the portion was a little small. The sizzling platter was sizzling, as advertised, and included various types of seafood including some crab, squid, shrimp and scallops. The sauce it was in was good. The pad thai was fine, nothing notable. Also they were playing some dance/techno music, thankfully not too loud.

The food was acceptable, the prices are a little high but thats partially for the ambiance.
author: Nathan M.

description:
We were craving pumpkin curry, it was as if a spell had been cast over us and lunch without it would've caused us dire pain. So, we trekked the three blocks to Koh Samui & the Monkey, since I'd heard about it for so long.

Now, it took them a while to finally get to our table to take the order, but other than that I would say that the sweetness level of the staff was super sweet. The food came out in a reasonable time and it was hot and YUM. 

We also got the Pad Se Ew, which had the widest noodles ever, holy majollie. 

We got out of there jst as the place was gonna be packed to the nines, it was as if the stars had lined up just for us, and then said, "Thank you for being you."
author: J. Scott H.

description:
I am a fan.  Since moving to the area I haven't found a Thai restaurant that I "loved".  This is a wonderful spot to have some really good quality food.  Not too mention the ambiance of the location.  Beautifully decorated. Lit candles  all along the walls (very romantic).  The service was good and prompt.

VEggie Friendly: Very!  Try the green curry and papaya salad.  Oh!  The Thai ice tea is delicious (except the short straw didn't reach the bottom of the tall glass :-D)  But, hey I still give it 5 stars.
author: ashley l.

description:
This place is great for both lunch and dinner. Lunch service delivers quality food quickly so you can get in and out and back to the office with in an hour. Diner is relaxed.   

The restaurant is warm and inviting and the staff is always friendly.  Food is great and they offer a wide selection of great food.
author: Brian K.

description:
We went there for a dinner on Friday evening. I tried their bar and the bartender was not very friendly. Their wine list was quite surprizingly nice.

We ordered the appetizers, and they were great however the quantity was very small compared to the price we pay. The main course food was amazing. The taste is authentic and very succulant. The Thai spices were well mixed and all the dishes were good.
author: Ankur J.

description:
what we ordered...crispy imperial rolls, grilled bankok bbq chicken and madame sea bass

...the place is uppity and you do see it in your bill. service and presentation was ok. 

...crispy imperial roll was good and the madame sea bass was exceptional, it's sweetness, spicyness and light curry sauce just morphed into a perfect goodness dish. now you may be wondering why the heck am i rating this a 1 STAR.... well, they served me a precooked dish, if i am paying top dollar for something, you better serve me quality with no monkey trick's.
the bbq chicken was ok but possibly grilled way early in the morning or a leftover the night before. a trick is a trick and i bet that monkey is still inside that kitchen. 

ahhhhhhh!  i will miss that darn curry dish...
author: Gors P.

description: This is one of my favorite Thai restaurants, they make excellent food and take great care of their customers! An all time favorite and one of the best Thai restaurants in the CITY!
author: Peter G.

description: definitely love this place! me, wifey, boston biggie (in the car) had lunch here for a friend's bday. I've had Thai food from all around the Bay but so far this is the best I've had. I mean the soft shell crab in roast garlic I almost beat my wifey over the head for the last bite and Boston Biggie was giving me the eye bc he couldn't have any. i like the atmosphere and the decor is straight from Thailand. Parking is hard to find but it's SOMA where is it easy? Price is good, you can talk about service and all that but I'm really down for the food. i didn't get the bad service some ppl might have but u know could have been someone's off day.. These guys definitely have their A+ game on. I will definitely go back and also recommend friends and family to have dinner here in the future... yeah the fried oysters help with the monkey business!! hahah..
author: Michael T.

description: I can just order the Bags of Gold for appetizer and go home.  It's my favorite thing to order on the menu.  Their creme brulee is really good too it has a hint of lavender in it.
author: amber c.

description:
What a waste of money, time and fuel! A friend (who probably ate here a LONG time ago) recommended it, and we went despite the crappy recent ratings. Now we've tried our hand at some thai dishes, and let me tell you -- this restaurant has the unenviable talent of rendering even the easiest and tastiest dishes bland and inedible. There are simply too many good thai restaurants in SF to waste your time and money here.
The service staff was reasonably nice, when they did finally make an appearance.
author: Godot -.

description:
We come here for lunch lots during the week. It's a nice treat after a week full of sandwiches and salads.

The service is quick and the food is delicious in a tasteful atmosphere. I highly recommend the chicken pumpkin curry--it's my favorite dish. Otherwise the BBQ chicken is good, and the summer rolls are a great starter. 

I wish the hot tea cups were bigger and less awkward (they're in the shape of elephants).
author: sarah s.

description:
I really like this place.  I generally stop by a couple times a month for take out for myself and my guy. But I always get the same 3 dishes..garlic cashew chicken, coconut soup, some beef dish - consistently good and works for me. I like the atmosphere as well.  Even when busy, you can have a conversation and the lighting is just warm.  Great first date place.  If I go, I usually take my own wine so not too sure of wine list.  Parking is easy on most evenings.

Update:  I went on a Saturday night and it was ridiculously loud.  May have been the table of  guys in a twitter about something and we're serious "ON" that night.  This is was first Saturday night there so just fyi.  Other nights have been very cool.
author: anna l.

description:
Average overall- the dinner entrees were nothing outstanding- (the pumpkin curry is better at citizen thai). 

worth nothing though are some of the appetizers.  the Imperal rolls are intreresting stacked like a log cabin.  The bags of gold had a nice decor for it and the Mieng Kum (chicken satay) was something new and unique that stood out from other thai spots in the city.
author: Ken S.

description:
Usually in SF restaurants, you're in and out so quickly, you tend to forget what you ate.  At Koh Samui, it's almost the same thing, except in this case, it takes so long to order and then get your food, you may forget what you ordered or what you just ate.  The industrial space is beautifully decorated, sort of a Thai restaurant with a SOMA-loft flavor. The hostess definitely did not seem to grasp the concept of multi-tasking.  She was on the phone, apparently taking a (really looong) phone order or reservation, and she couldn't be bothered to look up to acknowledge our existence (nor the 2 other parties that showed up in the next 5 minutes). 

The food was good, but as someone else said, a bit on the sweet side.  The MIENG KUM appetizer was good, but it wasn't well explained on the menu, and it was so loud in the restaurant, we could barely understand the server's explanation of the dish.  It was spinach leaves covered with the described ingredients  (dried coconut, lime, etc.); it felt more like a dessert (due to the coconut) than an appetizer.  We also had the sea bass clay pot (delicious), the pumpkin curry (good, but too sweet and, while the pumpkin as a bowl is indeed a pretty presentation, the actual amount of chicken and pumpkin was exceedingly skimpy), and the grilled pork (really good).  

Koh Samui is definitely a cool restaurant with pretty good Thai food.  As long as you go there wit the expectation of a slow dining experience, you should have a good time.
author: a t.

description: I'd give them half a star if I could. Took 20 minutes to get our drinks after ordering. The batter on the calamari was too thick and had no flavor. The fish cakes were too salty and inedible. We ordered the chicken pumpkin curry, which was luke warm and had only three small pieces of pumpkin. It was mostly overcooked chicken pieces. The pork belly basil was very greasy. Dishes took forever to come out even though the place was not crowded at the time. It was just a horrible experience. There was nothing authentic about it.  For authentic Thai food, go to Thai Time on 8th Avenue near Clement, or Marnee Thai.
author: A L.

description:
Love the food here. The portions got small a year or two ago but they seem a little bigger again. Love the bartenders, they are really friendly and good at coming up with good drinks. A few of the newer servers seem a little awkward but some of the old pros are really good. It seemed really loud last time we were there, more than usual, but it wasn't packed. 
Especially yummy: pumpkin curry, spicy tofu, one of the soups.
author: Patty W.

description: food was great.  Just enough spice to it to make it hot.  pad thai was great and the curry was a huge hit.  My wife and I were seated at a corner table, it was bright enough to see but romantic.  It seemed a bit noisy as there was a big group of people seated several tables away but not too bad.  The staff were efficent and professional.  They called us a cab after dinner, which was nice.
author: Max B.

description:
Koh Samui is good but very run-of-the mill thai. They have all the typical thai foods you could ask for and a fairly extensive beer and drink menu, but I've had much better, more authentic thai at smaller less extravagant places (like Best of Thai in the Haight and Marnee Thai in Inner Sunset.)

We ordered the Fresh Spring Rolls ($9) and the Stuffed Mushrooms with Peanut Sauce ($4). The spring rolls were average as could be though the stuffed mushrooms quite good. As a group we ordered family style: the Prawns and cashew nuts ($14) was the least favorite. The Pad Thai Chicken ($12) was below average.The Steamed salmon with Panang curry sauce ($13) was perhaps the best dish- it was flavorful and a unique use of panang with Salmon.

The best thing Koh Samui has going for it it's location- compared to restaurants in the area it's one of the better ones, but in a city of great thai food it ranks low.
author: Allison S.

description: I really like the atmosphere here; the restaurant is clean, well-decorated, and "hip - a good nighttime spot pre-going out, for instance. There are a few commendable go-to dishes that we always order: the beef satay, fried rice, garlic noodles are a few off the top of my head but the menu is unfortunately hit or miss. Thankfully, there's a swanky bar to make up for it.
author: Lilian W.

description:
We were there to celebrate the art showing for a friend of ours, the artist, the star of the night.

The wait is not bad - quite reasonable for a saturday.  no long lines.
The food is fantastic.
The service is shit.  We had the cute white girl that smiled at us and hoped that that made everything okay when they screwed up our order and we waited about 1 hr for our food whilst everyone else around us got served first.  They comped the dessert but it was more waiting.  By the time the check came, we felt even more aggravation and frustration.  Our star at the table had already darkened. The restaurant was not even entirely full by then. :P

Will I go back?  maybe.  only if i get a different hostess.
author: tc h.

description: My local Thai food restaurant near my work.  Pretty busy spot with tables put too close to each other, that it can be a little hard to walk through if you want to head back to the restroom.  And if its a packed house, it can get really noisy and warm.  I had to read my friend's lips in order to understand what she was telling me.  So let's talk about the food.  Not bad, but the serving size is a little small.  I ordered the wonton soup and was happy with it.  It had cabbage, spinach, bean sprouts, Chinese BBQ pork, egg noodles and 3-4 wontons.  Love that it had such a variety of stuff in it.  My cousin had the red curry and it was kind of small.  He said it tasted ok, but lacked veggies.  My friend had the asparagus with shrimp and she was impressed with the asparagus.  That it was cooked perfectly, and the best she has had in a while.  And my other friend was eating the spare ribs and the chicken eggplant, and enjoyed it too.  Overall, not bad, but now let's talk about the service.  The have 3 on the floor and usually one bus boy.  The dude waiter is not very attentive and cordial like the ladies.  Asked for hot sauce and never got it.  And he tried to rush us to leave and immediately gave us our check after we finished, not ever bothering to ask if we wanted dessert.  So overall, I suggest the tables not be so packed, open more windows when it gets crowded, re-train the dude and maybe make the serving size a tad bigger and it will rock the house.  For now, its just A-OK.
author: Janice F.

description: Pretty disappointing.   The food here is really sweet tasting, and not very authentic . Hah the thai food in Walnut Creek of all places is better than this.  You are much better off eating at king of thai noodle and saving a bunch of cash for drinks elsewhere.
author: Hugh G.

description: I can't stop ordering the pumpkin curry to try anything else. This pumpkin curry is sooo good I have to drive almost 2 hours for it.
author: Suzanne T.

description: Unbelievable food with unbelievable service. This place really has unique tasting food. I would come here again without giving it second thought. I recommend trying the bass curry. Delicious.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
Simple but tasty.  I had the Pad See-ew with soft shell crab.  I also sampled some of the yellow curry which had a nice amount of spice.

Waiters fumbled a little bit, forgetting some appetizers for our table, but were very quick to respond and deliver the goods (believe it or not, that is good service)

I'll definitely go there again at some point.
author: Sean M.

description:
Blech Blech Yuck! 

I ordered a salad - a steak one, tooooo salty like way tooo salty.  

Thai iced tea - tooo watery

Service - GREAT!
author: Swiyyah W.

description:
I really like this place, although I am a huge Thai fan in general.  I think it's nice without being over the top and although it isn't the cheapest place, it's still reasonable.  I've been there twice and have enjoyed delicious food both times.

The service has always been quick and attentive.  I've always been able to get in and out in a reasonable amount of time.

The curries and Thai samosas have always been delicious... anyway, am a fan :-)
author: Ryan M.

description: Service was great, and the food was filling and tasty. I had the chicken eggplant, and my only complaint was that the veggies were a bit mushy.
author: Rachel Q.

description: Koh Samui is your basic Thai place but with nice decor and a decent happy hour.  Pad thai was a little on the dry side, but other dishes are pretty decent and prices are reasonable for SOMA.
author: Maxine S.

description: Great dishes.  I strongly recommend the Madame Sea Bass in green curry.  The service was decent.  Wish they came around sooner a couple times considering we had a baseball game to get to and the restaurant wasn't especially busy at the time.
author: Brent P.

description: Solid, well seasoned Thai food in a clean environment.  We arrived  early (6:00), and there were only about  4 other parties at tables.  Our service was very attentive and respectful from both wait and kitchen staff.  We had Green Papaya Salad, Corn Fritters, Pumpkin Curry, and the Asian Beef.  All the dishes were seasoned beautifully, and layers of spice and heat kept coming through during the meal.  We are anxious to try the Other Monkey as well.
author: John K.

description:
I've been temping down the street from this place. It's really nice inside, although, I took my orders to go, so I didn't really get the whole experience. It'd be nice to check out for dinner sometime. 

So far, I've had a couple of lunches from there. 
Day 1 - Pumpkin Curry. It was delish. A good mix of squash and whatever protein of your choice. I had tofu. Nice and firm. All went well with the basmati rice. 
Day 2 - Tom Ka Gai (chicken/coconut soup) & Fresh Spring Rolls. The soup was very very sweet, compared to other Tom Kas I've had before. The rolls were excellent. The skins were not rubbery and the filling was very fresh and tasty. Although, the dipping sauce was more of a sweet/sour sauce rather than a pea-nutty sauce. 

Overall, so far, I'd say this place has good quality food. It's fresh and just the right proportions. I'd like to try it again sometime, but dine in.
author: Sandi B.

description:
I had ordered the Happy Monkey Pack ($12.95) which comes with a side dish, a noodle or rice dish, and a Thai ice tea.  The fried roll was decent.  But the Pad Sew Wee (rice flat noodle) was quite mediocre; sweeter then I have been used to, oily, not well mixed,..and the chicken had funny taste to it.  I also tried some of their Mango salad, which was decently good.   I saw a few other interesting dishes, and may consider visiting again in the future to try them.  

On a positive note, I did like the decor  and paint colors.  I also thought their bathroom wall decor with picture frames of various lost animal signs were quite cute...the only bad taste was that there were a few signs in the girl's restroom that reads something like this: "ladies, please do not remove what is not yours.".....
author: iris w.

description:
This restaurant is down the street from my place.  Me and the GF have been there several times, and we always leave feeling like we should have went somewhere else. 

I went through the list of reasons today and thought I would write them up:
  
   * Service is spotty at best
   * Seafood is worse than the service (how can frozen shrimp be bad you ask?)
   * Runny, bland curries
   * Bland tom yam soup
   * No dry curries
   * Inflexible kitchen sometimes (not to me, but heard them tell the table next to me that they wouldn't put tofu instead of chicken, couldn't believe it)
   * Pad Thai has more ketchup than peanut sauce
   * Horrible green place settings suck out your soul
   * Plastic chopsticks
   
The hair in the crappy pad thai was the last straw for us....
author: John S.

description: Loved this place. Eggplant with tofu & basil was delicious. Chicken basil was good too. And the 2 desserts we tried were yumm - sticky rice with mango and coconut ice cream with mango sorbet. Decor is very elegant. Nice big windows for natural light.
author: Gagan T.

description:
Drinks are strong and tasty, but our waitress took mine away before I was finished... granted there was only a couple sips left, but when the drink is only abt 10 sips in the first place... couple sips can make a difference.. ok. maybe not :P   
ANYWAYS... the place was only half full, but it was really loud for the number of people there, I can't imagine the noise level when the place is full.They also filled the WHOLE place with tables.  It was like a maze trying to get to our table.  I have no idea how people would get by if the chairs actually had people in them.  
The food ... the eggplant and tofu was tasty but seemed to lacking in quantity.  The seabass clay pot was disappointing.  The extra stuff in the dish had more taste than the sea bass.  Plus, I bit into a chunk of sand.  This is kind of gross, but later that night before I brushed my teeth, a chunk of the sand dislodged from my teeth and my boy friend looked at me in horror and thought I was eating a tooth filling.  Needless to say I had nightmares abt the fillings in my teeth falling out and having no teeth  :P
author: Karena L.

description: The crispy tofu was delicious and this place has a nice atmosphere, and friendly and efficient service. But I can only give three stars because the BBQ chicken was nothing special, and more importantly, prices are outrageous for most of the menu. Some items are literally double what you'd expect to pay at a comparable Thai place. I don't plan on going back.
author: Geoffrey U.

description:
I love it i love it i love it. Whether eat-in or take-out, this is consistently delish. 
Excellent, tasty food, fabulous restaurant/atmosphere, good for groups, birthdays, and equally efficient at getting take-out prepared. 
Curries, coconut soup, spicy tofu, sea bass curry are all firm favourites amongst my group
A stable in my book...
author: Em S.

description:
Great value in a hip and elegant dining room. I took a date there after an event and we were pleased with the beautiful interior. Service was friendly but inattentive. One of our appetizers we had to special order with the coconut shavings put off to the side due to an allergy, and when the dish arrived it had coconut all over the plate. The server graciously took the plate and we ordered fried calamari with sweet and sour sauce instead. Much better choice. The clay pot is delicious! Give it a try.

Affordable Thai food in a beautiful atmosphere. Great place for a date.
author: Foodie F.

description:
Another wonderful resto from my 'hood!  Although, I'll agree with other reviewers that the decorum struggles to find balance on the fine line of trendy and cheesy and it can be tough to find parking.  Note: if the Giants are playing, forget about it!  On to what matters, though...the food!!!
 
For starters (see what I did there - kind of a double entendre, no?), you can't go wrong with the "bag of gold."   Or, if you feel like going the non-fried route (what are you doing at an Asian restaurant?!) I'd recommend the "fresh spring roll."  The Tom Ka Gai (coconut soup) is refreshing and flavorful without being overwhelmingly sweet or coconut-esque.  

On to the main event(s)...The "fire cracker seafood sizzling hot plate" is delish!  Prawns, squid, scallops, and crab claws with a spicy peanut sauce - a must try!!  The Penang Neur (stewed beef) and Kang Dang Ped (honey-roasted duck and pineapple) are two of the better Thai curry dishes I've had in my illustrious gastronomic career.   Also, you get the option of steamed jasmine, brown, coconut or sticky rice, which is kinda neat!

Oh, and this is definitely a point of personal preference, but in my humble opinion nothing accompanies Thai food quite like an Argentinian Malbec, which they just so happen to offer by the glass of bottle.  Points awarded!
author: Johnny P.

description:
This is probably my most frequented restaurant in SOMA - good food, good price.  Plenty of other places with great food but you also get to pay for that privilege.

The building exterior isn't much to speak of - it's easy to walk right past this place without knowing it's a restaurant.  The first time we went, that's exactly what happened.  The inside has a definite southeast Asian theme to it, including requisite Buddhas and elephants.

All the food I've tried there is very good, though I've had better and more authentic Thai in the south bay.  They regularly have tasty variants on the Americanized standard Thai dishes, though my only complaint is that what they call hot isn't all that hot (and I don't really go for the scorching Thai hot).  Decent sized portions - not French tiny but not a heaping plate full.  The bar service has been mixed - sometimes the drinks are great, other times they're way out of proportion.
author: Dave L.

description:
A and I have been talking about eating here for a while and finally made it out this past Saturday for lunch.  It was really empty inside.  I think only one table was occupied, but I guess it's more bustling on weekdays versus weekends.  I didn't really mind because we didn't have to wait and had the full attention of our waiter.

The decor is really nice inside and the waiters are dressed in traditional Thai outfits.

The food was good.  I guess on weekends they just have the dinner menu, even during lunch - because we totally had the dinner menu.  Anyway, we started with the Emperor Steamed Dumplings and the Fresh Spring Rolls.  I actually liked the dumplings a lot.  The spring rolls tasted like they do at any other restaurant.  Nothing stood out about them.  For our main courses, we decided to order the Crispy Soft Shell Crab and the Pad Thai.  I wasn't too impressed with the Pad Thai, but the soft shell crab was good.  And luckily, the dish came with two, so we each got one to eat.  After perusing through all the Yelp reviews for this restaurant, I had intended on ordered the Pumpkin Curry because of all the rave reviews, but I didn't.  I'm just so not into the spicy and this one time I went to Osha Thai on a business lunch and ordered Pumpkin Curry and it was waaaaay too spicy for me.  So there I was trying to discuss business, but my mouth was burning!!!  I didn't want another one of those spicy incidents.  But back to the point, I might try ordering the Pumpkin Curry if I come back.
author: Kris L.

description: I'm have been going to Koh Samui for over a year and absolutely LOVE their food.  This time I'm more than disappointed and a bit bewildered.  I have asked for my food to be spicy there on many occasions and it is done just right!!!  Today I thought I was in a fire eating contest.  There was so much hot pepper in my food that I couldn't even taste it after the first couple of bits.  So after paying $26 for a carryout meal with only some yummy fried corn balls to show for it, I'm not a happy camper because I threw my inedible entree in the trash .  Is it because I decided to eat lunch after 3:00 today; my bad!
author: Donnie S.

description: The best fried rice in the world. Amazing honey roasted duck w/pineapple in red curry sauce, and I can't go there without ordering Madame Sea Bass. Very friendly staff.  Nice atmosphere.
author: Em P.

description: What a pleasant looking place.  I stopped by there for lunch a few days ago while wandering the neighborhood.  The menu was extensive, the meat was identifiable, the service was quick, the sauces were spicy and tasty AND they had sticky rice.  What more could I ask for?
author: ben y.

description:
We were visiting from Vancouver and staying in the neighborhood so thought we'd try this San Francisco Thai restaurant to compare to those back.  A really good idea as it turns out, as Koh Samui is one of the best Thai restaurants we've had the pleasure to visit.  The Chicken Mieng Kum is now my official favourite appetizer of any cuisine. We had the sea bass in ginger sauce special and it was divine, a bit like really tender lobster with a mild slightly sweet and slightly spicy ginger sauce. The bar looked well stocked but we stuck to a local wine.

The service was friendly and efficient, the crowd was young, the music was trendy lounge, the atmosphere was relaxed and jovial, the decor was contemporary without being overdone, and it's easy to get to.
author: Dave B.

description: Slightly Americanized take on Thai that works for me.  Most dishes are run of the mill and a few are not what you would expect (the Tom Yum is quite acidic) but the curries (particularly Pumpkin) are great. Just a tad pricier than you may expect but worth the trip.
author: Jacob F.

description: Food was mediocre, with embarrassing presentation (larb gai in a halved green bell pepper??). Pricier and less satisfying than other Thai options in the city. Waiter blatantly tried to oversell. Lovely ambiance, but doesn't make up for the food / value. Would not return.
author: N K.

description:
cute lil spot in soma with a definite thai flavor in decor without being over the top.

sit down for a laid back rendez vous or at the bar to watch the latest game and chat with the bartender and locals.

the food presentation is nice but the quantity is on the small side.
the green papaya salad is tasty though i'll be sure to ask for more spicy next time.
the braised tofu dish is great too but also indicated spicy when it wasn't.
but, a good dose of hot sauce fixed that up.
always ask for rice since it doesn't come with entrees necessarily.

looks like i have to try the rolls and pumpkin curry on my next visit.
author: Anh V.

description:
nice ambiance and delicious food.

3 words: pumpkin curry chicken. absolutely delicious, with the perfect amount of heat/sweetness. my mouth is watering just thinking about it! we also had a green seafood curry special which I thought was pretty good but not quite as yummy as the chicken curry. we enjoyed the green papaya salad as well.

bonus points for offering brown rice! :)
author: Jill M.

description: Ok, I'll keep it short and sweet. The ambiance was nice, the wait staff friendly, and the food was good--albeit slightly overpriced. I had the mango beef and the meat was really tender. There weren't many options in terms of authentic Thai dishes, but the menu looked pretty good overall.
author: Ty L.

description: This is probably one of the best Thai places I've had in SF.  It does definitely get very noisy though.  I have gone there with a variety of different friends who all found it delicious.
author: Clarence K.

description: Went here about 2 years ago.  Was very mediocre for Thai in San Francisco.  Too bad because I love the location, the name and the decor.  ooo ooo! (monkey talk)
author: Mitch A.

description: I have been visiting Koh Samui for about 2 years now...I discovered it awhile back when it was empty and kind of sad, I loved it for the parking and no reservation needed style of place. NOW, i returned last night and made a reservation for a party of 7. It was packed and loud! A lot of young souls there, food was good (the young curry served in a coconut was a treat off of the specials list). The gai pra kro (Basil Chix) was mediocre as was the mango n beef. Perhaps the tables' fault for ordering such mundane fare. The papya salad was good, not too fishy, but not too spicy either, lacked any type of flare. I think the food has been quashed in terms of spice or ingenuity, but overall, reasonable prices (we had a $25 btl of sauv blanc) and a nice meal. The service is timely so if you want to linger, this isnt the place for that either. Overall: functional, efficient, but lacks any luster.
author: Hilary H.

description:
Nice place.

Food was good.

Vibe was funky, good looking crowd.

Service was a bit wierd, was hard to get a servers attention during the whole time we were there. 

Would go back for the food.
author: John S.

description: you won't be disappointed here..thai place in my 'hood...and they do have a decent size bar with tv to watch sports....decent place for some grub or beer....the food isn't bad...nothing to rave about either....
author: Hen A.

description:
I have been here twice for dinner, and once for takeout.  The decor is nice, but the restaurant both times was crowded and very loud.  At a table of 6 people, there was no way to hear a person at the opposite end.  

The food is decent, but overpriced in the way that makes you bitter.  I can stomach paying $12.50 for green curry, but making me pay $10 for green curry and then a separate $2.50 for rice is obnoxious.  Who wants curry without rice? Isn't rice a given?  Can't you pretend you aren't needling me for every extra dollar?  

I was also confused by the sign in the bathroom saying: Please do not flush toilet paper, paper towels, or sanitary napkins in the toilet.  Wait, what? Where am I supposed to put toilet paper? Is this a mistake, or do they have bad plumbing imported from Thailand?  I just don't know, but it made me laugh while flushing the toilet paper.
author: Brooke G.

description: Very nice! Somewhat slow service, but the food makes up for that. I am very picky when it comes to Thai food, and this is a place I plan to return to. (However, the name is misleading -- this is central and not southern Thai food ... nor do they have monkeys, of course.)
author: Markus J.

description: I took a dear friend here tonight for a holiday dinner. I had the waitress-recommended beef steak, which had a tad too much fatty meat. My companion had the Madame Sea bass, which I'm assured was decent. We also shared the fish cake appetiser, which was exquisitely presented and tastes delicious. Our server had a "training" moniker on her nametag, so I cut her some slack regarding service. I was always told to give 25% tip at nicer restaurants, but my friend informed me that it's only 20% in the US. Odd that, but live and learn, I suppose. One star off for the trainee we were assigned and the amount of fatty meat.
author: Hasan D.

description:
after a LONG day of drinking and walking throughout the city for bay to breakers, we came here for dinner last night.  at around 8 pm, the restaurant was pretty empty, so we got some drinks and were seated right away.  the five of us shared the veggie samosas, corn fritters, green papaya salad, eggplant w/ tofu, pumpkin curry w/ tofu, pea sprouts, and veggie pad thai.  all of it was good, particularly the pumpkin curry and pea sprouts, but the portions were kinda small.  we got the monkey's mummy dessert, which was a bananas flambe w/ vanilla ice cream.  

cocktails here are pretty good and fruity.
author: Helen T.

description: This is where suburbanites go to eat on their "visiting the big city" adventure night before venturing out to one of the sad little SOMA nightclubs.  Good fried tofu, but otherwise they tried to create ambiance through trinkets and decore rather than through competent execution and inventive fare.
author: Michael H.

description: erg - 3 stars for dining in.  2 stars for the delivery.  We spent 45$ and there was barely enough food for 2.  spring rolls were poorly wrapped, barely filled and uncut (you get 2 long tubes), grapefruit salad was a few small bits of grapefruit, raw green beens, strawberries and grape tomatoes; entree was about 10 oily shrimp (that's it - 10 - shrimp floating in oil), and the sauteed veggies smelled like feet. Im saving a star b/c Ive liked this place for dining in but I wouldn't recommend their delivery.
author: Fallon C.

description:
i had dinner here last night with a friend; very cool place. the look/feel is unlike any other thai restaurant i've been to in san francisco, in a good way. we started with the vegetable samosa; good, not great. definitely less greasy than the samosas you'll find at (most) indian restaurants.

i had the spicy tofu with zucchini, onion, carrot and fresh basil in chili garlic sauce, which was pretty damn good. i missed the wok tossed thai pasta spicy spaghetti (which can be made with tofu) on the menu, will try this next time. overall, a good find. i'll definitely be back.
author: vincent m.

description: It had monkey in the name, so I had to go check it out. Glad I did - the Pumpkin Curry Chicken was absolutely delicious and came in a pumpkin - great presentation as well. My friend Cleo and I also ordered the samosas and one of the rolls too - both were very good. The only thing that bothered me was the chair... not the most comfortable chair to enjoy a meal in, but whatevs... my palate was happy, so that's good.
author: Chris W.

description: My second time going to this place was even better than the first, and the first was far from shabby. I made the mistake of getting a noodle soup to go (chicken with bean sprout, added veggies) which was a bit too messy to eat at my desk - however the flavors were delicious. Today I got the Jatujak Pad See Ew (flat rice noodles, with broccoli, and egg) with tofu made spicy. It was DELICIOUS. I'm fairly certain this will be a once every week or two lunch spot...
author: Lesley R.

description: Ordered a bunch of takeout from here yesterday.  My favorite dish here is the seabass in green curry.  I'm not a fan of their pad thai, the noodles were overcooked.  The spring rolls are fresh but not wrapped well and everything falls out after one bite.  Their brown rice is yummy and their thai ice coffee is pretty darn good.
author: Jen C.

description: Good food with lots to choose from.  I'd suggest the soft shelled crab or the sliced beef as en trees with the fried calamari for an appetizer.  Although the menu is extensive it is in the pricey range.  Ambiance and presentation are nice with nice interior setup.  However, service wasn't very friendly nor efficient (at least the server we got).
author: David C.

description: We were there for lunch and both the food and service was very good.  The atmosphere was slick and upbeat (compared to most Thai places I've been to), which was great but scary at the same time.  It seems like a cool place to get a cocktail after work so I'll try that next time.
author: Julie D.

description:
im not a big fan of koh samui.  they have very pretty plates and the presentation is nice too.  the food is just not that great. 

if you want a nicer atmosphere, then you should try this place.  if you want authentic thai food, i would go to any of the osha's in SF.
author: Wendy S.

description:
The other reviewers are right.  This place used to be good, but now it pretty bad.  The service was terrible - there were 4 waiters in the mostly empty restaurant, and we still waited 25 minutes for someone to take our order.  When the food arrived, it was cold.  It wasn't very tasty either. There are many great restaurants in SOMA, so don't waste your time and money on this one.

Latest addition:  They double charged us for the meal!  And not just us, our friends too.  To add further insult, the double charge was an inflated amount.  Wow... Never never again.
author: Malgosia G.

description: Not bad, but not great. It's very consistant, and the staff is very friendly. It's definitely a place I would go to regularly if I lived in the area, but not a place I would make a special place for. I've had the pumpkin curry, which is pretty good. Everything else is good, like the spring rolls, the beef dish, the pad thai.... again, everything is good. I come here often enough because a friend lives near by, it's inexpensive, they have a full bar,  and you can never get enough Thai food!
author: jennifer h.

description: I was surprised the place turned out to be so good after having read some Yelpers review's. So yummy, the decor is beautiful... and the check in the end was far from breaking my heart - dinner for 4 people $20 per person including tip. Service was friendly and fast.
author: Daria G.

description: Tried out the Monkey for the first time. This place is right near work, so it's a convenient lunch option. I enjoyed the soup noodle dish I had, full of fresh veggies and yummy seafood, which was tasty, if a bit oily. From a look around the restaurant, there seemed to be plenty of other appetizing dishes to try and I noticed they even have brown rice as an alternative to white. I'd certainly go again, but with Cha Am so close by, it'll be hard to choose this one instead unless I'm really just going for the convenience.
author: Megan K.

description: The food was status-quo, the service was subpar. Order the calamari and or sea bass if you're not too hungry and don't mind waiting 30mins until the server brings the table the introductory round of waters.
author: Jake P.

description:
so, they tried to assassinate me today. but i didn't let them get me down. i'm used to being culinarily assaulted in questionable quality ethnic lunch joints. 

problem is, when the death by undercooked chicken failed, they tried to charge me for it on the bill! i was offered a consolation death bisquit, but that would have taken 10 more minutes AFTER the rest of my cohorts had finished lunch.

suddenly when i protested the charge, the food showed up along with the bill for the same price! f*ckers!

i've had enough chicken to know when it's cooked. this was so underdone it was almost silly. now i have to go have mean shots of terrible liquor to kill the bugs making their way down my intestinal tract... another Fecal Factor show coming right up!
author: matt n.

description: Yummy Thai food! The staff was very welcoming and gracious! The appetizers were amazing! The Meing Kum (chopped peanut, roasted coconut, fresh lime, ginger, onion and chili - a MUST!) bursted with flavor, the fried calamari was perfection, and the spring rolls were great!
