I had Jurassic Prawns that were abundant and really tasty! The brown rice was the BEST brown rice I've ever had!! The Pumpkin Curry is really yummy and a popular favorite! The ambiance was warm and inviting. Love the hardwood floors and chic decor! The restaurant is a little loud - hard to hear with a party of 5, but the food was worth it and is within walking distance of AT&T Park! Don't eat off of the elephant plates with the trunks down (bad luck!), but they will bring you a regular plate without making you feel like a weirdo! They are on OpenTable too!
author: Lisa T.

description:
if you come here, you HAVE to try the Chicken Satay Mieng Kum as an appetizer. it's described as "a favorite Thai snack that's fun to eat" and it literally put a smile on my face. it must have something to do with the combination of peanut, coconut, lime and the chili saucet. 

this dish alone is worth 5 stars, but i had a great entree as well (grilled sirloin beef served with pineapple salad). i loved their use of fresh coconut in the pineapple salad, and how it had onions in it but still left a clean taste in my mouth (first time that's ever happened...) other than the food, i thought it had a great ambiance and great cocktails.
author: David P.

description: This is more of a 3.5, but ranking it down since the option is unavailable. I've had better Thai but was impressed by the corn patty starter and the duck noodle soup broth. The service was not disappointing, which I guess is surprising considering comments made by other reviewers. I think it must've been our lucky night... pumpkin curry was not bad, but not something I would order again. Price was... okay, I guess I've been brainwashed by food pricing in SF. Wouldn't mind coming to Koh Samui again (I mean, cocktails with monkey trinkets is always entertaining) but... if I were out specifically looking for good Thai I would probably go somewhere else.
author: Jessica L.

description: Mediocre, especially when pumpkin curry costs $16.
author: Wakako U.

description: Honestly, this place really isn't that good. Thai food is perhaps one of the best, most flavorful cuisines in the world, and this place really doesn't do it justice. I've had better Thai food that was less than half the price. Sure the place looks pretty nice and it's located in the heart of SOMA, but the food just doesn't cut it. I got the green curry with steak and the charred flavor from the steak completely overcomes the curry flavor -- so I wasn't eating curry, I was eating burnt steak with green crap. If you want better Thai food for the expensive price, I'd suggest you go to OSHA Thai.
author: Roy C.

description: This is one of my favorite Thai restaurants. Consistently good food, great drinks, and service. A bit pricey, but my only complaint! Great veggie selections.
author: Sonia W.

description: Friendly staff, festive atmosphere and spicy green chicken curry that hits the spot when you're craving Thai. Good for take-out, eating in, or happy hour/drinks. Tends to have weird psychedelic Thai movies playing on the flat screens above the bar, but it's not too distracting. Not a bargain by any stretch, but it's SF and this isn't a hole-in-the-wall.
author: Megan Q.

description: Hey this place was pretty nice.. good street parking (it was 8pm on a Monday night, no games or special events going on), decently priced (not cheap, but still on speaking terms w/ my wallet).  The food was pretty good.  I got the Koh Tau (wide noodles) w/ beef.. I thought peanut sauce was going to be more like crushed peanuts than peanut butter, but whatevs.  I really liked the setup tho.. felt classy and not too crowded on a weeknight.  Next time I'm going to try the honey duck.  And one of their desserts.
author: Christie C.

description: I liked Koh Samui & the Monkey. Actually I really love the name! The food was good, but the service needed work. Serious work. Like a brain transplant followed by a sex change. The place is a bit on the expensive side, but lunch was good.
author: Jordan M.

description: Nice decor (especially with the soft lighting which gives a romantic aura), fantastic service, and food presentation was so creative & pretty! I had Pot of Gold (appetizer) and Sea Bass Curry w/ eggplants. Both are very good, especially with the Pot of Gold warm in your mouth and the Sea Bass light and flavorful. Definitely will come again...on a date or a group of friends though perhaps conversation more subdued.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I love this little Gem of a place - Best little Restaurant in SOMA! The Pumpkin Curry (substitute Tofu instead of chicken) is Wonderful!! We have this at work at least once a week. Tom Ka Gai is excellent. Everything we've ever ordered we have been happy with! That's an excellent run for this picky group!!

Four stars for great food! We generally always take-out since lunch is always packed!!
author: Anne P.

description: It's the cutest place ever; every detail is attractive and soothing.  The interior of the restaurant is very hip, especially for the location!   I ordered the Chicken Satay appetizer and the Imperial Roll appetizer.  Really liked the Chicken Satay but was not crazy about the Rolls (too greasy and an odd spiciness that didn't agree with me). I spent $16.50 and that's just too much for two appetizers.  I enjoyed it but will likely not go there much in the future.
author: Sparkely K.

description:
this place is right down the ally from my work. very pretty inside and clean. service is great and staff is friendly and on point. unlike other thai restaurants in the soma...

they served the green tea in a interesting elephant tea pot and tea cups. my coworkers cup was leaking. she got it replaced right away. 

get the green curry seafood lunch mix with fresh spring rolls.
author: Renae C.

description: They have a really tasty Lobster curry here. All the appetizers we had were well done too. Good service and I like the atmosphere - the cool lantern with the monkey on it rocks =).
author: Christopher S.

description: the tom kha gai (chicken coconut milk soup) was WAY too sweet, i couldn't even finish half of it. the sesame-crusted scallops were pretty good, in that the scallops were huge and tender, but they weren't hot enough, and the sauce was a little bland. i had a craving for pad see ew and luckily they were able to make it for us even though it wasn't on the dinner menu. it was pretty good, as pad see ew goes. i'm giving this place 3 stars -- 2.5 for food, but service and cool decor bring it up to 3. i don't think i'd go back when there are so many other thai places to try in the city!
author: Clara K.

description: Great thai restaurant. Classy atmosphere, delicious food. The appetizers are unique and worth a try. For entrees, their pumpkin curry is really unique and I love their sea bass. Great for groups too, and last minute meals without reservations.
author: Joy X.

description: Tasty food, great atmosphere, and pleasant service!  Try the Pumpkin Curry Chicken, or the "Emerald Curry," which is a seafood mixture with green curry served in a coconut bowl.
author: Corey C.

description: Great Asian fusion place. Everything were deliciously presented and deeply flavored. Excellent peanut sauce for the spring rolls, creamy pumpkin curry, and the fried fish dish was very impressive.  It's always packed for good reasons. Try it!
author: Lan L.

description: I like how they place is put together.  The food is decent, service could use a little bit more work.  I love how they have those framed lost animal adds they have in the restroom.  What I even love more are those posted "warning" not to take the lost animal adds.  It actually crossed my mind taking one, I guess many have been stolen and steeling is wrong. hahaaaaaaaaa
author: Xiu L.

description: I ate lunch here with a friend.  I've passed by the place about 1000 times and I've never noticed it, even if you walk in the front it doesn't look like a restaurant until you walk up the stairs.   The restaurant has a trendy asian theme.  The lunch special always grabs my eye, I had the green curry with the spring rolls.  The portions were just about enough, I would eat here again.
author: Brandon L.

description:
The food was very good, the reason I only give 3 stars was because of the bad service.  They're trying to be an upscale restaurant with coffee shop caliber service (no offense to anyone working in a coffee shop....)
And stop charging extra for rice that should come with the meal!
author: Mike J.

description: I've had several good meals here but the one I really enjoyed was their scallop dish.  If you are a fan then you shouldn't be disappointed, all the other dishes and apps I've had here have been good as well.
author: Derek D.

description: I love this place for any day of the week dinner and drinks.  Besides that its down the street from where I live, they have a friendly staff and great thai food.  This is a great place for large gatherings, date night or dinner for one=) Love it!  Pumpkin Curry is my favorite!
author: Joella A.

description: We had dinner here on a Sunday night. I used to work down the street so would go here all the financial area near the embarcadero, I fell in love with Osha Thai. So it had been awhile since I've been here and wanted to take my gf here. We went and had the most amazing meal. We ordered a mixed seafood dish as well as the Pad Thai and some corn cakes for apetizers. It was soooo good. The  food was spectacular. Some of the specialty coctails were ok and some were not. The waitress was nice but the drink said was her favorite obviously she said about every drink since it was awful. Regardless the food was good serivce not bad. Our waitress was perfect but she was sweet and gracious whenever we asked for anything. Definitely will go back.
author: Hyung L.

description: This was my first date restaurant, my anniversary restaurant, and most recently our engagement restaurant. The duck curry was amazing and we got super authentic pad se ew. Delicious.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Best Thai in the city if I do say so myself.  The atmosphere is grand and you can tell they really took care in selecting the decor, down the staff uniforms.  I like the green plates with elephants on them, the buddha, the modern chairs, white tableclothes.  They have a decent wine selection.  I loved the pumpkin curry, which I have seen crop up on other menus, but I think it was a first here.  Madame sea bass is madame bliss.  Mieng cum is a rarity in standard Thai restaurants, but was very fresh here.  The salads are flavorful!  Fish cakes and rice are a perfect take out meal, but if you have time do stop in to catch a bit of atmosphere with your Thai meal.
author: apple r.

description: I really like the room, but the food is very uneven, often too sweet and suffering from an overdose of the ol' canned curry paste. It's often full of large groups which can make it less than ideal for that romantic dinner for two.
author: Stellah D.

description: This is decent if you're at work right around the corner and you are craving Thai.  If you have a choice, however, this is NOT where to go to satisfy your Thai craving.  The curry is not spicy (the green curry  doesn't even have a kick to it).  Everything is bland.  And I hate when people ask me where I'm going to lunch, and then I say, "Koh Samui & the Monkey", and then people say, "Where?", etc.  This goes on for a while.  The food's not worth the effort.
author: Lauren S.

description: Had some solid thai here for lunch last week. Ordered the special of the day, a chicken curry. Quick service and nice interior. Only issue was, had a bit of a stomach ache afterwards? Prefer their sister restaurant, Citizen Thai and the Monkey, in North Beach.
author: Sarah R.

description: Surprised to say the least. Went here for a birthday dinner with a group of about 8 and the price was surprisingly cheaper then we expected.  The portions looked small but I was content after, not the usual food coma afterwards.  The food was tasty but nothing stuck out to Yelp that much about it.  Wait staff was nice, cocktails were tasty but not very strong, parking can suck if you go around the wrong times,  I would go again for casual dining, or if in the area.
author: Charles M.

description: Yes, not a sure thing food-wise. Nice room, good service, inconsistent Thai food.
author: patrick g.

description: Comfortable interior and more than adequate food.  Not my favorite Thai place, but perhaps my favorite Thai in that neighborhood.  I like the Green Curry with tofu, extra spicy!
author: Amme P.

description: Love this place for a pre-show dinner (at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts).  The ambience is upscale, but the price is affordable.  I LOVE the green elephant plates.  Definitely order the hot and sour soup, and grilled pork with sticky rice.
author: Vera D.

description: Went for lunch. Decor is fine. Nice bar. Staff was fast and attentive, the flavors are there but are not well executed. Overall... waaaaaay overpriced for tiny portions  Rice plate lunch specials priced at $13, $15 and $17 dollars for a cup of Curry, cup of Rice, and a couple small rice rolls... over forty bucks for 2 rice plates and an Ice Tea? Absurd. So many better options in SF... I will not be back.
author: Nomad I.

description: Disclaimer: I haven't a restaurant 5 stars in a while. But this deserved it. I wasn't expecting much when I went and was delightfully surprised by the meal. The ambiance was really great. Soft house music playing, ornate but not too gaudy Thai artifacts, a cute little pond with floating candles outside, etc. The food itself was outstanding (for menu items ordered, see dining companion Ian M's review) and the prices were very reasonable (and I didnt even have to pay!). The tom ka gai was one of the best I've ever had. Best part of the place is, its 2 blocks away.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Graham A.

description:
Went here last night for the first time. The decor, ambiance, service and cocktail selection (mango mojito, yum!) got a 5 from me right away. It was a late dinner, so it wasn't crowded. However, they lose a star for being confusing with our appetizer. We asked for the chicken satay mieng kum appetizer, which neither of us had before. So when they brought out both a chicken satay appetizer on its own AND the chicken mieng kum, we figured they went together and gobbled both up (delicious, btw, thought I'm not a fan of ginger). However, we got the bill and realized they'd given us two separate appetizers. Too late, we'd already eaten them. They gained back that lost star when they brought out the madame sea bass, which was so buttery-flaky-delicious that I nearly lost my head. The coconut curry sauce that came with it was to die for; almost tempted to lick it off my plate. However, their pad thai left something to be desired. It was a little dry, lacked flavor, and the beef we ordered in it  was a little chewy and fatty. Pad thai is such a go-to dish that it better be made right, but this one definitely lost them 2 stars... 

I'd still go back and try other dishes. Their pumpkin chicken curry looked great, and I'd definitely have the madame sea bass again (not to mention the coconut rice!). But if I am looking for pad thai, I'd go elsewhere.
author: Erica M.

description: I have only recently begun to reallize that it's possible I am not a huge fan of "authentic" Thai; it seems too... bitter? That said, this place was PERFECT. Creamy coconut curry, perfectly cooked shrimp, spicy but not burning "medium," an excellent rose, those adorable missing pet pictures in the bathroom, really, I loved this place.  My only complaint is the noise level; it's just not a building made to disperse the din of multiple conversations.  Totally worth it, though!
author: Amber S.

description: No complaints here, but no raves either.  Just an above average thai place that isnt a destination, but definitely worth a walk-in on a tuesday night.  One of the few thai places that have a full bar - if you want a martini with your pad thai - which is definitely a plus.  The seafood dishes were good and the decor was pretty nice - but again - nothing to write home about.
author: D S.

description: This has become one of my favorite thai places to eat at in the city. BBQ chicken pork are both excellent, they come with mango or papaya salad. Pumpkin curry is spicy but well worth ordering. Their pad thai is really good also. Imperial rolls are yummy, as the fried calamari is too. Fried bananas and mango sticky rice - yum! Try something on the menu and you will not be disappointed.   It's a bit noisy during lunch so if you need a quite place to eat, I would not suggest take out.
author: Beth W.

description: The food was quite good, maybe too salty, the service friendly, and the pacing leisurely like I like it for dinner. The most exciting feature is the reproductions of lost cat posters decorating the women's bathroom, surrounded by homemade label maker signs about "lady, stealing is a crime" and "ugliness is from within" and "lady, please respect us like we are respecting you." Possibly the same menu as Citizen Thai and the Monkey, but maybe slightly cheaper and less pretentious atmosphere.
author: Amy E.

description: Very good food.  Tom Kha was spot on and the beef curry dish I had was outrageously tasty.  I could have used more kick though, it is Thai after all.
author: Sean M.

description: Good Thai food - I've only been here for lunch - they have a great lunch deal for $10.95.  The spring rolls were yummy, and the chicken curry was good too.  The space is very bright and attractive, and it's packed during lunchtime.  I don't think I would come here for dinner, but it's definitely a good lunch choice.
author: Christina S.

description: "The Monkey" as we call it, is a great Thai place and the only decent asian food you'll find in the Brannan/3rd area... I especially like their duck dishes like the honey roasted duck with spinach and rice or the duck noodles soup.  The decor is also very nice so it's one of those lunch-time treats.
author: grant l.

description:
Came here to have dinner and the place was constantly buzzing. It's not the biggest restaurant holding maybe 60 people. There were about 3 groups of at least ten people so there was a lot of chatter. Seems like a great place for a group party. They have a bar area with 2 big screen tvs. 

Started with the stuffed mushrooms with peanut sauce. It's fried so it's pretty hard to mess up. There's a lot more meatball inside than mushroom which was fine with me. The peanut sauce was pretty good.  Main course we had pumpkin curry, fried soft shell crab, sea bass in a clay pot and their special for the night fried scallops. The pumpkin curry was fantastic. Nice flavor, texture and presentation. It comes in a small little pumpkin. The fried soft shell crab was good but nothing out of the ordinary. It came with some kind of tangy, spicy sauce that was delicious. The fried scallops were ok but I ate more of the fried breading than scallops. Try to stay away from their sea bass in a clay pot dish. The noodles and flavor were pretty good but we only got 3 pieces of sea bass in the whole dish. Stick to some authentic chinese restaurants for good clay pot dishes and avoid this one at all costs. 

The restaurant had a plethora of exotic cocktails that looked pretty good. They had a few beers on tap and a nice wine selection too. Definitely a fun place to go, have some drinks and eat some good thai food. You will have to talk pretty loudly since the whole restaurant is pretty loud.  The service was fantastic. I'm basing my review completely on the food but I would give this place a 4 star rating for the entire experience. The curry is definitely a safe bet.
author: Ken W.

description: The food here is excellent. I especially recommend getting the Mieng Kum as an appetizer - tasty little bits of coconut, chopped peanuts, lime, ginger, onion, and chili wrapped on a leaf. The flavors and textures change as you eat it -- it's fabulous.
author: Roger L.

description: Went to the place for lunch, the service was pretty slow, and the food decent but not exceptional.
author: Steph S.

description:
i would like a heaping order of attitude, with a side of rude hold the polite.

minus the 'i don't know my ass-from-my-elbow bartender' and the rude waiter i thoroughly enjoyed my stay here at the ass-hole inn.

abrupt conclusion:  great food...sub par service.
author: clever u.

description: Great Thai food!! Service was a bit overbearing and rushed, but not so bad. Spicy duck YUM red curry chicken YUM and bbq chicken YUMMM. I think next time I will get the bento box so that I can have it ALL!
author: Rikki D.

description: I love it here!  The food is great - we had the Madam Curry (sea bass green curry) and vegetable samosas (VERY good).  The beef noodle with peanut sauce was good, but a bit heavy.  Our waiter also gave us a small bowl of coconut rice after we were unsure of how it would taste - and we liked it a lot.  The service was excellent, and we really enjoyed the restaurant.
author: Jessica F.

description: I have been here for both lunch and dinner and i think this place is just ok.  Lunch portions are VERY small and they are expensive. Dinner is nicer because of the ambiance however they are even more expensive during dinner! Amazing....
author: Audrey T.

description: All around very good Thai food, I just wish it wasn't so expensive. I like that they have four different kinds of rice they serve- white, sticky, jasmin and brown. Cocktails are nothing to write home about, but the ambience is good and the food is delicious. I do like that they have an good wine list that pairs well with Thai food. I still prefer more authentic Thail affair with more spices and kick to my food...
author: Havana H.

description: I ain't goin' to lie, I've been here three times in the past four weeks with former coworkers and friends. Curry is my comfort food and I normally order a new curry dish every visit. Most recently I ordered the jungle curry for the beef and the savory yellow curry which goes really well with the sticky rice. My meat and potato friends loved the new flavours and their very strong cocktails.
author: Phillip T.

description: Pumpkin curry was great. All other dishes we tried were stand outs too - monkfish served two different ways (even though I never saw this fish in Thailand) and scallops, and the beers were cold and refreshing. The negatives were that we were sat at a table by the bathroom but the staff was very accommodating and moved our party of six and the green papaya salad was mediocre.  Service was friendly but almost too quick with bringing out food.
author: Chrissy C.

description: I agree, this place is inconsistent. I had this amazing eggplant salad--the flavors were perfectly subtle and light. On the other hand, there were 3 shrimps in the salad that were so chewy. But overall the salad was to die for. I also ordered a mushroom and shrimp soup that was way too salty. I think they put too much fish sauce. Great salad, horrible soup. I couldn't even finish the soup. I ordered my food to go and they were very fast.  I ate it at the park next to AT&T Park and my one year old daughter played. That was nice, I'll probably eat here again when I'm craving Thai food and I'm not in the mood to make it myself.
author: Sharon B.

description: I love their chicken, mushroom coconut soup- I crave it. The restaurant is a little dark and it's difficult at times to see what you're eating. I highly recommed the sea bass with green curry. I haven't found a better Thai place yet in the city... I drive all the way from the marina to soma for this place.
author: Noel H.

description:
Came here for a late Saturday dinner with a couple of my friends.  We were craving something tasty and ethnic.  The decor of the restaurant is pretty modern and also has nice ethnic Thai touches.  The ambiance is upscale but casual.  We really liked the atmosphere.  

We had some tasty cocktails and then were seated a nice table next to the window.  There is a good drink menu and a decent wine list.  The menu has a wide variety of dishes.  Curries, noodle dishes, clay pot dishes and lots of appetizers.  All of our food was very good.  We had yellow curry chicken, sea bass in clay pot, and beef pad thai.  We also ordered a nice bottle of cabernet savignon with our meal, which was very nice.  The service was good...it was funny though b/c we went on Thai new year, so the cooks were apparently throwing buckets of water on each other and our waitress went to every table to explain all the uproar from the kitchen.  We thought it was cool...we didn't even know that Thailand had a separate new year let alone had the tradition of dousing one another with water.  Overall a really good dining experience.  We all agreed that we would return to try other tasty dishes on the menu.
author: Kristina D.

description: Went to lunch here today. Actually I come here every so often to meet an old co-worker and talk about how great life is at a different company. Every single time I come I cannot not order the bbq chicken dish. Everything about it is great. I try to look at the menu for something different but I can't sway from the one dish I know is perfect for me. They just changed the wine glasses too, they are much larger than they were before. Good decision.
author: Erin R.

description: Service was oustanding period. I love the lounge area. 5 stars for the lemon grass soup, the chicken was ok and the tofu was super salty....
author: Dee D.

description:
great pad thai, but what you have to try is the mieng kum!!! just like in thailand!

wish their thai iced teas were better...
author: Clau F.

description: I made a reservation for my friend and I during the weekday. When we got there, it was a little confusing as no one was at the hostess desk for a few minutes. When someone showed up, they confirmed my reservation and asked me to sit at the bar, which we did. We ordered a drink and the hostess told us to let her know when our drinks arrived and she would seat us. Normally I would expect to be seated immediately and have our drinks brought to us, but no biggie. We ordered the spicy tofu and the pumpkin curry. The pumpkin curry was good enough that I might kill someone to eat it again. God I can't wait to have it again!!! I also ordered two drinks that night that were both yummy. I can't remember the first one (because honestly I left a little drunk after those drinks) but the second one was called Shock the Monkey and was fantastic. I'm definitely coming back.
author: kristen v.

description: A very good Thai restauraunt.  Friendly staff.  Modern yet exotic decors create a very nice atmosphere.  I liked the lettus cups with peanuts, coconut, etc. with sweet tart dressing :)
author: Ayumi I.

description: Once you get tired of the King of Thai menu (don't get me worng, I love their noodles), this is a decent upgrade for more spohisticated dishes. Spring rolls are a good start, and you can't go wrong with the cashew with chicken stir-fry. Curries are not as spicy as what you'd get in Thailand, but that's not always bad. Dessert menu is lacking in choices, unless you want friend banana every single time...
author: Tami Y.

description:
koh samui, dont play coy with me
with that sticky rice and pumpkin curry
sesame scallops, all up on my taste buds
that takeout satisfies appetites like what
author: James L.

description: I've eaten here 3 times so far during lunch during the work week.  It is always crowded so a reservation is a good idea.  The food is pretty good.  Since I go there with the lunch crowd, I never realized that it was pretty child friendly.  My two year old ate with us.  The hostess gave her little plastic monkeys to keep her entertained.  (The kind that you hang on your drink glasses.)  They also gave her a big bowl of steamed vegetables on the house.  There are also high chairs.  I did not check the bathroom to see if they had a changing table though.
author: Kaye M.

description:
Tried this place for happy hour (HH) based on their site and yelp reviews. We just ordered food. For the HH you can only sit at a bar which has 2 huge TVs playing sports, which I was not a big fan of. Music playing was also questionable. For $5 each we got the fresh Summer rolls, they were good size but mostly filled with iceberg lettuce and few pieces of fried tofu. Next was the the Pad Thai, which had a weird odor to it - i guess that was the fish sauce, which I personally can't handle. I've had Pad Thai elsewhere, but it was never this strong.  The Pad See Ew had really wide noodles some where stuck together, there were few pieces of brocolli and some of the tofu pieces were cold in the middle. On one side I can see that restaurants get skimpy on the HH food offering.  On the other side they should serve food that is a sample of what you might get if you ate dinner there. And since the HH food was horrible I will not be back for more. 

As far as the interior based on their site that has only evening photos, I was a bit dissapointed. The place was more casual looking during the day and not as hip as portrayed....
author: Kat F.

description:
poo poo on the monkey!

it would be nice if that chunk of brannan would turn into restaurant row or something. you have bacar, coco500, zeke's (always good times to sit at the bar and drink with some old-timer at 11am.), brickhouse (those two girls there received training at some internment camp, i think), the post office (oh, wait. they don't serve food there. but they do make you wait in line forever, take your money, and then send you on your way). district should have relocated to that block, along with the small mexican restaurant and tres tequila (blah, review on that someday). anyhoo...

first time was dinner. tried a bunch of different dishes ranging from noodle soup to satay to curry to pad thai (pad tacky, i know). noodle soup? bland. satay? warm and dry not quite like sawdust, but another hour under the heat lamp... curry? the sauce held coupled with the dry meat complemented each other (not in a good way). pad thai? blah. 'twas ok, i guess. but pad thai is one of those "orange chicken" dishes, so i can't give it much weight in the rankings. that's like letting in nathan's hot dog eating competition into the 2008 beijing summer olympics.

the only dish that really saved the entire meal was the fish sauce and thai chilis which they brought out in a little dish. i went through more than a handful of these little dishes. not saying they're stingy here. the atmosphere was nice in a temple-clean room sort of way. in order to maintain decorum, they couldn't bring out a vat of the stuff. i dig.

sitting at the window is always fun, especially during lunch time (2nd time i went). watching the busy bees walking around and having them look up at me from the street was interesting. blah on the second time.

why do people come here? there's no other thai restaurant in the neighborhood. if king of thai came here or osha or some new thai joint (people, do we really need any more?), the monkey would be done. prediction has been made. i do like that they attempt upscale thai. a pat on the back for trying.

it's craptastic.

rating? hmmm. how about one big toilet wax seal donut.
author: dave tastic fantasmo x.

description: Has to be one of my favorite's !!!  Albiet I'm not a restaraunteur, but I know great food at great prices.  I love to eat   ROFL
author: Obi W.

description: This place is festival for your eyes.  There's plenty of decoration to make the place feel authentic.  In addition, the waitresses are decked out in tailor made Thai outfits which is pretty impressive.  The restaurant sits slightly above sidewalk level so you have this sense of exclusiveness when you sit near the window area.  The food is tasty with reasonable prices.  They are served in small portion but is very well put together for appearance.
author: R B.

description: Every Thursday is Thai night in my world, and right now Koh Samui & the Monkey's soft, juicy Chicken Satay and warm flavorful Pad Thai with Chicken (and a reddish (?) Sprite) is as good as it gets.  I've been testing all sorts of Thai restaurants, and this one is currently my favorite.  Oh, their Pad See Ew (sp?) is fantastic as well.
author: David B.

description:
Hate to say it but the last 2 times we went here we were very disappointed.  Service was unbearably slow (on a Tuesday night when 1/2 the tables are empty).  My pad thai was un-eatable but by the time I waved down a waiter to send it back, everyone else at the table was ready for dessert.  My husband's whole red snapper (tasty) but not properly fillet'd as he spent his entire meal picking out 20+ bones.  

When we received the check, I noticed they had charged $10 each for glasses of wine that had been listed at $8 on the menu.  When I mentioned to the waiter, he said $10 was the new price and I had to argue with him to refund the $2/glass as that was the listed menu price.

Since we live a block from this place, we really want to like it but after 2 bad visits... life is too short for this kind of mediocrity.
author: Stacy N.

description: Decent thai, I didn't really like the peanut sauce but everything else was ok. Service is impersonal but ok.
author: Michael S.

description: Service was not so good -- they forgot one of my friends' entrees, then when it finally arrived, the food wasn't so great anyway. It's recommended if you want a stylish place to eat and you don't care about getting your food on time.
author: Ellie P.

description: One of my favorite places for lunch. I eat here at least once a week. Mainly take out because this place has a huge lunch crowd. Diverse menu, veggie friendly, nice sake menu too. I highly recommend all appetizers. I love their duck too.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I went back today to celebrate my Supervisor's birthday and the food was much better the second time around, though I dared not order the cashew chicken again (maybe two cashews is enough for Mary Kate Olsen, but not me). Instead, I got the Bangkok Pad Thai with Beef. I was given a generous serving of beef (guess beef costs less than cashews nowadays) and the noodles were pretty good, but what stood out above the rest were the Fried Calamari and Crispy Imperial Rolls. I got heartburn afterward from all the grease, but it was worth it, they were delicious.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
a modern dining room with nice accents of thai tradition. koh samui delivers consistently good food in cool comfortable atmosphere.

the a/c can be pretty annoying though... got reseated once when the vent was blowing on me like a blowdryer.
author: shaun l.

description:
heh.  this place has been worth a chuckle on more than one occasion.

let's get the food part out of the way: basic thai.  nothing remarkable -- but nothing particularly objectionable either.  reasonably munchable thai food at slightly-too-high-for-what-ya-get prices.

I gotta give 'em credit for being cool, even when they're messing up though.  I noticed they had a full bar and (being such a lush) decided to order a top-shelf margarita to go with my lunch.  yeah, yeah -- this isn't a tequila bar or a mexican restaurant.  got that.  still, a bar is a bar, no?  I wanted something tart with lots of lime to go with my meal, so there.

anywaaaaays... after ordering and waiting for a long time for my drink, my friend and I noticed a somewhat heated discussion going on behind the bar.  there was a group of five or six employees apparently trying to figure out what the heck goes into a top-shelf margarita.

noticing their plight, I sauntered over just to see if I could help out.  as it turns out, their bartender hadn't shown up for the shift... and they couldn't find "top-shelf margarita" in their bar guide.

god bless 'em for trying.  that's not the best part though: when I offered to show them how to make one, they were actually cool with it!  I asked for some limes from the kitchen (and put the nasty bottled sweet-and-sour mix they had out back where it belongs... hidden away forever) and made a proper one with real lime juice, patron silver, and a cointreau float... with a little extra to pour for them to taste.

how often does something like that happen?  I'll hazard to guess we broke any number of ABC regs... but it was fun, I got what I wanted, and they had a really happy customer instead of a miffed one.

liking that :-)
author: Mark B.

description: I'm not sure why this place is called "& the Monkey", because the decor and tableware seemed to feature more elephants than monkeys. Actually, I don't think I saw a monkey in there! I want my money back. The service reminds me of the monkeys though, and by that I mean non-existent.
author: Cliff C.

description:
2 words.... scallop curry. 
deep fried scallops in a bath of mild spicy curry and veggies. yum!
i never had scallops with curry before but i definitely want them in my curry now. the drinks were a bit too sweet, they needed to be diluted with some club soda. great place to go for some thai right after a game.
author: Charlie L.

description: Overall, I had a good experience at this restaurant. The food was okay. We started with the basic mieng kum. This was the first time I've ever seen this at a Thai restaurant. It was pretty unique. It was a mixture of coconut, peanut, lemon, bamboo, and ginger wrapped in a spinach leaf. The chicken salad was peanut dressing was really boring and plain. The sizzling seafood platter was delicious... I think that was my favorite... really flavor with the basil. I also enjoyed the spicy tofu with vegetables.
author: Denise L.

description: Food was excellent, but service was sluggish.  They have great lunch deals that include an appetizer and main course, for around $10-15.  I had the duck curry (very good) and my friend had the BBQ chicken (equally good).  Lunch crowd gathers at the strike of noon, so try to get there early...
author: Mark D.

description: The food is ok, I've never had a GREAT meal here but I really enjoy the place and the service.  It's a good restaurant to go to on a date
author: Mrs. G.

description: Not a bad Thai place...the layout is spacious and i've never had a problem with having no reservations. although maybe i'm just lucky like that. the standard appetizers (chicken satay skewers in peanut sauce) are usually done right, as are the imperial rolls and you really can't go wrong with the pad thai. the pumpkin chicken curry can make you forget why you're eating chicken, curry and pumpkin all at once. service isn't too shabby, either.
author: Chris C.

description: I would've given this place five star but their HORRIBLE parking deserve a minus one star.  I guess I went during a game night so it was extra hard to find parking... but the food and service was great!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Totally addicted to their Spicy Thai Pasta with Tofu, damn, damn good - it's my jam, what can I say . .
author: Lauren G.

description: Great food, good drinks, friendly staff.  The pumpkin curry is the best!  I'm hooked on it.  If you get it there they serve it in the pumpkin, no such luck with delivery.
author: Garrett D.

description: For SOMA/Mission Bay... Asian food is a hard find.  Fortunately, Koh Samui is a 2 block crawl from my place... nothing fancy... and I'll agree with the other reviewers here about the food... it can be inconsistent... when they error... it's on the side of overly sweet or overly salty/curry (depending on the dish).  But I won't complain beyond that, because it's reasonably priced (yes.. not as cheap as Clement St. stuff) and normally, my ice cold Singha lager negates any ill flavors.  Go ahead and slap this monkey!
author: Dale K.

description: I live next door to this often crowded Thai joint so I've eaten there more than my fair share of times.  Pretty noisy, so definitely not a recommended date venue.  The sesame crusted scallops are my favorite dish there.  All the other dishes are pretty good and the prices aren't terribly expensive.  Good for a semi-casual dinner with a few friends.  Doesn't accomodate large groups well.
author: Dave L.

description: Nice decor and ambience and decent food. Love the pumpkin curry and fried banana dessert.
author: Yan M.

description: Hands down the best Thai restaurant in the city. If you have not had a good experience here, it is probably because you're not ordering either the pumpkin chicken curry, the yellow curry scallops or their pad thai. We live close by so we eat here at least once a month and only once was a dish slightly off. We love it so much, we decided to let that time slide as an aberration. We bring all of our out of town guests here - great ambiance, great portions, great prices.
author: Deb I.

description: My girlfriend and I have been having steadily medeocre Thai food experiences in San Fran (mediocre thai food being pretty damn good of course) but we finally had a great thai food experience here. We popped in for lunch and split the $16 bento box with an extra side of rice and both left full and content. The imperial rolls were well above average, the curry was delicious, as was the bbq pork and the little salad. All components were excellent and we were in and out the door in about 35 minutes. We can't wait to go back during happy hour to sample some of thier very unique cocktails and get a real deal meal. A little expensive but worth it. Pom Chop!
author: M L.

description: One of the best Thai restaurants in the city.  The pumpkin chicken curry is served in a kabocha squash which is a really nice presentation.  The Penang beef is soft and melts in the sauce.  The sesame scallops with bok choi was presented quite differently than I remember in the past, but it's still good!  The appetizers were good as well, though the sauce for the fish cakes and imperial rolls was a little bit too sweet.  Every experience I've had here has been good, including once with a large group.  Priced a bit more expensive than the other Thai restaurants in the area (which are mostly quite good as well), but different enough that it's worth your while for a slightly nicer meal.
author: Leo C.

description: 3.5 stars.  Our office ordered take out from this place, and all the dishes were pretty good, not greasy, filling.  Portions were not huge, not too small, just the right size.  I plan on eating-in at this place with co-workers or friends during lunch sometime.  It's got a great atmosphere inside.
author: Jason R.

description: One of my favorite Thai places in SF.  Have been here a number of times and it never dissapoints.  Great atmosphere and service...the crying tiger salad is my favorite...writing this review reminds me I need to go back again!
author: Denny R.

description: Great pad Thia. Not too oily and not too dry. It can get a little loud in there but everything we ate was pretty tasty and they had a decently large selection.
author: shadi m.

description: Great joint to have in the neighborhood. Can be inconsistent, but I've never been disappointed by the green curry or the pumpkin curry. Salmon with green beans is good on some days and bad on others. Reasonable by South Beach / SOMA standards.
author: Vikram K.

description:
We used to come here quite a bit because it's easy access from the 280 and the food was pretty good. 

Unfortunately, the portion sizes are now about HALF of what I'd expect them to be, and the price for rice is absolutely unbelievable. 

I will not be back.
author: suz q.

description: Food is great. service is good. prices are reasonable. place is very charming. they were able to accommodate a large group of us
author: Yinnie Q.

description: Good ambiance for dinner.  The red curry dish and pad thai are good.  Parking isn't too bad.  Would go there again when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Just H.

description: Service was awesome and the food very, very good... The honey roasted duck and pineapple simmered in red curry sauce was perfect - very savory and hearty.  It was definitely the big winner at our table and will always be a "must order" dish in the future.  The grilled honey duck with steamed spinach was pretty good too, but couldn't top the duck curry.  The grilled sirloin beef served with pineapple salad and Thai spicy sauce was the least popular dish by far.  Can't recommend that dish at all... For the appetizers, I'd go for the fried sweet corn patties again... delicious!  Oh, and LOVE that Koh Samui delivers!!
author: Tara C.

description: It was definitely a pleasant lunch, but when Thep Phenom is your benchmark (it's right on my block!)...places like this have a rough go of it.  It was good, but I think the sauces, both peanut and chili, lacked flavor.  it's aight...
author: Sarah D.

description: The pumpkin curry is to die for, the rest of the dishes are good and what you would expect from a mid range Thai restaurant.
author: Helen J.

description: I've been eating lunch here at least once a week for a couple years and the food is really good.  It's reasonably priced, reasonably authentic, and more or less promptly delivered.  The staff is quite sweet, if a bit rushed and inconsistent, and the ambiance is pleasant.  I'd rather eat lunch here than dinner- it's not quite a dinner calibre experience- but for a lunch place, it's pretty darn great.
author: Margaret F.

description:
i really like the interior of this place!  although we have only ordered take out- we have to go in to pick it up (one downside- they don't deliver) and it's very nicely designed.  i love how the windows are practically floor length- so the patrons can dine and watch the passersby (or cars drive by- i guess not as fun though).

if you are ordering off their website- when you enter it you come to a blank brown screen that is rather confusing.  if you figure out you need to scroll all the way to the right you will find the menu button.  i think they need to redesign their website.

we typically order the fresh spring rolls (yummy!), the green papaya salad, the pad thai (i love the thicker than normal noodles), the chicken pumpkin curry (my boyfriend loves it), and the prawns and cashew nuts.  

we have ordered in the past- and never will again- the prawn salad (it was not a great size with very few prawns on it) and the grilled prawns entree (it was really disappointing- not many prawns sitting on top of a tasteless salad of greens).  and if you like your rice order at least one per person- the side rice is not a huge portion by any means.  

this is a great place for take out- and i would try it for dine in.  some of the dishes are hit and miss.  but the ones i have found i like are consistently good.  and the waitstaff is always pleasant.  i would give them 3 1/2 stars if i could.  they are our standby for take out thai food- as they are convenient (a few blocks away) and pretty good.  in my experience it's pretty hard to find a really good thai place- despite the fact that there are hundreds of them in most every major city.  my favorite thai place happens to be in federal way, washington- and whenever i visit i attempt to have a meal there.  i'd love to find a place like that in s.f.  but until then i will stick with koh samui.
author: Harmony R.

description: Bustling crowds for lunch and dinner alike, this place has very solid Thai food with a full bar and fun cocktails. I have had a great experience each time, and I personally enjoy the Lemongrass Tofu and the Pumpkin Curry Chicken. The menu has a lot to offer, so I recommend teaming up with some friends to attack it and share the entrees. Good eats!
author: Michael G.

description: If you are in SOMA, I would recommend this place.  The pumpkin chicken curry was good.  Also recommend the Bag of Gold as an appetizer.   If you are coming from out of town, I would go to its sister restaurant Citizen Thai instead.  Better place in more lively neighborhood.
author: Marc M.

description: I've had a lot of Thai food in the last few years; this is one of the better Thai Restaurants in the city.    For an appetizer, I like getting the fresh spring rolls with the dipping sauce; the sauce is particularly good.  For my entree I like the yellow curry chicken.  Yellow curry chicken is usually the dish I try at Thai restaurants.  I've had some bad curry chicken in the city usually because the curry tastes watered down or the potatoes in the curry are too small or none at all.  The yellow curry at Koh Samui is flavorful and there are good sized potatoes in the curry.  This is a good place for lunch if you have some time, the staff is friendly but the service can sometimes be inconsistent and the place gets packed by noon.
author: Josh K.

description: Really liked this place .. the praram was a little too peanuty and heavy, but overall .. nice ambience, good food ... and a stone's throw away from where I live!
author: Antara B.

description: It's decent thai food.  Not extraordinary.  I wouldn't cry if they disappear from the map.
author: N. C.

description: Decent food. It can get really busy at lunch but it quiets down quite a bit after 2. I went here for the second time today, order noodles w/ chicken, picked up my order and went back to the office. It turned out to be tofu. Now I've been considering going vegetarian but I didn't want to start today! So I call and they said they will remake my order with chicken. I think they should have offered to deliver but I had to go back. I thought maybe they would offer to refund my meal or a freebie for next time, but no cigar. My coworker wanted spring rolls so I ordered them for her and they didn't even offer to comp. that.  Finally got back to my desk with my lunch and my new order is burnt. Go figure.
author: Holly E.

description: Fairly cheap place at affordable price.   Meat dishes could have had a little more meat, but otherwise, no complaints. The mango dessert is pretty damn good.
author: Chaz N.

description: Over-priced mediocre Thai food!  Plus they give you small portions too.  Even the beer was expensive.  I honestly don't see anything unique about this place.  Must be the name?
author: Jeff H.

description: Any restaurant that has monkey in its name has to be suspect. This place has decent thai food. But somehow, every time I eat there, I feel super bloated and sleepy! If you work in SoMA, this is probably the best thai restaurant in the area. If not, I wouldn't bother making the trek.
author: Aanand K.

description:
we were feeling adventurous for my boyfriend's birthday and decided to use urbanspoon on the iphone to find a restaurant. That's how we stumbled across Koh Samui. I was pleasantly surprised to find us able to make a reservation on short notice that friday night... which can go both ways as far as that being a good thing... when i made the reservation i told the hostess that we were celebrating a birthday and she mentioned that there were options we could discuss once i got there. cool. and jd was none the wiser so far.
upon arrival at the monkey i sent the boy to the bar to order drinks while the hostess and i covertly went over our mission... operation chocolate cake was underway by the time i met jd at the bar. the cocktails are very creative and my sake/lychee cosmo (when did i get so girly?!) was quite yummy. The bartender was pretty rad as well and gave us some good advice on a bottle of sake for the table.
we were overall pretty happy with the food- the chicken satay left a bit of something to be desired (had it a hundred times better at thai orchid in santa cruz) but the little samosa appetizer was very yum. 
by then end of the meal things were looking up... until our waiter came and asked if we'd like dessert. DOH! i kind of blinked at him a few times before i suggested he maybe talk to the hostess about that. he immediately realized what he'd done and then started apologizing over and over! noooo! my cover was hella blown and for the next 10 minutes i had to listen to jd ask me "what did you do? he better not sing to me" over and over. quick- bring more sake!
when said cake and sake DID come, lowly waiter guy actually started to sing happy birthday all by his lonesome to my boyfriend. awkward! a second waitress went to pour our sake and spilled a good half of a shot on the table, never to be seen again. 
all in all we paid a bit too much for alright food and pretty crappy service- i won't write you off, monkey, but i'm gonna keep searching for a staple thai haunt in the meantime.
author: saraH c.

description: My favorite Thai place in SF.  The red curry has just enough spice, and the panang curry is delicious too.  The lunch prices are very reasonable.  They are  very quick too!
author: ellana f.

description:
holy crap, this is the best thai food i've had in a LONG time!  started off by partaking in happy hour and got a nice buzz off $3 drinks, woot!

- bag of gold appetizer (really good sauce)
- panang curry with some freaking bomb meat (you gotta ask for the good meat and extra curry on the side)
- pad see yoo with chicken (you can never go wrong with this!)
- we had some duck dish and eggplant dish too, but i'm not a big fan of either.  i heard they were good though :)

good service!  they hooked us up with happy hour prices as we continued to drink at our table and our food came out pretty quickly too.
author: Yale P.

description: The food here is fantastic. The only thing that made me make this place a three star place versus a four star place are the prices. Outside of that, this place is delicious. All of the curries are fantastic. I'm a huge fan of the pompano and the pad thai. The infused vodkas are a treat as well, but if you're not into that sort of thing you can't miss with a thai iced tea.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Good Thai place... And I like the restaurant environment too! The nice array of hot sauces are also a plus...  :) They have a good lunch special for curry dishes too!
author: Lucy C.

description: yet another office fav in the hood. we've probably been here about 250 times. I definitely recommend their vegetarian dishes. they make a mean tofu dish. the cashew nut tofu, the tofu peanut sauce, mixed vegetables with tofu, etc. the imperial rolls are fabulous. I am not a vegetarian, but I gravitate towards those dishes because the meat is always a bit off. I have had the cashew nut chicken and several other dishes with chicken (curry) and it has been disappointingly over-cooked and rubbery. the seafood dishes are not impressive either. stick to the tofu. very yummy!
author: a w.

description: This restaurant was yummy in my tummy!  I will mainly speak for the appetizers... absolutely scrumptious!  And the dishes looked very cute, well presented.  The restaurant decor was really nice too.  Overpriced though.
author: Labonee M.

description: Expensive but the service is genuinely nice and the ladies bathroom is awesome (they have flyers for lost pets from all over the world)!!! Also, their chicken satay should be made illegal. It's too damn good. Someone had to sell their soul to learn how to cook that good. Mmmmm!
author: M J.

description: First off, Koh Samui needs better service.  We sat around waiting for our waiter and so did the nearby tables.  Second, they never brought a couple of cocktails we ordered.  That aside, their food is pretty good.  Their springs rolls were fresher than expected and the Tom Ka Gai soup gets an A.  For entrees be sure to try the Asapragus Prawns and Crushed Sesame Scallops with baby bok choy in yellow curry sauce (my favorite dish of the night).  The decor is real nice too and gives this place a cool vibe.
author: Julie K.

description:
I go here because it's the only Thai restaurant within a 5-minute walking distance of my work. Even then, I don't save much time because the takeout service takes its sweet time.

Let's talk about how I spent $19 for Thai iced tea, the green curry chicken, and brown rice. What the hell? Boo. I know it was dinner and all, but the curry portions were piddling and the Thai iced tea was mostly ice. 

And there was the time I got their hot and sour noodle soup. So. very. bland. My hot sauce-fiendin' tastebuds died a little that day.

Three stars only because I've also had a pleasant, window-side sit-down dining experience. This place is definitely hit or miss.
author: Mia L.

description: Excellent imperial rolls, pumpkin chicken curry, cashew shrimp, and tofu triangles. My new favorite Thai in SF.
author: Sarah T.

description:
I'll write the disclaimer first - I've only been here once.

The one time I came to this place, it was pretty atrocious. The service was horrible. It took the waiter 30 minutes to bring out our water and the place was empty! 

The food was pretty horrible as well. I got some egg noodle dish and the noodles were soggy and stuck together. Also there were like 3 noodles and the rest was bitter bok choy. I only had two bites before fighting a gag reflex. 

Oh yeah and the waitresses were half naked and kinda trashy. This one girl had a halter top on with a regular bra so you could see the red bra straps. Classy. I guess this could be considered a perk for some people...

Ugh, not going to this place again. Ever.
author: A K.

description: Tasty food, but it can get really loud during busy hours.
author: Bibi B.

description: Food is pretty good. We usually do take out.  A little more costly than what we normally like to pay for Thai but hey this is SF.
author: Patrick Z.

description: I was forced to come here by my co-workers after a corporate function nearby. The food is barely above average and mediocre. The portions are small and overpriced. My 2 stars is for the interior decor and cocktails.  I can go eat at other Thai restaurants (ie. Osha, King of Thai) and experience similar flavors at a 80% discount.
author: Joseph N.

description: Nice ambiance and presentation. Food was better than a lot of the mediocre Thai joints around town, but not the best I've had either. Has a nice looking bar, would probably be a good place for a date.
author: Joseph R.

description: Love it!!!  This is a great place to meet the girls out.  The place is lovely and intimate.  The cocktails and food were tasty.  Lots of complex flavor, inventive presentation and really fresh ingredients.
author: Gita P.

description: Great thai food and and adorable setting... love the pics in the bathroom of  ads for missing pets.
author: Shellie N.

description: I'll defnitely be back.  The pumpkin curry is to die for, the service attentive yet not overdone, the cocktails are well made for and the portions are reasonable.  I like the decor - reminds me of Asia.
author: J M.

description:
went here w/ my vegetarian friend. 

she loves that place. it was ok for me = 3 1/2 stars
However since Ritu loved that i am adding 1/2 * :-)

Ritu even got a jar of their peanut sauce, saying w/ rice it  would be a perfect monday lunch for her  (i wish i can be satisfied w/ soo little )
author: Lena M.

description: I go to Koh Samui & the Monkey at least once a week.  Their food is fresh and not as greasy as other thai restaurants.  Their staff is also professional and friendly.
author: B A.

description: Just got take out from there last night as a matter of fact.  Sesame Curried Scallops /w Steamed Bok Choy -- my all time favorite there.  The spring rolls are also great.  Always good service the times I've been there but I will agree with other reviewers that the staff tend to be a little pesky at times.  That's why I do take out :-)
author: abdullah s.

description: This is GREAT Thai food, I don' t know what the other people are talking about.  Everyone I have ever taken there loved it too.  The pumpkin curry with chicken is incredible. I also love the regular green curry with beef.  It's not on the menu, but the Pad Seuw(sp?) is great. There is a great seafood stew (it's not called that, but it's really good). In general all the food is cooked well and has nice subtle flavors. The service is also really great. The staff is kind, gentle and courteous.  Great place for a date.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: OK, but better food elsewhere. Nice decor and good service, but disappointing food. Can't put my finger on what exactly is missing from the food. It's just kinda bleh. Is that descriptive enough for ya?
author: Bruce C.

description: Yum! I tried one of the lunch specials ($7.95) - BBQ chicken w/green papaya salad and rice. The sauce that came on the side was sooo...good! The papaya salad was spicy and tasty. I would love to return and try other dishes! My friend had the Noodles w/peanut sauce and ate almost all of it (took the leftovers to go). I thought the other lunch specials were a bit pricey ($10 - $12). One thing to note if you haven't been there-- I walked past the entrance because it didn't look like it led to the restaurant. I peeked around the corner to see if the entrance was on the side. As I waited for my friend, I someone else do that, too!
author: Michele O.

description: The pumpkin chicken curry here is AWESOME!  Reservations are never necessary and they have a nice long bar with TV's if you need to wait for a table.  The service can be slow.  $50 for two with appetizers and we always have leftovers.
author: Luke L.

description: Above average Thai food with spotty service.  The food is good, but so many times the waiter's will just disappear.  Very crowded at lunch so wait to eat late if you want to walk right in and sit down.
author: Pele N.

description:
I love this place. I have been coming here for a couple of years, and they offer a steady level of deliciousness combined with friendly staff.

When you go, get the corn cakes and chicken satay, which is state of the art. Then follow it with the pumpkin curry, spicy green beans and whatever else you desire. This place always hits the spot.
author: Lucie T.

description:
Really expensive (even during lunch), sub-par Thai food. I mean, $9 for freakin TOFU pad thai. I work around the corner from this place, so I go there when I get a Thai craving. I don't know why though, as it NEVER satisfies it and inevitably just makes the craving worse and I have to go and pay for more Thai food for dinner or later in the week. Everything I've gotten from Koh Samui seems to be oddly oversweetened. 

You'd think I'd learn my lesson by now. Maybe I shouldn't be so lazy and walk the extra two blocks down to Cha-Am. 

In any case, save yourself some money, and go somewhere else.
author: Jazmin C.

description: It's pretty good thai for being in the neighborhood. Nothing to call home about. Service is pretty quick.
author: George M.

description: As a warning, the menu can be a bit hit or miss, so I don't recommend everyone in a group ordering the same thing if this is your first time here.  That said, several of the spicy and/or peanut based dishes are pretty good.  Portion sizes are decent, as is the size of the appetizers [the various rolls are good].  The tea is served very hot [this is good] but I always seem to have trouble not spilling from the weird artsy teacup.  Prices for lunch are good, and are okay for dinner.  One of the better food options in the ballpark area.  I wouldn't necessarily go here over some other Thai places in the city, but given that I work near here and that noone I know seems to dislike it, I am sure I will end up here again and again.
author: Alured P.

description:
went to koh samui for a workie lunch and was pleasantly surprised.  aside for the service which was decidedly off for an empty restaurant, the experience was very enjoyable.  i had the pad thai with chicken since i'm pretty basic when it comes to thai food.  nice portion size - meaning i didn't head directly into the food coma when i returned.  

it was a birthday - so we had to get dessert - order the flaming banana!  it's de-lish. 

if you're going for lunch i advise going earlier - it fills up around noon!
author: Kristin K.

description: I had dinner here this past Friday night. I am a very picky eater so I usually order some of the same Thai dishes. Pad See Eu Chicken is my favorite dish and they did not have it on the menu. I did however ask the waitress if it was available. They did have it and I was able to order it. It was pretty good- but I like Tara much better. The Spring Rolls were fantastic! I would give this place 4 stars- but they are getting 3 because the service was really slow. I ordered a glass of wine up front- then we placed our order. We had to flag down the waitress for my date to order a beer. I love Thai food- and I know it doesn't take too long to make- but when you want to enjoy a dinner date with a few cocktails- you want the first course to come then have a little bit of time before getting your main course. With the food coming out so quickly after we ordered- I felt a little rushed. All in all good food and GREAT decor!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Sunburst Pomelo and Fruit salad is THE BEST SALAD IN SAN FRANCISCO. it is a mixture of like 10 different veggies - nicely prepped, fresh, etc.

staff is friendly but unattentive. every time i go there, they bring out food in wrong order, and fail to bring out drinks in time for meal.. weird. 

be careful about parking on the street - lots of break-ins - even during the dinner hour. hide your stuff. 

ps - great ambience - cool teak furniture and buddhas everywhere.
author: David F.

description: Great Thai place in Soma. They have some pretty authentic thai dishes mixed up with the normal fare. Prices are a little high for thai food, but quality is still quite good. also great for take out.
author: Peter K.

description: Lunch spot in Soma, food is ok.  Very busy during lunch due to lack of options in the area and service is bad.  Some portions are very small for the price, ingredients seem fresh.  Try getting some water or your check and it will take 10 minutes...
author: May M.

description: This  place is great, a combo of great food, pleasant staff and fun cocktails. The portions are large enough to share and there are many tasty choices like pumkin curry or grilled pork with mango salad. Last night I tried the Shock the Monkey Cocktail and  can't say a bad thing about it. Oh and the desserts are kinda exciting ,using  treats like pumkin and water chestnuts. The best time to go is right as the sunsets the lighting is  very peaceful but if  romance is your aim get the table in the back near the buddha later in the evening, it's quite cozy.
author: Jetsetgirl B.

description: I'm kind of sad to see all the bad reviews.  Perhaps I've been eating crap Thai food or something, or maybe these people are expecting too much.  It's not hole-in-the-wall, dirty authentic Thai - it's clean, Pottery Barn-style Asian ambiance, flirting-with-fusion Thai.  I mean, come on, they give you chopsticks.  Real Thai food doesn't have chopsticks...  it's fork and spoon for the genuine article.  But, hey, I like eating with chopsticks, I like my furniture and dinnerware not to be sticky, and I don't mind if my Thai food isn't spicy enough to make me cry.  My husband and I had Pad See Ew and the Yellow Chicken Curry with Fresh Spring Rolls.  The food was served almost as fast as we ordered it, and the waiter was friendly.  I thought everything was delicious - the noodles were a little oily, but that just makes them good.  Thumbs up for the Monkey.
author: Stacey W.

description:
Service- Gave us a reservation time for 8.45 and finally seated us at 9.35! Then there was no sign of the waiters till we made some noise.  Took a while to get our main course as well.

Food- Was average.  I have had better Thai for the price. We tried the peanut on a leaf and samosas for appetizers and they were creative and the sauces were decent.  The main course was not very creative-- the sea bass was too oily and the pumpkin curry was too sweet. Salmon with string beans was decent,

Decor-- decent, the hostesses clothes were very decor appropriate!
author: Malini P.

description:
In The Know: Right of the bat I knew I was going to love this design. It isn't like every other restaurant that is street level; you actually have to go up a small flight of stairs to get there. (Its not that it is the only restaurant that is like this in SF but I haven't blogged on those places yet so outta sight, outta mind - at least for now so back off!) It is great as far as restaurants go because you feel better than everyone else when you are looking down upon all the other restaurant minions...muahahahaha. At the top of the stairs is a bench with bronze see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil monkeys. Great touch seeing as how the restaurant has monkey in the title and flippin monkeys everywhere (all thats missing is the barrel). Once you enter the full bar is to your immediate left, a great water fountain/Buddha sculpture/partition situation separating the dining area. The tables and chairs used to furnish the restaurant was only one of the things that really tickled my pickle. One could say custom build furniture is a fetish of mine so....hi, creators of those fabulous wood/metal pieces...hi ;) The other pickle tickler was how they incorporated the obvious Thai decor in a warehousey shell. There was almost floor to ceiling warehouse windows (generally it is several small panes of glass) and exposed ventilation system. On one of the walls there was an incredible Buddha sculpture surrounded by candles adding to a very intimate feel throughout the whole space. It would definitely be a great place to take a date, if your into the looking down through warehouse windows at other restaurants while surrounded by monkeys, sculptures, and candles siting on fabulous chairs...kinda thing. 


Behind The Bar: A sexy tattoo, slick haired, beautiful eyed, pirate looking chap. Please don't mistake the mention of this pirate with the SF's infamous pirate (General Lee) that works (ed) at the Beauty Bar. Oh, no no no. He is a much cleaner cut and of the more delicious variety. However, even with the pretty ones I can always find fault. My one qualm with him is I think he thought I was some sort of undercover agent sent by the powers that be (i.e. his bosses) to make sure that nothing but whispers of sweet nothings come from his supple lips. Translation: he was boring and withheld all the juicy gossip from me. He mentioned how nice it was to have large windows surrounding the space allowing for the sun to heat the room up itself. That's it, that's all I get!?! I blame in on his equally boring and non-imaginative colleagues/friends siting at the bar. You don't have to be shy with me and look at your friends to help you answer questions my sensual succulent. If he was to humor me, however, he would have said that in the dining section they tried to squeeze to many tables into the space. There was no coherent flow. Unless you know the layout extremely well, it was hard to navigate the maze. Some tables where just far enough apart that made you think you could fit through them but come to find out after sipping on the Pumpkin curry chicken in red curry sauce served in pumpkin you realize how tight your cloths fit now and promise to start tomorrow with your Extreme Makeover: Stop telling yourself your going to start tomorrow and just do it already! edition...so getting between these tables was a bit harder than you could imagine. Thanks for the help and words of wisdom you sexy lil pirate vixen you; I'll be after your booty soon... 


Who's Who: Other than the aforementioned pirates' shipmates at the bar, I saw two after work ladies and a group of diners in their mid 30's (ish). Not a whole lot to work with. (It also was 7pmish on a Thursday. pretty much been proven that is exactly the hour where no one goes out to eat....ummm....ya) Let me paint you a picture of what kinda crowd I can imagine would frequent this kinda joint: at the bar we have a mixture of 20-30 somethings sipping on tasty beverages after a long and extremely prosperous day at work. Everyone is enjoying each others companies, laughing at each others jokes, and lining up to buy me shots;) The dining room is filled with folks of all ages and backgrounds, from a grandma knitting in the corner to Jesus playing cards with 50 cent to children hiccuping rainbows to Johnny Depp (the real, and my forever #1 pirate) feeding me strawberries to everyone lining up to buy me shots. Come to think of it, I am an extremely great artist and think I really should frequent this place more often. 

Find this review on Behind the Bar - www.btbdesign.blogspot.com
author: Sheyna G.

description:
Came here about a year ago with some friends and remembered liking it. So went back for dinner this week.  Our meal was as follows:

Chef's testing platter: Fresh Spring roll, Crispy imperial roll, Prawns, Sweet Corn, Mieng Kum, Chicken satay skewers and Mango Salad
with 3 dipping sauces
*since I like variety, this was a great starter piece...especially liked the crispy imperial roll and prawns. Mango salad was okay. And the mieng kum was the only thing that I didnt like-a bit too salty and sweet with a weird texture

Honey roasted duck and pineapple simmered in red curry sauce
*highly recommend. not so generous with the duck, but the few pieces they had were appetizing.  The sauce was sweet (gathering it from the pinnaple and tomatoe) and flavorful.

pad thai-with tofu and chicken
(definately skip this, hardly any flavor. barely saved by me adding hot sauce, peppers, and soy sauce)

And definately skip the asian beers they have (forget the names...but one from singapore and one from Thailand).
author: Jane P.

description: We always end up ordering mostly appetizers here.  Their selection is really nice.  I recommend their Bags of Gold (usually a special app).  It has a nice crispy crunch!  The waitstaff has always been really friendly and courteous- though they don't really talk much.  Not bad....not Excellent either.  It's a good choice for something casual in that area :)
author: Tracy B.

description: There's nothing overtly wrong with this place, but sadly that's the best compliment I have.  The food is flashy but uninspired.  Ditto the service.  And it's all priced for the SOMA set without providing any value above a neighborhood take out Thai joint.  If you're looking for a nice atmosphere for a business lunch on someone else's dime, and you like bland Americanized Thai, have at it.
author: Chris J.

description: Very good thai with a fun environment. Having just moved to Soma I was relieved to find such an awesome thai restaurant within walking distance. The pumpkin curry was fantastic, definitely becoming my usual here. I went on a friday night and the place was packed. We were able to get a table right away by the bar, but I would recommend getting reservations just in case. Drink menu is great, I had the Thai Kiss which wasn't too strong but did the trick.
author: jess c.

description: great place for business lunch - try the green beef curry
author: Duke H.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant in SF. I have been there many times, and the food is always great-- fresh, tasty, and well-presented. The staff are very friendly and helpful, and I've never had to wait long for a table. Delicious and highly recommended!!
author: L T.

description: I love this place! Excellent food, great ambiance, and impeccable service. We had dinner here recently and  I found the whole experience to be highly enjoyable. The yellow curry is delicious!
author: Girseach S.

description:
It's not the best.

I like OSHA better.  I get the impression the OSHA people are nicer people, don't know why.

Koh Samui is OK, if you don't have any other dinner options.

It's expensive for Thai food.

Go to Manora for homey Thai food.

Go to Osha for dinner with friends.

Go to Koh Samui if you're in the hood anyway and need to grab a business casual lunch or after work dinner.
author: SOMA lady S.

description: After three visits to Koh Samui, I've added it to my list of favorite Thai restaurants in the city.  It is excellent value for the money and offers a nice variety of food.  I've always been seated within 10 minutes, and the wait staff is attentive and efficient.
author: Katie M.

description:
Loved our meals from Koh Samui and the Monkey!

Great food, an authentic (for me) vibe and well balanced flavors.  I took a class in Thai Cooking and though I still prefer to make it myself (it tends to taste better and I can tailor more) for convenience I would go to KSATM first for a quick-fix or if I'm feeling lazy.   :o)
author: Steve T.

description: I don't love the food here, and you can certainly find better Thai in this city. However, the drinks are great, and the service is terrific. It's the only one of four bars that I went to where the bartender happily switched the TV channel to Obama's speech at the Democratic Convention, and he even turned it up for us to hear. I'll be back for happy hour and perhaps some pad thai as well.
author: Andrew S.

description: I've only been here for lunch, but I continue to be impressed by the quality of both their food and presentation.  The lunch combos are a great deal, and give you a chance to get a sampling of different dishes.  I highly recommend the duck curry.
author: Kevin O.

description:
I give this rip off joint 1 star, because it is a very beautifully decorated rip off joint.
I have just created this yelp profile because i couldn't let Koh Samui get away with it!!
I just finished eating my take away Pad Thai which cost me $17.50!!!!
Let me explain, I did get a shrimp pad thai, and I also asked for extra noodles (as I have heard that there portions are small) and said I would be happy to pay for them (the extra noodles). I'm not obese and greedy, just was starving.
So I would have thought that maybe after you take a 7.95 pad thai (a pile of noodles) add shrimp $2 + a few extra noodles $2 more? so a $12.00 pad Thai feast you might think...
These dish took 25 minutes to be ready in which time I sat at the bar and was not asked if i wanted a drink for about fifteen minutes. It arrived and i went back to work where i discovered the smallest portion of Pad Thai I have ever had. No extra noodles and the noodles that were there were so overcooked they were like mush. My shrimp were completely overcooked too and had only the smallest bit more flavor than the flavorless tofu in the dish.
It was honestly the smallest and worst pad thai I have ever had and it set me back $17.50....$17.50!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I could feed two people at the delicious Ploy thai in upper Haight for this much, and have left overs.
Koh Samui is clever, they've branded themselves to stupid rich yuppies who get scared at places that aren't perfectly manicured and it works. I know it works and will continue to work because SF has an everlasting supply of stupid rich yuppies!!
Enjoy being ripped off guys....
author: Miles P.

description: we ordered grilled BBQ chicken and Miracle Duck with coconut rice... this is bestest even bestest than thai rest.place in Sydney...
author: vycandy c.

description:
Over rated & over priced. I've never had great service here, but that is probably because I have only come here for group-dinners. 

Food is "meh", but the ambiance is nice.
author: Willow B.

description:
kind of expensive, but really good... really fresh ingredients. i was especially surprised by the quality of the meat. I had the panang curry and shredded beef--- my lord it was tasty.

also, the decor is exceedingly pleasant.
author: matica g.
